{"uri": "8186619982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "08:27:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T08:27:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T08:25:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/football/lionel-messi-set-to-appear-one-last-time-emotional-scenes-expected-in-2024-copa-america-101718870937544.html", "title": "Lionel Messi set to appear one last time? Emotional scenes expected in 2024 Copa America", "body": "Messi-mania is at an all-time high as the great man looks to have another major trophy in the bag. The 2024 Copa America starts early Friday morning with defending champions Argentina taking on Canada at Atlanta in the United States of America.\n\nIn all likelihood, this is going to be Messi's last international tournament. The next major tournament is going to be the World Cup in 2026 and the forward, who is going to turn 37 next week, can't sure have enough legs to last another two years, can he? Football is a demanding game after all, not just mentally, but also physically.\n\nThat's why the 2024 Copa America becomes such an important spectacle for fans all over the world. Last time when the tournament happened in 2021, things were starkly different for the Argentine superstar. He had not had any major international trophy to speak of and fans and experts alike were questioning his greatness. He appeared to have fallen behind Cristiano Ronaldo - winner of Euro 2016 with Portugal -- in the GOAT debate too.\n\nThree years on... a lot has happened. Feels like Providence had a hand as Messi not only won the Copa America in 2021 but the very next year he also won the biggest trophy on the planet. Yes, the World Cup in Qatar. Mind you, he wasn't just a participant. He actually played a very important role in the South American nation's success in those two tournaments. The GOAT debate was swiftly thrown out the window.\n\nMessi is heading into the 2024 edition as an ultra-achiever. There is nothing to prove. World Cup winner, Copa America winner, one of highest goal-scorers in the history of international football and highly decorated footballer at club level... he has seen and done it all.\n\nBut if it's going to his last international tournament, we have seen him enough in action to know that he is going to do his damnedest to win another trophy. In the months before the 2021 Copa America, he was visibly on the decline, didn't look as potent as before. The way he has resurrected himself since says a lot about what kind of person he is, and his mentality.\n\nBelieve it or not, there is a strong possibility that if Argentina can defend their Copa title successfully, he may continue and eventually feature in the US-Canada-Mexico event in 2026.\n\nHis strategy is very clear. He is taking one tournament at a time. If he can be resourceful on the pitch benefiting his team in a desired way, why should he call it quits?! This argument perfectly makes sense.\n\nMessi could have left after the 2022 World Cup win. There couldn't have been a better time. But the fact he didn't suggests his hunger for trophies was not satiated after all. So, there is a very strong possibility that Messi continues to play for Argentina even after the Copa. Besides, he has not said anything concrete about whether the Copa will be his last appearance.\n\nWe will know that soon enough. For now, we should treat the Copa America as if it's Messi's last appearance. The European Championship - Copa's equivalent -- is also going on at present and whenever these two tournaments coincide, the Euros manages to get more eyeballs, for, from a holistic point of view, much better teams and players are on view over there.\n\nBut thanks to the uncertainty surrounding him, there will be plenty of focus on the tournament this time around. The 2024 Copa America is going to be an emotional ride for his fans, to be sure. In the absence of Neymar of Brazil owing to injury, Messi is carrying the flag for both the North and South continents now.\n\nWhen all is said and done, whatever may be the outcome of the tournament and whether or not Messi decides to continue, his place in history as one of the greatest footballers is already sealed. Fourteen stadiums across the US will host the Copa America matches. The USA also hosted the 2016 edition, which Chile won after defeating Argentina on penalties after a goalless final. The teams have been divided into four groups. The top two teams from the four groups will progress to the quarter-finals. The Copa America 2024 final is slated to take place at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami on July 15. The sole loss came in November 2023 with a 2-0 loss to Uruguay.\n\nCanada enters the tournament as one of the longer shots to win the tournament. The team did not make it out of the group stage of the 2022 World Cup, going 0-0-3. Since then, the squad's gone 6-4-4.\n\nWANNA BET? Records with Argentina national team ahead of finals in US", "body": "Lionel Messi is the top scorer in the history of the Argentine national team, and a good portion of those goals have come in Copa America matches, a competition in which in he could soon move up the list of historical all-time top scorers.\n\nThe Inter Miami icon has won pretty much all there is to win at club and international level, and his influence is likely to be critical if Argentina are to go all the way again in 2024 and claim a record 16th title.\n\nBut exactly how many goals does Messi have in the Copa America? And which rivals has he scored against? The Sporting News has all the details.\n\nMORE: Argentina schedule at Copa America 2024, all Messi's matches here\n\nLionel Messi has scored 13 goals in the Copa America during his career so far.\n\nHe first got off the mark in the tournament with two goals in the 2007 competition, in which Argentina finished as runners-up after being beaten by arch-rivals Brazil 3-0 in the final.\n\nIt would be eight years before he got his next goals on the continental stage, as in back-to-back years La Albiceleste were dealt heartbreak by Chile in the final.\n\nMessi netted once in the 2015 tournament, as hosts Chile won the trophy, and it was a repeat 12 months later for the Copa America Centenario in 2016 in the USA. Chile again prevailed against Messi, as he missed his spot-kick in the penalty shootout and Jorge Sampaoli's side held their nerve.\n\nMessi was far more prolific in that tournament, with five goals from his six matches, but so heartbroken was he after a second successive final defeat that Argentina's talisman opted to initially retire from international football after the game.\n\nThree years later, however, he was back. He scored once in 2019 and then four times in 2021, when he was finally able to get his first title in the competition. That was the precursor to his first-ever World Cup title 12 months later in Qatar.\n\nCuriously, his only Copa America in which he did not score was the only one he played at home: in Argentina in Prior to the tournament, Argentina, Canada, Chile, and Peru were sorted into Group A, and Canada have the unlucky pleasure of playing the 2021 winners in their first ever Copa America match.\n\nCanada's lack of experience in the tournament is the complete opposite to Argentina's Copa America dominance. Lionel Messi just lifted Argentina's 15th Copa America title two years ago, and will look to lead his team to a strong start against Jesse Marsch's squad in La Albiceleste's campaign to go back-to-back.\n\nHere's 90min's guide to Argentina vs Canada tomorrow.\n\nArgentina are coming into this summer's Copa America after winning both of their tournament tune-ups in fairly convincing fashion, extending their unbeaten run to five matches.\n\nEnzo Fernandez and Lisandro Mart\u00ednez have recovered from their respective injuries and are fully fit for the competition, giving Lionel Scaloni some decisions to make in the midfield and on the backline. Jesse Marsch has only been in charge for a month, and the manager has yet to secure his first win. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nA look at the tournament: There will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The US, Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the US, which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 US venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. {"uri": "2024-06-392839003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:45:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:45:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/lionel-messi-argentina-try-3rd-straight-major-title-copa-america/61148465", "title": "Lionel Messi and Argentina will try for a 3rd straight major title in Copa America", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain's feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.Coming off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.He has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina's national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.Argentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.Brazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.Spain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.A look at the tournament:Expanded fieldThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.Back in the USAEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.Eleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.CONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.U.S. teamThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup -- the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada -- and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.Christian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we'll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It's a special time for this sport in America.\"World Cup test?In 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.Unlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.At MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... Not only can we track the drone, but more importantly, we can track where the operator is.\"\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain's feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.\n\nComing off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\n\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nHe has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina's national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nA look at the tournament:\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.\n\nCONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup -- the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada -- and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.\n\nChristian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\n\n\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we'll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It's a special time for this sport in America.\"\n\nIn 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.\n\nAt MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\n\n\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... {"uri": "8185634540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:17:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:17:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:15:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13547649/Soccer-Messis-Argentina-face-debutants-Canada-Copa-opener.html", "title": "Soccer-Messi's Argentina face debutants Canada in Copa opener", "body": "June 19 (Reuters) - Defending champions Argentina, led by Lionel Messi, kick off their Copa America Group A campaign against tournament debutants Canada on Thursday in Atlanta.\n\nThe Argentines, who won the tournament in 2021 and went on to hoist the 2022 World Cup, are no strangers to Copa America success.\n\nThey reached the finals in 2015 and 2016 and finished third in 2019.\n\nThis year's tournament brings together 10 South American teams and six from North and Central America and the Caribbean, in the 48th edition of the tournament, hosted for the second time by the United States.\n\nHolding the tournament's all-time record with 34 top-three finishes and 128 match victories, Argentina are a formidable force.\n\nMessi, tied for seventh place in the tournament's all-time scoring chart with 13 goals, also holds the record with 17 assists.\n\nOn Thursday he will surpass Chile's Sergio Livingstone record by playing in his 35th Copa America match.\n\nArgentina, coached by Lionel Scaloni and featuring 21 players from their World Cup-winning squad, are tipped to make it to the final on July 14 in Miami, Florida.\n\nHowever, Messi insists they will not be complacent.\n\n\"Today, we can say that we are the best because we are the world champions. But that does not make us believe that we are going to win this Copa America by walking,\" Messi said.\n\nRanked number one in the FIFA world rankings, Argentina will face 49th-ranked Canada.\n\nWith newly appointed American coach Jesse Marsch, Canada are using the tournament as preparation for the 2026 World Cup which they will co-host with the U.S. and Mexico.\n\nCanada's Copa America squad features only two players over age 30 -- goalkeeper Maxime Crepeau (30) and midfielder Jonathan Osorio (32) -- and 15 are aged 25 or younger.\n\n\"I think it's been good for this new group. It's kind of a new era and guys are responding really well,\" Osorio said.\n\nThe youthfulness contrasts with Messi, who turns 37 on Monday and has shown no signs of slowing down, with 12 goals in 12 matches for Inter Miami in the MLS this season.\n\nCanada's next match is against Peru on Tuesday, the same day Argentina face Chile. Both teams will wrap up their group games on June 29 with Canada taking on Chile and Argentina playing Peru. (Reporting by Field Level Media, editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-395189017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:56:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:56:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:54:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/sports/article289399360.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 bigger than European Championship? Lionel Messi knows it is.", "body": "By Kevin Baxter, Los Angeles Times The Tribune Content Agency\n\nLOS ANGELES - Kylian Mbappe clearly ruffled some feathers last week when he suggested the European Championship was the world's most difficult international soccer competition.\n\n\"The Euros are complicated. For me, more complicated than a World Cup,\" the French national team captain said at a news conference before his team's first game.\n\nHold my beer, said former club teammate Lionel Messi, who led Argentina past France in an epic 2022 World Cup final, in which he and Mbappe - who broke his nose in France's Euro-opening win over Austria on Monday - combined for five of the game's six goals.\n\nSure the Euros, the quadrennial championship for FIFA's 55-member European confederation, is difficult. However, don't sleep on Copa Am\u00e9rica, the South American tournament expanded this year to include the U.S., Mexico and four other teams.\n\n\"Well, everybody prioritizes their tournament,\" Messi fired back in a TV interview ahead of the Copa Am\u00e9rica opener Thursday between Argentina and Canada. \"The Euros is very important and has the best teams, but he's leaving out three-time champion Argentina, five-time champion Brazil, two-time champion Uruguay.\n\n\"There are a lot of world champions left off to say that it's the most difficult tournament.\"\n\nNot just world champions. In top-ranked Argentina and No. 5 Brazil, the Copa Am\u00e9rica field also has two of the top five teams in the latest FIFA world rankings. Colombia, which is also in the 16-team field, hasn't lost in 23 games over more than two years, the longest unbeaten streak in international soccer.\n\nA third of the 24 teams in the top-heavy Euro field are ranked outside the top 32.\n\nWith that as an introduction, here are four things to watch when the 48th Copa Am\u00e9rica kicks off at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta:\n\nIt's a World Cup dress rehearsal\n\nThe South American championship is being played in the U.S. for the second time in eight years and eight of the 14 venues, including Inglewood's SoFi Stadium, also will play host to games in the 2026 World Cup. That makes the tournament an important trial run.\n\n\"We will always look at every event as a test for the next things that's coming up,\" said Otto Benedict, senior vice president for facility and campus operations at SoFi Stadium. \"Copa will allow us to have an international fan base that's coming through the building, so we're going to understand how those guests come, how they perceive the building.\"\n\nSoFi, which will stage eight games in the World Cup, will host two Copa group-stage matches: Brazil's tournament opener with Costa Rica on June 24 and Mexico's second game, with Venezuela, on June 26.\n\nBenedict said the stadium's Matrix Turf surface will be covered with a carpet of natural grass, a procedure that will be repeated for the World Cup, but the retractable bleachers in the corners will remain in place, leaving the pitch slightly narrower than FIFA will require for the World Cup.\n\n\"We're still going to have opportunities to learn,\" Benedict said. \"All those things are data points that will be collected.\"\n\nThe seven other Copa stadiums staging World Cup matches will conduct similar trials.\n\nCopa Am\u00e9rica will be a World Cup test for the USMNT as well\n\nThe 2026 World Cup will be a defining moment for the U.S., and the Copa might give an indication how the national team will be defined.\n\nIs the U.S. one of the world's top soccer-playing nations, as U.S. Soccer would like you to believe, or is it a pretender, a team that struggles against top competition and is undeserving of being ranked 11th - ahead of Colombia, Germany and Uruguay - in the latest FIFA rankings?\n\nAs a World Cup host, the U.S. - along with co-hosts Mexico and Canada - will not have to go through qualifying for 2026, making Copa the most challenging tournament it will face in the next two years.\n\nThe roster coach Gregg Berhalter will take into the team's opener against Bolivia at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Saturday is collectively the best in USMNT history, with 23 of 26 players coming off major European clubs. Copa provides an important international stage on which to display those talents.\n\n\"It's a chance for us to show, before the World Cup, that we're a team to be feared,\" defender Chris Richards told reporters.\n\nIs Berhalter up to the task?\n\nNo U.S. manager who has coached more than seven games has a better winning percentage than Berhalter, but given the quality of the roster and the team's recent struggles - the U.S. has won only two of its last six games - he has come under fire. The protests grew louder after an especially poor showing in a 5-1 loss to Colombia earlier this month.\n\nThe Copa group stage, in which the U.S. will play Bolivia, Panama and Uruguay, offers a chance to flip that script. The three teams will present vastly different challenges, giving Berhalter a chance to show off his coaching chops with three different game plans.\n\nGetting out of group play is the bare minimum for the U.S., but matters will get a little tougher if it advances and probably will face either Colombia or Brazil in the quarterfinals.\n\nWhat about the rest of the field?\n\nArgentina, the reigning World Cup champion and ranked No. 1 in the world, has lost only two of its last 57 games and has made the Copa Am\u00e9rica final a record 29 times, winning 15.\n\nAlthough the team led by the 36-year-old Messi has aged - 11 players over 30 and the third-oldest roster in the tournament - it appears to have a fairly comfortable path to a 30th final at Hard Rock Stadium in suburban Miami on July 14.\n\nWith Colombia and Brazil, Group D could be the toughest of the four four-team groups. Brazil, still without injured Neymar, needs to improve play after losing its last three games - albeit to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina - in CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying.\n\nEcuador, whose only losses in 14 games came to Argentina and Italy, could be a dark horse.", "source": {"uri": "bradenton.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bradenton Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/06/20/sports/usmnt-vs-uruguay-among-copa-americas-best-early-games/", "title": "USMNT's pre-World Cup test from Uruguay among Copa America's best...", "body": "Before hosting the World Cup in two years, the U.S. is getting an appetizer this summer.\n\nCopa America, South America's continental championship, will be played in America this summer for the first time in eight years, with North American teams invited to compete against the likes of Argentina, Brazil, Colombia and Uruguay.\n\nThough teams from outside South America have regularly been invited to Copa America, none have ever won the tournament, with Mexico's pair of final appearances in 1993 and 2001 accounting for the best result for a team outside the continent.\n\nThe U.S., Mexico and Canada, however, will be among the teams looking to change that this summer, starting on Thursday night.\n\nThe Post's Ethan Sears breaks down five games to watch in the Copa America group stage:\n\nIt's rare in an international tournament that the opening match is not contested by the host nation, but that will be the case in Miami on Thursday, since Lionel Messi is an enterprise of his own.\n\nArgentina opens its defense of the 2021 Copa title in Messi's new home city against a Canada squad that has struggled since an insurgent campaign to qualify for the 2022 World Cup.\n\nUnder new head coach Jesse Marsch, though, the Canadians will have their eyes on qualification for the knockout stage, with the opener being an immediate litmus test.\n\nOne of two group stage matches to be contested at MetLife Stadium should be one of the highlights of the early part of the tournament.\n\nThe last time Chile and Argentina faced off in New Jersey was in the 2016 Copa America final -- a 0-0 draw that ended with the Chileans winning a penalty shootout to deny Messi's Argentina a first major trophy.\n\nChile's core is on the older side now and it will come as no surprise that Argentina will be considerable favorites in this game.\n\nBut this is a classic South American rivalry and a chance to catch Messi close to home, and that alone qualifies it for this slot.\n\nAs the U.S. has risen to the top of North American soccer, so too has Mexico fallen off a perch it once dominated.\n\nA failure to make it out of the group stage in the Qatar World Cup represented the worst result for Mexico at the tournament since they were banned from the 1990 edition, and the worst at a tournament in which they qualified since 1978.\n\nCoach Jaime Lozano, a native of Mexico, comes into this tournament with the program under immense scrutiny despite winning the 2023 Gold Cup, and with a chance for his squad to prove itself in front of what will be a de facto home crowd in every game.\n\nMexico should get out of a group that also includes Ecuador, Venezuela and Jamaica, but this match against the Ecuadorians will be their biggest test of the three.\n\nIf they can win it -- and likely win the group along with it -- that would likely mean avoiding Argentina in the quarterfinals.\n\nThere is not quite as much unease with the USMNT heading into this tournament as with Mexico, but compared to the optimism heading into the World Cup two years ago, Gregg Berhalter's squad is very much at a crossroads.\n\nUruguay, a traditional South American powerhouse, will be the first major test of this Copa America for a squad that has yet to score a victory against such a team.\n\nThe result here will help set the tone for the discourse around the national team for the next couple years -- though not as much as the ultimate outcome of this tournament -- and is likely to decide the group winner.\n\nIt's a shame that Brazil-Colombia is the Group D finale and not the opener, since it's possible that both teams will have secured advancement by the time they face off.\n\nStill, this looks on paper like the best match of the group stage, and could determine the U.S. opponent in the quarterfinal should the Americans advance.\n\nBrazil is in a particularly interesting spot coming into this tournament, with a new generation headlined by Vinicius Jr., Rodrygo and Endrick stepping into the spotlight.\n\nA 1-1 draw against the USMNT in its last match before the tournament caused histrionics at home, with Brazilian legend Ronaldinho blasting the squad and saying he wouldn't watch the Copa.\n\nWe'll see whether he ultimately goes back on that promise.", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil feature an attack headed by Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The US, Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nEcuador were picked to host the tournament under the rotation of Conmebol, the South American governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the US, which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nConmebol says more than one million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nIn 2016, Conmebol partnered with the US Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. {"uri": "2024-06-395895281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:27:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:27:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.aol.com/copa-am-rica-2024-lionel-110355270.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024: Lionel Messi's final 'Last Dance' with Argentina?", "body": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024: Lionel Messi's final 'Last Dance' with Argentina?\n\nMatias Grez, CNN\n\nJune 20, 2024 at 1:03 PM\n\nFor just the second time in the tournament's 108-year history, the Copa Am\u00e9rica will be played outside of South America.\n\nAs it did in 2016 for the special centenary, the United States will host this year's expanded edition that will feature 16 teams rather than the customary 12 and will be something of a dress rehearsal for the 2026 World Cup, which will be hosted in the US, Mexico and Canada.\n\nTaking part will be the 10 CONMEBOL nations as usual, plus the US, Mexico, Jamaica and Panama, which all qualified as semifinalists of the CONCACAF Nations League.\n\nAdditionally, Costa Rica and Canada also qualified via the playoffs contested between the losing Nations League quarterfinalists.\n\nThis year's tournament runs from June 20 to July 14.\n\nThe favorite\n\nUnsurprisingly, Lionel Messi's Argentina is the favorite to lift the trophy for a record-breaking 16th time.\n\nThree years ago, Messi helped the Albiceleste to glory at the Covid-delayed 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica, beating host Brazil in the final, his first major trophy with the national team and the country's first in 28 years.\n\nThat victory lifted the weight of expectation off his shoulders and more than likely acted as a catalyst for Argentina's World Cup victory in Qatar 18 months later, with Messi finally getting his hands on the one trophy he had craved most.\n\nPreviously tormented by his failures with Argentina, even retiring temporarily from international football after a second straight Copa Am\u00e9rica final defeat to Chile in 2016, Messi told Argentine outlet Infobae recently that he's now \"achieved everything.\"\n\nThere is the real possibility that the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica will be the last major international tournament Messi plays. After previously stating that the 2022 World Cup would be his last, Messi told Star+ in December that \"time will tell.\"\n\n\"As long as I feel I am well and that I am able to help, I will do it,\" Messi, who will turn 37 during the Copa Am\u00e9rica, said. \"Today, all I think about is to get well to the Copa Am\u00e9rica and play it. Fight for it again, as we always do, try to be the champions.\n\n\"If we do well at Copa Am\u00e9rica and I can keep playing, maybe it happens.\"\n\nBut Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni, who has overseen just four defeats in the team's last 50 games, had a message for Messi fans: Don't worry about the future, just enjoy the now.\n\n\"We Argentines are too melancholic and we are already thinking about the day when he is gone while he's still playing,\" Scaloni said last week. \"So let's enjoy him and we'll see what happens tomorrow. I think the present is so important for the whole world - not only for Argentina - because, in the end, Leo plays for everyone who likes football.\"\n\nOne player who will definitely be making his last tournament appearance for Argentina is \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda.\n\nThe 36-year-old has made 140 appearances for the national team and enjoys legendary status back home thanks to his winner in the final of the 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica and a goal in the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nDi Mar\u00eda also won the U20 World Cup in 2007 and an Olympic gold medal at Beijing 2008.\n\nThe best of the rest\n\nBrazil\n\nPreviously thought of as one of, if not the greatest football nation on earth, Brazil currently finds itself navigating a complicated transitional period.\n\nThe squad for the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica is largely inexperienced, with 15 players on less than 10 caps for their country. Only one player, West Ham's Lucas Paquet\u00e1, has reached 10 goals for Brazil, making the omissions of Casemiro and Richarlison all the more surprising.\n\nThe Sele\u00e7\u00e3o is still reeling from the absence of star man Neymar Jr., who ruptured his ACL playing for the national team in October. Brazil's all-time record goalscorer and a player with the ability to change a game in an instant, Neymar will be sorely missed for his contributions on the pitch, but also his leadership and status as an icon in an inexperienced dressing room.\n\nBrazil recently suffered back-to-back World Cup qualifier set-backs for the first time in its history, before going on to lose a third in a row. That third defeat - a 1-0 loss to Argentina at the Maracan\u00e3 - was historic, too, marking the first time Brazil had ever lost a home World Cup qualifier.\n\nInterim coach Fernando Diniz was sacked in January, less than halfway through his one-year deal, and replaced by journeyman manager Dorival J\u00fanior, who has so far overseen narrow wins against England and Mexico and draws against the USA and Spain.\n\nBut despite the team's recent struggles, the pressure and expectation will still be high back home - in particular with Vin\u00edcius Jr. leading the attack.\n\nThe Real Madrid forward has enjoyed a sensational season for Los Blancos, helping the team to a La Liga and Champions League double and making himself the favorite to win the Ballon d'Or.\n\nUruguay\n\nPerennial overachiever Uruguay once again goes into a Copa Am\u00e9rica among the favorites to win the title.\n\nThe nation of just 3.5 million people holds the joint record alongside Argentina for most Copa Am\u00e9rica titles won with 15.\n\nUnder new manager Marcelo Bielsa, who took charge in May 2023, a new, youthful Uruguay has made a tremendous start to World Cup qualifying, winning four of its six matches so far - including 2-0 wins over Brazil and Argentina - to sit second in the standings.\n\nWhile Bielsa has called up many inexperienced and uncapped players during his tenure so far to better implement his high intensity press, national team icon Luis Su\u00e1rez made the cut and will be supported by a talented cast that includes Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez, Ronald Ara\u00fajo and Federico Valverde.\n\nThe host\n\nThe USA enters the Copa Am\u00e9rica off the back of winning a third straight Nations League title, beating bitter rival Mexico 2-0 in the final less than two months ago.\n\nHowever, preparations for the tournament got off to the worst possible start with a 5-1 hammering at the hands of Colombia in Washington.\n\nAfter the defeat, goalkeeper Matt Turner said the team needed to \"bounce back in a big way,\" and a much-improved performance followed in a morale-boosting 1-1 draw against Brazil.\n\nDespite boasting several talented players, including Tim Weah, Christian Pulisic, Yunus Musah and Folarin Balogun, serious questions remain about whether the US men can consistently compete against teams outside of the weaker CONCACAF bubble.\n\nFortunately for the US, the group draw has been kind. First up is a weak Bolivia side which has endured an abysmal start to World Cup qualifying, losing five of its first six matches, before a clash against familiar CONCACAF opponent Panama.\n\nThe sternest test will come last against Uruguay, but Gregg Berhalter's side should have enough quality to at least advance to the knockout stages. Anything less could be a disaster as the team attempts to drum up support across the country ahead of a home World Cup.\n\nDark Horses\n\nChile\n\nOnly a couple of months ago, you will likely have been hard pressed to find a Chile fan optimistic enough to predict that the team would make it past the group stages.\n\nThe failure to qualify for back-to-back World Cups in 2018 and 2022 has been a bitter pill to swallow for everyone involved after the country's 'Golden Generation' won successive Copa Am\u00e9ricas in 2015 and 2016 and reached the final of the 2017 Confederations Cup.\n\nSince Juan Antonio Pizzi was sacked as manager after the team missed out on Russia 2018, three successive coaches failed to get a tune out of the team - then Ricardo Gareca was hired.\n\nGareca, who impressively took Peru to the 2018 World Cup and the final of the 2019 Copa Am\u00e9rica, has had an immediate impact on the team since taking over in January, leading La Roja to comprehensive 3-0 wins over Paraguay and Albania and pushing France close in a 3-2 defeat in Marseille.\n\nBig names such as Alexis S\u00e1nchez and Claudio Bravo remain in the squad, but there is no place for Arturo Vidal or Gary Medel.\n\nIt might be a bit much to say expectations are now high, but fans are finally excited about watching La Roja playing again.\n\nColombia\n\nColombia arrives in the US as arguably the most in-form team in the tournament, if not the world.\n\nLos Cafeteros are currently on a 23-game unbeaten run that includes wins in their last eight matches. With three wins and three draws so far in World Cup qualifying, the team has soared to third place in the standings to put the failure of reaching Qatar 2022 behind it.\n\nLiverpool's Luis D\u00edaz will be Colombia's main man at the Copa Am\u00e9rica, supported by well-known veterans such as James Rodriguez, David Ospina and Yerry Mina.\n\nThe main issue for Colombia is its brutal potential route to the final, during which it will likely have to face Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": Here are some Records held by Lionel Messi and possible records LM10 could achieve in the competition.\n\nPossible Records Lionel Messi in Upcoming Copa America 2024\n\nPlayer with Most Appearances at Copa America: Lionel Messi already holds the record for most Copa America matches for the Argentina National Football Team but in the tournament, he is level with Chilean goalkeeper Sergio Livingstone who also has 34 caps for his side in the competition. Messi could overtake the tally by making an appearance in a single match.\n\nAll-time Top Scorer in Copa America: Despite playing in six Copa America competitions before, Lionel Messi has scored 13 goals and stands seventh in the All-Time scorers' list in the tournament. The position of the top scorer is shared at 17 goals by a compatriot of his - Norberto M\u00e9ndez and a Brazilian Zizinho. The South American superstar is a goal away to claim the second position. The top position is far-fetched though as leader Cristiano Ronaldo has 130 international goals and is currently playing in the UEFA Euro 2024 tournament.\n\nMost International Goals Contributions: even though goal scoring record might be a 'long shot', goal contribution is where Lionel Messi excels. Cristiano Ronaldo (165) currently holds the record for the most international goal contributions with 130 goals scored and 35 assists. As the 2022 World Cup champions and defending Copa America winners, Lionel Messi and Argentina certainly appear poised to put on another top-tier performance. The odds-on favorites to hoist the Copa America trophy at +175, but the USMNT can't be counted out.\n\nSitting at No. 11 in the FIFA World Rankings, the United States Men's National Team enter Copa America determined to make a deep run. Spain is the only nation to have ever accomplished the feat: winning the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nCopa America, the oldest international soccer tournament in the world (1916), will be held in the United States for only the second time ever. The centenary of the tournament in 2016 was held in the United States. {"uri": "8187455371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:20:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:20:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:19:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.courant.com/2024/06/20/copa-america-2024-bigger-than-european-championship-lionel-messi-knows-it-is/", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 bigger than European Championship? Lionel Messi knows it is", "body": "LOS ANGELES -- Kylian Mbapp\u00e9 clearly ruffled some feathers last week when he suggested the European Championship was the world's most difficult international soccer competition.\n\n\"The Euros are complicated. For me, more complicated than a World Cup,\" the French national team captain said at a news conference before his team's first game.\n\nHold my beer, said former club teammate Lionel Messi, who led Argentina past France in an epic 2022 World Cup final, in which he and Mbapp\u00e9 -- who broke his nose in France's Euro-opening win over Austria on Monday -- combined for five of the game's six goals.\n\nSure the Euros, the quadrennial championship for FIFA's 55-member European confederation, is difficult. However, don't sleep on Copa Am\u00e9rica, the South American tournament expanded this year to include the U.S., Mexico and four other teams.\n\n\"Well, everybody prioritizes their tournament,\" Messi fired back in a TV interview ahead of the Copa Am\u00e9rica opener Thursday between Argentina and Canada. \"The Euros is very important and has the best teams, but he's leaving out three-time champion Argentina, five-time champion Brazil, two-time champion Uruguay.\n\n\"There are a lot of world champions left off to say that it's the most difficult tournament.\"\n\nNot just world champions. In top-ranked Argentina and No. 5 Brazil, the Copa Am\u00e9rica field also has two of the top five teams in the latest FIFA world rankings. Colombia, which is also in the 16-team field, hasn't lost in 23 games over more than two years, the longest unbeaten streak in international soccer.\n\nA third of the 24 teams in the top-heavy Euro field are ranked outside the top 32.\n\nWith that as an introduction, here are four things to watch when the 48th Copa Am\u00e9rica kicks off at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta:\n\nThe South American championship is being played in the U.S. for the second time in eight years and eight of the 14 venues, including Inglewood's SoFi Stadium, also will play host to games in the 2026 World Cup. That makes the tournament an important trial run.\n\n\"We will always look at every event as a test for the next things that's coming up,\" said Otto Benedict, senior vice president for facility and campus operations at SoFi Stadium. \"Copa will allow us to have an international fan base that's coming through the building, so we're going to understand how those guests come, how they perceive the building.\"\n\nSoFi, which will stage eight games in the World Cup, will host two Copa group-stage matches: Brazil's tournament opener with Costa Rica on June 24 and Mexico's second game, with Venezuela, on June 26.\n\nBenedict said the stadium's Matrix Turf surface will be covered with a carpet of natural grass, a procedure that will be repeated for the World Cup, but the retractable bleachers in the corners will remain in place, leaving the pitch slightly narrower than FIFA will require for the World Cup.\n\n\"We're still going to have opportunities to learn,\" Benedict said. \"All those things are data points that will be collected.\"\n\nThe seven other Copa stadiums staging World Cup matches will conduct similar trials.\n\nThe 2026 World Cup will be a defining moment for the U.S., and the Copa might give an indication how the national team will be defined.\n\nIs the U.S. one of the world's top soccer-playing nations, as U.S. Soccer would like you to believe, or is it a pretender, a team that struggles against top competition and is undeserving of being ranked 11th -- ahead of Colombia, Germany and Uruguay -- in the latest FIFA rankings?\n\nAs a World Cup host, the U.S. -- along with co-hosts Mexico and Canada -- will not have to go through qualifying for 2026, making Copa the most challenging tournament it will face in the next two years.\n\nThe roster coach Gregg Berhalter will take into the team's opener against Bolivia at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Saturday is collectively the best in USMNT history, with 23 of 26 players coming off major European clubs. Copa provides an important international stage on which to display those talents.\n\n\"It's a chance for us to show, before the World Cup, that we're a team to be feared,\" defender Chris Richards told reporters.\n\nNo U.S. manager who has coached more than seven games has a better winning percentage than Berhalter, but given the quality of the roster and the team's recent struggles -- the U.S. has won only two of its last six games -- he has come under fire. The protests grew louder after an especially poor showing in a 5-1 loss to Colombia earlier this month.\n\nThe Copa group stage, in which the U.S. will play Bolivia, Panama and Uruguay, offers a chance to flip that script. The three teams will present vastly different challenges, giving Berhalter a chance to show off his coaching chops with three different game plans.\n\nGetting out of group play is the bare minimum for the U.S., but matters will get a little tougher if it advances and probably will face either Colombia or Brazil in the quarterfinals.\n\nArgentina, the reigning World Cup champion and ranked No. 1 in the world, has lost only two of its last 57 games and has made the Copa Am\u00e9rica final a record 29 times, winning 15.\n\nAlthough the team led by the 36-year-old Messi has aged -- 11 players over 30 and the third-oldest roster in the tournament -- it appears to have a fairly comfortable path to a 30th final at Hard Rock Stadium in suburban Miami on July 14.\n\nWith Colombia and Brazil, Group D could be the toughest of the four four-team groups. Brazil, still without injured Neymar, needs to improve play after losing its last three games -- albeit to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina -- in CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying.\n\nEcuador, whose only losses in 14 games came to Argentina and Italy, could be a dark horse.", "source": {"uri": "courant.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hartfort Courant"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": He's also the author of \"Net Gains: Inside the Beautiful Game's Analytics Revolution.\"\n\nThe last time the United States hosted a Copa America in 2016, Brazil got knocked out in the group stages. The U.S. men's national team lost 4-0 to Argentina in the semifinals. And Argentina lost the final in penalties to Chile at MetLife Stadium, home of the New York Giants and Jets. It was Argentina's second loss to Chile in a Copa America final in as many years, and it led to Lionel Messi -- presumably distraught at being unable to live up to the legacies created by Eli Manning and Ryan Fitzpatrick on that same field -- retiring from international soccer immediately following the match.\n\nWhile Messi has spent his career expanding our collective imagination of what's possible on a soccer field and in a soccer career, I don't think anyone could've accurately predicted where we'd be eight years later. Messi is in Year 2 of playing for Inter Miami, a soccer team that didn't exist in 2016. He spent two barely memorable seasons playing for Paris Saint-Germain. Oh, and he unretired so he and Argentina could finally win the Copa America and World Cup in consecutive years in his mid-30s.\n\nElsewhere, Chile have since failed to qualify for the 2018 World Cup and the 2022 World Cup. The other semifinalists in 2016 missed one a piece: the U.S. failed to qualify for 2018, Colombia for 2022. Brazil didn't make it past the quarterfinals of either tournament, and just two players from their 2016 Copa team are still around in 2024 (Alisson and Marquinhos).\n\nMexico, meanwhile, continue to lose to the USMNT in the Nations League, a tournament that didn't exist eight years ago. And Canada are managed by Jesse Marsch -- a statement that would've been meaningless in 2016 but not so today because he's managed multiple clubs in the Champions League and the Premier League since the Copa America Centenario.\n\nThe Copa America is the kind of tournament that can change the course of soccer as we know it, and it really matters to the teams that participate. So, given all the twists and turns we've had since the last time a Copa America was played on U.S. soil, why not look at the state of the 2024 tournament and make some predictions for where this all might end up?\n\nIt's time to look into our stats-filled, analytics-powered crystal ball and predict how every single game of the 2024 Copa America plays out and who, ultimately, will be crowned the winner. {"uri": "2024-06-392836151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:38:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:38:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://amp.sportsmole.co.uk/football/argentina/copa-america/feature/lionel-messis-copa-america-record-goals-assists_546129.html", "title": "Lionel Messi's Copa America record: goals, assists, standout moments", "body": "Sports Mole takes a look at Lionel Messi's for Argentina at the Copa America, including goals, assists and standout moments.\n\nyou have updates\n\nArgentina star Lionel Messi will feature at a seventh Copa America when he represents his country at this summer's tournament in the USA.\n\nThe forward clinched his first international title at Copa America 2021, before he led La Albiceleste to World Cup glory in December 2022.\n\nAlthough he is set to turn 37, Messi still remains a key player for Lionel Scaloni's side and will be crucial to their hopes of winning a third consecutive major tournament.\n\nHere, Sports Mole takes a look at Messi's previous performances at the tournament, including his goal contributions and standout moments.\n\nCopa America 2007 - 2 goals, 1 assist\n\nThe little boy from Rosario made his Copa America debut in 2007 just a year after he made his first major tournament appearance at the 2006 World Cup.\n\nA 20-year-old Messi provided just an assist in the group stage, before he finally got on the scoresheet in Argentina's quarter-final demolition.\n\nMessi made an intelligent run inside to collect Rodrigo Riquelme's exquisite through ball and slot home his first-ever goal at the Copa America.\n\nHis finish in the quarter-final may have been regarded as a relatively simple one, but there was nothing ordinary about the sumptuous strike he produced in the last-four success against Mexico.\n\nWith Argentina a goal to the good, Messi picked up the ball on the right side of the box and opened up his body to conjure up an audacious lob that teased the outstretched Oswaldo Sanchez before nestling in the far corner.\n\nUnfortunately for Messi, his maiden Copa America ended in disappointment as Argentina slumped to a devastating 3-0 defeat to rivals Brazil in the final.\n\nCopa America 2011 - 0 goals, 3 assists\n\nAfter failing to trouble the scorers at the 2010 World Cup, Messi would have hoped to experience improved fortunes at the 2011 Copa America in Argentina.\n\nAs it proved, the attacker would endure another goalless tournament, although he did provide three assists in Argentina's four matches.\n\nHe also kept his composure to dispatch Argentina's first penalty in the quarter-final shootout against Uruguay, but Carlos Tevez failed to convert his spot-kick, ensuring La Albiceleste failed to reach the semi-finals for the first time since 1999.\n\nCopa America 2015 - 1 goal, 3 assists\n\nMessi participated in his second Copa America final in 2015 after helping Argentina progress through the group stage and oust Colombia and Paraguay in the knockout rounds.\n\nHe proved to be a thorn in Paraguay's side, scoring in the opening group game before providing three assists when the two nations met again in Argentina's 6-1 semi-final success.\n\nMessi scored his penalty in the quarter-final shootout against Colombia, and he repeated the feat in the final with Chile after the two countries had played out a goalless draw in Santiago.\n\nHowever, Gonzalo Higuain and Ever Banega were unable to follow Messi's lead as they fluffed their lines to hand Chile the trophy at their home tournament.\n\nCopa America 2016 - 4 goal, 4 assists\n\nJust a year later, Messi and Argentina experienced more penalty shootout heartbreak in another Copa America final against Chile.\n\nMessi sat out Argentina's opening group game with Chile due to a back problem, but he returned with a bang in their next fixture, netting his one and only hat-trick at a major tournament to fire his country to a 5-0 victory.\n\nThe Argentine magician then produced two phenomenal displays in the quarter-final and semi-final, registering a goal and two assists in both games against Venezuela and the USA.\n\nUnfortunately for Messi, those match-winning performances failed to translate into silverware as he and Lucas Biglia missed their penalties in the final shootout with Chile, leaving him to contemplate whether a major international honour would ever come his way.\n\nCopa America 2019 - 4 goals, 4 assists\n\nAfter having three years to reflect on the 2016 disappointment, Messi's return to the Copa America did not go according to plan as he mustered just one goal and one assist in the 2019 tournament.\n\nArgentina's hopes of winning the competition were quashed by a 2-0 semi-final defeat against Brazil, leaving Messi and his colleagues to fight over the third spot with Chile.\n\nMessi teed up Sergio Aguera for the opener in the third-place playoff, but his tournament ultimately ended with a rare red card after he was dismissed for his part in a confrontation with Gary Medel, who was also dismissed in a game that finished 2-1 in Argentina's favour.\n\nCopa America 2021 - 4 goals, 5 assists\n\nAs Messi entered another international tournament, there were certainly some doubts as to whether he would ever celebrate a title with Argentina after falling short in the 2014 World Cup final and three Copa America finals.\n\nHowever, all those years of anguish and frustration were finally laid to rest as Messi ended his long wait for international success in Brazil three years ago.\n\nMessi set out his stall with a goal and an assist in Argentina's opening two games, before he moved through the gears with a scintillating display in the final group game against Bolivia, setting up Papu Gomez for the opener before netting a brace to fire La Albiceleste to a 4-1 victory.\n\nThe former Barcelona star continued to lead from the front in the 3-0 quarter-final success over Ecuador, grabbing two assists and netting a trademark free-kick.\n\nMessi then registered an assist in the semi-final against Colombia, before he held his nerve to score in Argentina's penalty shootout success, setting up a mouthwatering final against bitter rivals Brazil.\n\nIt was perhaps fitting that 14 years after losing to Brazil in his first major international tournament final, the attacker finally got over the line against the same opponent thanks to Angel Di Maria's at the Maracana, generating the iconic scene of Messi's teammates running towards him as soon as the final whistle blew.\n\nIf there was one drawback to the 2021 triumph it was that the tournament was played behind closed doors due to COVID, so Messi may have that extra motivation to win the Copa America in front of his adoring faithful when he leads Argentina in the 2024 compettion.\n\nbody check tags ::", "source": {"uri": "amp.sportsmole.co.uk", {"uri": "8182295959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "17:38:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T17:38:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T17:21:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13539397/Lionel-Messi-Argentina-try-3rd-straight-major-title-Copa-America.html", "title": "Lionel Messi and Argentina will try for a 3rd straight major title...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain\u00b4s feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.\n\nComing off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\n\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nHe has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina\u00b4s national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal\u00b4s Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nFILE - Argentina's Lionel Messi celebrates with the trophy after beating Brazil 1-0 in the Copa America final soccer match at Maracana stadium in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Saturday, July 10, 2021. Messi and Argentina will try to win their third straight major title when they defend their Copa America championship while Brazil hopes 17-year-old Endrick will combine with Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo for success. (AP Photo/Bruna Prado, File)\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it\u00b4s probably one of the world\u00b4s best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nA look at the tournament:\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer\u00b4s governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.\n\nCONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup - the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada - and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.\n\nChristian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\n\n\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we\u00b4ll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It\u00b4s a special time for this sport in America.\"\n\nIn 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.\n\nAt MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\n\n\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... Not only can we track the drone, but more importantly, we can track where the operator is.\"\n\nAP sports: https://apnews.com/sports\n\nFILE - Teammates toss Argentina's Lionel Messi in the air after beating Brazil 1-0 in the Copa America final soccer match at the Maracana stadium in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, July 10, 2021. Messi and Argentina will try to win their third straight major title when they defend their Copa America championship while Brazil hopes 17-year-old Endrick will combine with Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo for success. (AP Photo/Bruna Prado, File)\n\nFILE - Brazil's Endrick, right, celebrates with Rodrygo after scoring his side's second goal during a friendly soccer match between Spain and Brazil at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid, Spain, Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Messi and Argentina will try to win their third straight major title when they defend their Copa America championship while Brazil hopes 17-year-old Endrick will combine with Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo for success. {"uri": "8184504569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "01:51:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T01:51:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:49:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "http://www.china.org.cn/sports/2024-06/19/content_117262064.htm", "title": "Copa America preview: Eight things to look out for", "body": "The Copa America will kick off on Thursday when defending champions Argentina meet Canada at the Mercedes-Benz stadium in Atlanta, Georgia.\n\nThis year's tournament, to be played in 14 cities across the United States, will feature the 10 South American nations, plus six from the Confederation of North America, Central America and the Caribbean (CONCACAF).\n\nHere are eight things to look out for in the 48th edition of the world's oldest continental football competition.\n\n1. Can Argentina be champions again?\n\nHow times have changed for Argentina. Three years ago, the country's press and fans were openly wondering if the Albiceleste would ever win another major trophy as their title drought approached three decades. That changed when Lionel Scaloni's men beat Brazil in the final of the 2021 Copa America at Rio de Janeiro's Maracana stadium.\n\nLess than 18 months later, they went one better by lifting the World Cup trophy for the first time since 1986 with a penalty shootout victory over France in Qatar.\n\nLionel Messi (C) of Argentina competes during the 2026 FIFA World Cup South American qualification match against Uruguay in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Nov. 16, 2023. (Photo by Martin Sabala/Xinhua)\n\nBut can the South American giants make it three major trophies in a row?\n\nRecent results would suggest so. The Albiceleste have been in ominous form of late, having scored three goals or more in three of their past four matches, including a 4-1 rout of Guatemala in their final Copa America warmup fixture last Friday (June 14).\n\nAnother triumph in the United States would make Scaloni's side the first team to successfully defend the Copa America while simultaneously holding the World Cup trophy.\n\n2. Is this really the United States' Golden Generation?\n\nManager Gregg Berhalter has what is arguably the strongest playing list ever assembled by the United States for a major football tournament.\n\nEighteen of the 26 players named in Berhalter's squad ply their trade in one of Europe's top leagues (England, Spain, Italy, France, Germany and the Netherlands).\n\nThe midfield looks particularly dangerous, marshaled by Juventus star Weston McKennie, AC Milan's Yunus Musah and Nottingham Forest playmaker Giovanni Reyna.\n\nThe attack will be led by Christian Pulisic, who says he is in career-best form after a superb season at AC Milan.\n\n3. Brazil's new Golden Boy\n\nEndrick this month became the youngest player since Pele to score in three consecutive matches for Brazil. But the 17-year-old is no certainty to start for the Selecao at the Copa America.\n\nHead coach Dorival Junior has promised not to ask too much of Endrick during the Copa America as the attacker vies for a place in the starting lineup alongside Vinicius Junior, Rodrygo, Raphinha, Savinho and Gabriel Martinelli.\n\n\"I have always been in favor of giving chances to young players but I just ask for a little patience with the boy so that things can happen naturally,\" Dorival told reporters earlier this month.\n\n4: Uruguay: The Bielsa effect\n\nUpon his appointment as Uruguay's manager in May last year, Marcelo Bielsa said his role would involve daring the Celeste's players to dream. The team's impressive sequence of results under the Argentine would suggest he is succeeding.\n\nThe Celeste have won seven, drawn three and lost two matches under Bielsa's stewardship, a run that has included World Cup qualifying victories over Brazil and Argentina.\n\nBielsa's 26-man Copa America list includes a balanced mix of youth and experience while boasting an array of world-class talent such as Real Madrid midfielder Federico Valverde, Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo, Atletico Madrid defender Jose Gimenez and Liverpool forward Darwin Nunez.\n\nVeteran marksman Luis Suarez will likely be an option off the bench, despite his prolific recent scoring form for Inter Miami. Suarez's long-time national team strike partner Edinson Cavani is not a part of the Celeste squad after announcing his retirement from international football in May.\n\n5. Colombia's formidable form\n\nColombia will deservedly enter the Copa America as one of the tournament favorites. The Cafeteros are unbeaten in 20 matches since Argentine Nestor Lorenzo replaced Reinaldo Rueda as manager in June 2022.\n\nThe sequence has included victories over Germany, Spain, Brazil, Mexico and the United States over the past year.\n\nColombia's strength is a stable defense - led by the center-back pairing of Jhon Lucumi and Carlos Cuesta - and an attack spearheaded by Liverpool winger Luis Diaz.\n\nPerhaps one weak spot is the middle of the park. James Rodriguez and Jhon Arias are the central pieces of a midfield that could lack depth, particularly if injuries strike.\n\n6. Gareca's Copa America record\n\nChile boss Ricardo Gareca, has a Midas touch in the Copa America, having guided Peru to second and third places in the previous two editions.\n\nThe 66-year-old Argentine, who was appointed Chile manager in January, has shown that he is not afraid to make tough decisions as he oversees a generational overhaul of La Roja's squad.\n\nAmong those missing from Chile's current playing group are Arturo Vidal and Gary Medel, integral members of the side that won back-to-back Copa America titles in 2015 and 2016.\n\nOne veteran who has remained in Gareca's plans is Eduardo Vargas, who was the Copa America's leading scorer in both 2015 and 2016, with four and six goals, respectively.\n\nThe 34-year-old Atletico Mineiro forward has 14 Copa America goals, three shy of the record that is jointly held by Argentine midfielder Norberto Mendez and Brazil playmaker Zizinho.\n\n7. The last dance?\n\nWhile Lionel Messi has not yet entertained the idea of retirement - at least publicly - this will almost certainly be his last Copa America.\n\nArgentina's talismanic captain will turn 37 during the tournament's group stage and he will be 41 when the next edition comes around.\n\nOne player who has already made a decision about his future is Messi's long-time national teammate and close friend, Angel Di Maria.\n\nThe 36-year-old has confirmed that he will end his 16-year international career after the Copa America.\n\nThe Benfica winger has been capped 140 times for his country and, with one World Cup trophy and a Copa America triumph to his name, he is already guaranteed legend status for the Albiceleste. Who would deny him one last shot at glory?\n\n8. Venezuela's high hopes\n\nVenezuela have never progressed beyond the quarterfinals of the continental tournament, having reached the last eight in 2011 and 2016.\n\nBut the Vinotinto have good reason to believe this could be their best ever Copa America campaign.\n\nSince Fernando Batista replaced Jose Pekerman as head coach in March 2023, Venezuela have played 12 matches, winning five, drawing five and losing just two.\n\nThe encouraging run of results has included victories over Chile and Paraguay and a draw against Brazil in 2026 World Cup qualifiers.", "source": {"uri": "china.org.cn", They have been spotless, winning four games by a combined score of 11-2. Canada's form hasn't been as good, with a 1-1-1 record in 2024, including a loss and a tie in June. Canada didn't take it easy going into the tournament, taking on Netherlands and France in those two friendly matches. It is time to continue our Copa America odds series with an Argentina-Canada prediction, pick, and how-to-watch.\n\nArgentina has been the best country in international soccer since losing to Saudi Arabia in the 2022 World Cup. After losing the opening game of that tournament, Argentina won six consecutive games, finishing the journey with a penalty kick victory over France in the final. The Argentinians sent Lionel Messi into World Cup retirement with his first-ever title, as one of soccer's greatest players said the Qatar World Cup would be his last. However, he isn't ready to call it quits yet, as he will be playing in the Copa America, which is likely his final significant international competition.\n\nCanada has lost some steam after their dramatic qualification for the 2022 World Cup. The tournament didn't go as planned for Canada, and they've lost big games in the Concacaf Gold Cup and Concacaf Nations League since their elimination in Qatar. Canada won't have to go through the dramatics of qualifying for the 2026 World Cup, as they're co-hosting the tournament with the United States and Mexico. The Copa America will be a good chance for the Canadian team to get back on track.\n\nArgentina's reasons to win are clear. They lost one match in their last 20, a qualifying game against Uruguay. Argentina has run over teams that are better than Canada on this path, and they could be highly motivated to win the Copa America. If this is Messi's last tournament they'll want to send him off on a winning note, and they could become just the second nation ever to win three consecutive major titles after winning the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nWhy Canada Will Win\n\nCanada has some crucial players in their squad, including Alphonso Davies, one of the best full-backs in the world, and Jonathan David, one of the top goal-scorers in Ligue 1. The Canadians used these players and other unsung heroes to qualify for the 2022 World Cup. However, once they got to the big stage, they realized the difficulties of playing some of the better teams in the world for an entire tournament.\n\nCanada will be prepared better in Copa America, but this opening-round matchup with Argentina is a difficult draw. Canada could make some noise against Peru and Chile and advance to the knockout stage, but they'll need heroic performances to get past Argentina. Their most significant reason to believe is Argentina's propensity to start the bigger tournaments on the wrong foot, as we saw in the 2022 World Cup against Saudi Arabia.\n\nFinal Argentina-Canada Prediction & Pick\n\nArgentina's odds are astronomical to win this game since most expect them to dominate the group stage. Their odds of -350 are too juiced for a team that lost their World Cup opener to Saudi Arabia. The better value in this matchup is on the over, as Argentina could cover this number themselves, but Canada can also contribute a goal or two. Jonathan David and Alphonso Davies are more than capable of combining on a goal against the Argentinians.\n\nClick here for more betting news & predictions", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com",
