{"uri": "8184442389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "00:30:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T00:30:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T00:27:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.batimes.com.ar/news/sports/messi-takes-centre-stage-again-for-copa-america.phtml", "title": "Messi takes centre stage again for Copa Am\u00e9rica", "body": "Argentina have won the Copa Am\u00e9rica 15 times but only once, in 2021, during the Lionel Messi era. The Albiceleste get the tournament underway on Thursday.\n\nWorld champions Argentina get an expanded Copa Am\u00e9rica under way on Thursday with Lionel Messi looking to add a second continental title in what is almost certainly his final appearance in the tournament.\n\nThe 108-year-old competition is being held in the United States with the host nation among six teams from the CONCACAF region joining the 10 South American nations looking for a place in the July 14 final in Miami.\n\nWhile FIFA will be looking closely at the organisation of the event, two years out from the World Cup which will be co-hosted by the USA, Canada and Mexico, the tournament's rich history and prestige means it is much, much more than a 'trial event.'\n\nArgentina have won the Copa Am\u00e9rica 15 times but only once, in 2021, during the Messi era and coach Lionel Scaloni has stuck largely with his World Cup-winning squad, with veterans \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda and Nicol\u00e1s Otamendi likely taking their final bow in a major tournament.\n\nWhether this is Messi's goodbye to elite international football remains to be seen - the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner, now playing in Major League Soccer with Inter Miami, will turn 37 four days after Thursday's opener in Atlanta against Canada and has yet to decide whether he will try to play in a record sixth World Cup.\n\n\"It's great to have records and continue to achieve things but I won't take part in a World Cup just to say I've done six,\" Messi told ESPN last week.\n\n\"If I feel good and everything is in place for me to be there, fine, but I won't go just to go. It's very difficult to imagine what can happen because it's still two years away. I don't need to commit right now to whether or not I'll be there,\" he added.\n\nWhat is certain is that Messi, who has managed his workload to try to be in peak condition for the tournament, would relish the chance to win a third straight major tournament with his country after so many years of frustration with his national team.\n\nAfter facing Canada, Argentina take on Chile in New Jersey before finishing their group A action against Peru in Miami but they know that tough opposition awaits in the knock-out stage with rivals Brazil and Uruguay the two expected challengers for the title.\n\nBrazil have struggled in CONMEBOL qualifiers for the 2026 World Cup having won just two of their opening six games and they currently sit in sixth place in the standings having lost to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina.\n\nThere are several familiar names missing from Dorival Junior's Brazil squad with Casemiro, Gabriel Jesus and Thiago Silva left out while Richarlison and Neymar are both missing due to injury.\n\nThe pressure will be on the Real Madrid attacking pair of Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo to translate their club form into success for the Sele\u00e7ao while there is much excitement around the senior tournament debut of 17-year-old talent Endrick, who is set to join Real next month from Palmeiras.\n\nUruguay, also 15-times winners, have impressed under their 68-year-old Argentina coach Marcelo Bielsa, who has brought his trademark high-energy style to the team and raised expectations with recent wins over Argentina and Brazil.\n\nLiverpool forward Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez will lead the line although Bielsa has the option of introducing veteran Luis Su\u00e1rez from the bench.\n\nColombia head into the tournament without a loss in over two years and with Liverpool's livewire winger Luis D\u00edaz a constant threat and James Rodr\u00edguez enjoying a late career revival, Nestor Lorenzo's team can't be discounted.\n\nThe USA will hope that they can generate some sorely needed excitement after losing their way since a creditable run to the last-16 at the World Cup.\n\nCoach Gregg Berhalter is under some pressure to show he can get his team, which relies on the smart wing play of Christian Pulisic, to compete with teams from outside of CONCACAF.\n\nMexico have guested frequently in the Copa in the past and reached the final in 1993 and 2001, but they look well below their usual level although they can, as always, count on huge support in the USA.\n\nThis is the second time the Copa Am\u00e9rica is being held in the USA, after the centenary tournament in 2016, and while that is a break with tradition the presence of significant immigrant communities from all the competing nations, should ensure big crowds at the mostly NFL {"uri": "8184961899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:49:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:49:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:48:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://bobrtimes.com/copa-america-messis-argentina-faces-vinicius-juniors-brazil-who-will-lift-the-cup-on-july-15-in-the-united-states/", "title": "Copa America: Messi's Argentina faces Vinicius Junior's Brazil, who will lift the cup on July 15 in the United States ? - The Bobr Times", "body": "Lionel Messi, the Argentinian legend, in search of a new title. MAXPPP - Le Parisien/Arnaud Journois\n\nThe 48th Copa America is being played in the United States against a backdrop of rivalry between Argentina and Brazil.\n\nThe reigning Argentine world champions, led by their totem Lionel Messi, and Vinicius Jr's Brazil, in great shape, are dreaming of the 48th Copa America, played in the United States, from Thursday until the 14th. ;July. The tournament launches a series of three major competitions in the land of \"soccer\", before the new version of the FIFA Club World Cup in 2025 and then the 48-country Gigantism World Cup co-organized with Mexico and Canada in 2026.\n\nLionel Messi has not ruled out still being present in 2026, but for the moment he is eyeing the Copa America, which he finally won with the ;rsquo;Argentina in 2021. In an experienced group which includes 22 world champions, Messi obviously finds Angel di Maria or even Lautaro Martinez.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or, who will celebrate its 37th anniversary on June 24, will open the competition against Canada on Thursday in Atlanta before a shock in the first round on June 25 against Chile, reminder of the two finals lost by the Albiceleste in 2015 and 2016. Messi is even more the face of this Copa since he has been playing at Inter Miami since July 2023.\n\nThe city with a Latino accent (the community most focused on \"soccer\" in the USA) is establishing itself as the new stronghold of American football, where the final will take place of the tournament and where Fifa has set up offices. Freed from the rhythm and harshness of European football, Messi offers himself the luxury of arriving fresher at the Copa, little marked by the senatorial train of the MLS championship, where he continues to pile up the goals (12 after 19 days) without being criticized for his lack of races.\n\nWith his dragster acceleration, Vinicius Junior has brought European football into line, recently winning a second Champions League with Real Madrid, and establishing himself as leader of Brazil, another giant of the world. South America, in the absence of Neymar, operated in November for a rupture of the cruciate ligaments and meniscus of the left knee.\n\n\"I haven't won a national team title yet, I hope to do so now. We prepared well. This generation is strong and we want to do great things with the Sele\u00e7ao\", said Vinicius, who will celebrate his 24th birthday on July 12.\n\nHe will play in the Sele\u00e7ao with his Real teammates Rodrygo (attacker) and Eder Militao (defender), and will be able to cover his future Madrid teammate Endrick, the new star of Auriverde football who is playing at 17 years old his first big tournament.\n\nJoint record holder for the number of victories in the competition with Argentina (15), Uruguay advances with Darwin Nunez and the eternal Luis Suarez, Messi's teammate in Miami, but without Edinson Cavani, who announced his international retirement at the end of May. Argentina's Marcelo Bielsa will sit on the bench (or the icebox) of the Celeste, in search of a first personal Copa after his failures with Argentina.\n\nAs in 2016, for the centenary Copa, the competition will take place in the United States with a format expanded to 16 teams, the ten usual South American competitors of Conmebol being joined by six members of Concacaf (North, Central America and the Caribbean).\n\nThe Copa and its 32 matches are like an aperitif before the World Cup 2026 and its 104 matches, including 78 in the United States. Eight stadiums are part of the system for the two competitions, including the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami and the MetLife Stadium in New York, future home of the World Cup final.\n\nThe American host, with a team in full doubt, lacks a priori arguments to compete with the great South American nations, despite the draw snatched against Brazil (1-1) last week in a preparation match.", "source": {"uri": "8185103067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:20:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:20:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:19:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/copa-am-rica-2024-bigger-100014469.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 bigger than European Championship? Lionel Messi knows it is", "body": "Kylian Mbappe clearly ruffled some feathers last week when he suggested the European Championship was the world's most difficult international soccer competition.\n\n\"The Euros are complicated. For me, more complicated than a World Cup,\" the French national team captain said at a news conference before his team's first game.\n\nHold my beer, said former club teammate Lionel Messi, who led Argentina past France in an epic 2022 World Cup final, in which he and Mbappe -- who broke his nose in France's Euro-opening win over Austria on Monday -- combined for five of the game's six goals.\n\nSure the Euros, the quadrennial championship for FIFA's 55-member European confederation, is difficult. However, don't sleep on Copa Am\u00e9rica, the South American tournament expanded this year to include the U.S., Mexico and four other teams.\n\nRead more: How an amputee soccer team is helping Ukrainian soldiers overcome the trauma of war\n\n\"Well, everybody prioritizes their tournament,\" Messi fired back in a TV interview ahead of the Copa Am\u00e9rica opener Thursday between Argentina and Canada. \"The Euros is very important and has the best teams, but he's leaving out three-time champion Argentina, five-time champion Brazil, two-time champion Uruguay.\n\n\"There are a lot of world champions left off to say that it's the most difficult tournament.\"\n\nNot just world champions. In top-ranked Argentina and No. 5 Brazil, the Copa Am\u00e9rica field also has two of the top five teams in the latest FIFA world rankings. Colombia, which is also in the 16-team field, hasn't lost in 23 games over more than two years, the longest unbeaten streak in international soccer.\n\nA third of the 24 teams in the top-heavy Euro field are ranked outside the top 32.\n\nWith that as an introduction, here are four things to watch when the 48th Copa Am\u00e9rica kicks off at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta:\n\nThe South American championship is being played in the U.S. for the second time in eight years and eight of the 14 venues, including Inglewood's SoFi Stadium, also will play host to games in the 2026 World Cup. That makes the tournament an important trial run.\n\n\"We will always look at every event as a test for the next things that's coming up,\" said Otto Benedict, senior vice president for facility and campus operations at SoFi Stadium. \"Copa will allow us to have an international fan base that's coming through the building, so we're going to understand how those guests come, how they perceive the building.\"\n\nRead more: Emma Hayes won't let her USWNT coaching dream turn into a nightmare\n\nSoFi, which will stage eight games in the World Cup, will host two Copa group-stage matches: Brazil's tournament opener with Costa Rica on June 24 and Mexico's second game, with Venezuela, on June 26.\n\nBenedict said the stadium's Matrix Turf surface will be covered with a carpet of natural grass, a procedure that will be repeated for the World Cup, but the retractable bleachers in the corners will remain in place, leaving the pitch slightly narrower than FIFA will require for the World Cup.\n\n\"We're still going to have opportunities to learn,\" Benedict said. \"All those things are data points that will be collected.\"\n\nThe seven other Copa stadiums staging World Cup matches will conduct similar trials.\n\nThe 2026 World Cup will be a defining moment for the U.S., and the Copa might give an indication how the national team will be defined.\n\nIs the U.S. one of the world's top soccer-playing nations, as U.S. Soccer would like you to believe, or is it a pretender, a team that struggles against top competition and is undeserving of being ranked 11th -- ahead of Colombia, Germany and Uruguay -- in the latest FIFA rankings?\n\nAs a World Cup host, the U.S. -- along with co-hosts Mexico and Canada -- will not have to go through qualifying for 2026, making Copa the most challenging tournament it will face in the next two years.\n\nThe roster coach Gregg Berhalter will take into the team's opener against Bolivia at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Saturday is collectively the best in USMNT history, with 23 of 26 players coming off major European clubs. Copa provides an important international stage on which to display those talents.\n\n\"It's a chance for us to show, before the World Cup, that we're a team to be feared,\" defender Chris Richards told reporters.\n\nNo U.S. manager who has coached more than seven games has a better winning percentage than Berhalter, but given the quality of the roster and the team's recent struggles -- the U.S. has won only two of its last six games -- he has come under fire. The protests grew louder after an especially poor showing in a 5-1 loss to Colombia earlier this month.\n\nThe Copa group stage, in which the U.S. will play Bolivia, Panama and Uruguay, offers a chance to flip that script. The three teams will present vastly different challenges, giving Berhalter a chance to show off his coaching chops with three different game plans.\n\nGetting out of group play is the bare minimum for the U.S., but matters will get a little tougher if it advances and probably will face either Colombia or Brazil in the quarterfinals.\n\nArgentina, the reigning World Cup champion and ranked No. 1 in the world, has lost only two of its last 57 games and has made the Copa Am\u00e9rica final a record 29 times, winning 15.\n\nAlthough the team led by the 36-year-old Messi has aged -- 11 players over 30 and the third-oldest roster in the tournament -- it appears to have a fairly comfortable path to a 30th final at Hard Rock Stadium in suburban Miami on July 14.\n\nWith Colombia and Brazil, Group D could be the toughest of the four four-team groups. Brazil, still without injured Neymar, needs to improve play after losing its last three games -- albeit to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina -- in CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying.", "source": {"uri": Start time and how to watch pre-game show before Argentina vs. Canada", "body": "All roads lead to the Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia, this Thursday, with the Copa America 2024 opening ceremony set to kick off the continent's premier national footballing extravaganza ahead of the tournament opener between holders Argentina and Canada at the same venue.\n\nThe 48th edition of the competition -- jointly organized by the South American Football Confederation (CONMEBOL) and the North, Central American and Caribbean Football Confederation (CONCACAF) for only the second time in its history -- will feature 16 teams, including the regular 10 from CONMEBOL and six representatives from CONCACAF, such as host nation United States.\n\nThe opening ceremony will be staged shortly before Lionel Messi and company take to the field to kick off the tournament that will run through to the final on July 14.\n\nThe Sporting News has the key details ahead of the event, including how to watch it across the world and the start time in Atlanta and other major territories.\n\nMORE: Copa America 2024 schedule and results, updated LIVE | Who will win Copa America 2024? Latest odds and predictions | FIFA Rankings for all Copa America 2024 teams\n\nBroadcasters from across the world will be showing the best action from Copa America 2024, including the opening ceremony, which will take place around an hour before kickoff on June 20 in the opening match between hosts Argentina and Canada.\n\nUSA: Copa America 2024 matches will be broadcast in English on Fox Sports Network with streaming options available on Fubo where new users can sign up to a FREE trial.\n\nIn addition to the English-language coverage on Fox Sports, Univision has the rights to broadcast Copa America in Spanish language on Univision, the sports-only channel TUDN, as well as the other sister channels owned by TelevisaUnivision (UniMas). Spanish-language streaming will also be available on ViX.\n\nCanada: TSN and TSN+ is the place to go for Copa America 2024 action in Canada. CTV and RDS are also showing Canada's opener.\n\nAustralia: Fans in Australia can follow all the Copa America 2024 action live and on demand on Optus Sport.\n\nUK: Matches at Copa America 2024 will be available on Premier Sports 1 in the UK, with live streaming service offered on Premier Sports Player.\n\nIndia: Copa America 2024 matches will be available on FanCode in India.\n\nIf Copa America 2024 is not available to watch live in your location or if you're traveling abroad, you can use a Virtual Private Network (VPN). VPNs offer a secure and private online connection, allowing you to bypass geographical restrictions to access your favorite streaming services from any device anywhere in the world.\n\nWATCH FROM ANYWHERE: Sign up for NordVPN (30-day moneyback guarantee)\n\nThe tournament kicks off with the opening game, which will see reigning world champions Argentina taking on Canada, at 8 p.m. ET on Thursday, June 20, 2024. The opening ceremony will take place prior to the match.\n\nMercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia, the renowned home of the NFL's Falcons and MLS' Atlanta United, will host the event and the opening game.\n\nWith a seating capacity of 71,000 (expandable to 75,000), the stadium has hosted prestigious American sporting events such as Super Bowl LIII and the College Football Playoff National Championship in 2018. The stadium is well known for its unique retractable roof system.\n\nTwo days before the opening ceremony, CONMEBOL announced that multi-Grammy-award-winning artist Feid would be the first performer at the event.\n\nThe Colombian, who has received rave reviews for his Ferxxoapocalipsis Tour of the U.S. and Canada this year, was teased as the star act of the show when CONMBEOL posted an image of social media of a soccer ball and a pair of glasses adorned with double crosses -- a signature look of the Reggaeton performer.\n\nHowever, Feid won't be the only star lighting up the stage. Rumours persist that Shakira is also performing at the ceremony given that her song \"Punteria\" is the official anthem of the Copa America. Nothing has yet been confirmed, though.\n\nMORE: Full list of teams playing at Copa America 2024\n\nThe opening ceremony is expected to start either an hour or 30 minutes before kickoff of the opening {"uri": "8185510120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:48:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:48:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:47:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/soccer/news/copa-america-2024-opening-ceremony-performers-time-date-tv-stream/d035262c691f74a17a1c97dd", "title": "Copa America 2024 opening ceremony: Time, date, performers, event details and where to watch pre-game show on TV, live stream", "body": "We are on the brink of the 48th edition of the Copa America, the premier national football tournament involving teams from North and South America, and the 2024 finals mark an historic occasion.\n\nThis is because it's been jointly organized by the South American Football Confederation (CONMEBOL) and the North, Central American and Caribbean Football Confederation (CONCACAF) for only the second time in its history.\n\nAll 10 CONMEBOL members will feature in the tournament, with six teams from the CONCACAF region, making it a 16-team competition.\n\nGrand opening ceremonies, with cultural programmes and performances from prominent singers and artists, have been a prominent feature of Copa America tournaments from the past and much of the same is expected of this year's event in the United States.\n\nThe Sporting News has the key details ahead of the ceremony, including how to watch it across the world and the start time in Atlanta and where you are.\n\nMORE: Copa America 2024 schedule and results, updated LIVE | Who will win Copa America 2024? Latest odds and predictions | FIFA Rankings for all Copa America 2024 teams\n\nThe tournament kicks off with the opening game, which will see reigning world champions Argentina taking on Canada, at 8 p.m. ET on Thursday, June 20, 2024. The opening ceremony will take place prior to the match.\n\nMercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia, the renowned home of the NFL's Falcons and MLS' Atlanta United, will host the event and the opening game.\n\nWith a seating capacity of 71,000 (expandable to 75,000), the stadium has hosted prestigious American sporting events such as Super Bowl LIII and the College Football Playoff National Championship in 2018. The stadium is well known for its unique retractable roof system.\n\nExcitement is building for the Copa America 2024 opening ceremony on June 20. Two days earlier, CONMEBOL announced that multi-Grammy-award-winning artist Feid would be the opening performer at the event.\n\nThe Colombian, who has received rave reviews for his Ferxxoapocalipsis Tour of the U.S. and Canada this year, was teased as the star act of the show when CONMBEOL posted an image of social media of a soccer ball and a pair of glasses adorned with double crosses -- a signature look of the Reggaeton performer.\n\nHowever, Feid won't be the only star lighting up the stage. Rumours persist that Shakira is also performing at the ceremony.\n\nGiven that her song \"Punteria\" is the official anthem of the Copa America, it's likely she will deliver a live performance of the hit.\n\nMORE: Full list of teams playing at Copa America 2024\n\nIt's expected that the opening ceremony will begin around one hour or 30 minutes before kickoff of the opening match between Argentina and Canada on June 20, which would mean a start time of 7 p.m. or 7:30 p.m. local time (ET).\n\nHere's how that translates around the world:\n\nBroadcasters from across the world will be showing the best action from Copa America 2024, including the opening ceremony, which will take place around an hour before kickoff on June 20 in the opening match between hosts Argentina and Canada.\n\nBelow are the key details on how to watch and stream the opening match in some of the major global territories:\n\nUSA: Copa America 2024 matches will be broadcast in English on Fox Sports Network with streaming options available on Fubo where new users can sign up to a FREE trial.\n\nIn addition to the English-language coverage on Fox Sports, Univision has the rights to broadcast Copa America in Spanish language on Univision, the sports-only channel TUDN, as well as the other sister channels owned by TelevisaUnivision (UniMas). Spanish-language streaming will also be available on ViX.\n\nCanada: TSN and TSN+ is the place to go for Copa America 2024 action in Canada. CTV and RDS are also showing Canada's opener.\n\nAustralia: Fans in Australia can follow all the Copa America 2024 action live and on demand on Optus Sport.\n\nUK: Matches at Copa America 2024 will be available on Premier Sports 1 in the UK, with live streaming service offered on Premier Sports Player.\n\nIndia: Copa America 2024 matches will be available on FanCode in India.\n\nIf Copa America 2024 is not available to watch live in your location or if you're traveling abroad, you can use a Virtual Private Network (VPN). VPNs offer a secure and private online connection, allowing you to bypass geographical restrictions to access your favorite streaming services from any device anywhere in the world.\n\nWATCH FROM {"uri": "2024-06-395846639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:49:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:49:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://kion546.com/sports/cnn-sports/2024/06/20/copa-america-2024-lionel-messis-final-last-dance-with-argentina/", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024: Lionel Messi's final 'Last Dance' with Argentina? - KION546", "body": "(CNN) -- For just the second time in the tournament's 108-year history, the Copa Am\u00e9rica will be played outside of South America.\n\nAs it did in 2016 for the special centenary, the United States will host this year's expanded edition that will feature 16 teams rather than the customary 12 and will be something of a dress rehearsal for the 2026 World Cup, which will be hosted in the US, Mexico and Canada.\n\nTaking part will be the 10 CONMEBOL nations as usual, plus the US, Mexico, Jamaica and Panama, which all qualified as semifinalists of the CONCACAF Nations League.\n\nAdditionally, Costa Rica and Canada also qualified via the playoffs contested between the losing Nations League quarterfinalists.\n\nUnsurprisingly, Lionel Messi's Argentina is the favorite to lift the trophy for a record-breaking 16th time.\n\nThree years ago, Messi helped the Albiceleste to glory at the Covid-delayed 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica, beating host Brazil in the final, his first major trophy with the national team and the country's first in 28 years.\n\nThat victory lifted the weight of expectation off his shoulders and more than likely acted as a catalyst for Argentina's World Cup victory in Qatar 18 months later, with Messi finally getting his hands on the one trophy he had craved most.\n\nPreviously tormented by his failures with Argentina, even retiring temporarily from international football after a second straight Copa Am\u00e9rica final defeat to Chile in 2016, Messi told Argentine outlet Infobae recently that he's now \"achieved everything.\"\n\nThere is the real possibility that the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica will be the last major international tournament Messi plays. After previously stating that the 2022 World Cup would be his last, Messi told Star+ in December that \"time will tell.\"\n\n\"As long as I feel I am well and that I am able to help, I will do it,\" Messi, who will turn 37 during the Copa Am\u00e9rica, said. \"Today, all I think about is to get well to the Copa Am\u00e9rica and play it. Fight for it again, as we always do, try to be the champions.\n\n\"If we do well at Copa Am\u00e9rica and I can keep playing, maybe it happens.\"\n\nBut Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni, who has overseen just four defeats in the team's last 50 games, had a message for Messi fans: Don't worry about the future, just enjoy the now.\n\n\"We Argentines are too melancholic and we are already thinking about the day when he is gone while he's still playing,\" Scaloni said last week. \"So let's enjoy him and we'll see what happens tomorrow. I think the present is so important for the whole world - not only for Argentina - because, in the end, Leo plays for everyone who likes football.\"\n\nOne player who will definitely be making his last tournament appearance for Argentina is \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda.\n\nThe 36-year-old has made 140 appearances for the national team and enjoys legendary status back home thanks to his winner in the final of the 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica and a goal in the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nDi Mar\u00eda also won the U20 World Cup in 2007 and an Olympic gold medal at Beijing 2008.\n\nPreviously thought of as one of, if not the greatest football nation on earth, Brazil currently finds itself navigating a complicated transitional period.\n\nThe squad for the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica is largely inexperienced, with 15 players on less than 10 caps for their country. Only one player, West Ham's Lucas Paquet\u00e1, has reached 10 goals for Brazil, making the omissions of Casemiro and Richarlison all the more surprising.\n\nThe Sele\u00e7\u00e3o is still reeling from the absence of star man Neymar Jr., who ruptured his ACL playing for the national team in October. Brazil's all-time record goalscorer and a player with the ability to change a game in an instant, Neymar will be sorely missed for his contributions on the pitch, but also his leadership and status as an icon in an inexperienced dressing room.\n\nBrazil recently suffered back-to-back World Cup qualifier set-backs for the first time in its history, before going on to lose a third in a row. That third defeat - a 1-0 loss to Argentina at the Maracan\u00e3 - was historic, too, marking the first time Brazil had ever lost a home World Cup qualifier.\n\nInterim coach Fernando Diniz was sacked in January, less than halfway through his one-year deal, and replaced by journeyman manager Dorival J\u00fanior, who has so far overseen narrow wins against England and Mexico and draws against the USA and Spain.\n\nBut despite the team's recent struggles, the pressure and expectation will still be high back home - in particular with Vin\u00edcius Jr. leading the attack.\n\nThe Real Madrid forward has enjoyed a sensational season for Los Blancos, helping the team to a La Liga and Champions League double and making himself the favorite to win the Ballon d'Or.\n\nUruguay\n\nPerennial overachiever Uruguay once again goes into a Copa Am\u00e9rica among the favorites to win the title.\n\nThe nation of just 3.5 million people holds the joint record alongside Argentina for most Copa Am\u00e9rica titles won with 15.\n\nUnder new manager Marcelo Bielsa, who took charge in May 2023, a new, youthful Uruguay has made a tremendous start to World Cup qualifying, winning four of its six matches so far - including 2-0 wins over Brazil and Argentina - to sit second in the standings.\n\nWhile Bielsa has called up many inexperienced and uncapped players during his tenure so far to better implement his high intensity press, national team icon Luis Su\u00e1rez made the cut and will be supported by a talented cast that includes Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez, Ronald Ara\u00fajo and Federico Valverde.\n\nThe host\n\nThe USA enters the Copa Am\u00e9rica off the back of winning a third straight Nations League title, beating bitter rival Mexico 2-0 in the final less than two months ago.\n\nHowever, preparations for the tournament got off to the worst possible start with a 5-1 hammering at the hands of Colombia in Washington.\n\nAfter the defeat, goalkeeper Matt Turner said the team needed to \"bounce back in a big way,\" and a much-improved performance followed in a morale-boosting 1-1 draw against Brazil.\n\nDespite boasting several talented players, including Tim Weah, Christian Pulisic, Yunus Musah and Folarin Balogun, serious questions remain about whether the US men can consistently compete against teams outside of the weaker CONCACAF bubble.\n\nFortunately for the US, the group draw has been kind. First up is a weak Bolivia side which has endured an abysmal start to World Cup qualifying, losing five of its first six matches, before a clash against familiar CONCACAF opponent Panama.\n\nThe sternest test will come last against Uruguay, but Gregg Berhalter's side should have enough quality to at least advance to the knockout stages. Anything less could be a disaster as the team attempts to drum up support across the country ahead of a home World Cup.\n\nOnly a couple of months ago, you will likely have been hard pressed to find a Chile fan optimistic enough to predict that the team would make it past the group stages.\n\nThe failure to qualify for back-to-back World Cups in 2018 and 2022 has been a bitter pill to swallow for everyone involved after the country's 'Golden Generation' won successive Copa Am\u00e9ricas in 2015 and 2016 and reached the final of the 2017 Confederations Cup.\n\nSince Juan Antonio Pizzi was sacked as manager after the team missed out on Russia 2018, three successive coaches failed to get a tune out of the team - then Ricardo Gareca was hired.\n\nGareca, who impressively took Peru to the 2018 World Cup and the final of the 2019 Copa Am\u00e9rica, has had an immediate impact on the team since taking over in January, leading La Roja to comprehensive 3-0 wins over Paraguay and Albania and pushing France close in a 3-2 defeat in Marseille.\n\nBig names such as Alexis S\u00e1nchez and Claudio Bravo remain in the squad, but there is no place for Arturo Vidal or Gary Medel.\n\nIt might be a bit much to say expectations are now high, but fans are finally excited about watching La Roja playing again.\n\nColombia\n\nColombia arrives in the US as arguably the most in-form team in the tournament, if not the world.\n\nLos Cafeteros are currently on a 23-game unbeaten run that includes wins in their last eight matches. With three wins and three draws so far in World Cup qualifying, the team has soared to third place in the standings to put the failure of reaching Qatar 2022 behind it.\n\nLiverpool's Luis D\u00edaz will be Colombia's main man at the Copa Am\u00e9rica, supported by well-known veterans such as James Rodriguez, David Ospina and Yerry Mina.\n\nThe main issue for Colombia is its brutal potential route to the final, during which it will likely have to face Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8182697070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:32:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/argentina/copa-america/feature/lionel-messis-copa-america-record-goals-assists_546129.html", "title": "Lionel Messi's Copa America record: goals, assists", "body": "Argentina star Lionel Messi will feature at a seventh Copa America when he represents his country at this summer's tournament in the USA.\n\nThe forward clinched his first international title at Copa America 2021, before he led La Albiceleste to World Cup glory in December 2022.\n\nAlthough he is set to turn 37, Messi still remains a key player for Lionel Scaloni's side and will be crucial to their hopes of winning a third consecutive major tournament.\n\nHere, Sports Mole takes a look at Messi's previous performances at the tournament, including his goal contributions and standout moments.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nCopa America 2007 - 2 goals, 1 assist\n\nThe little boy from Rosario made his Copa America debut in 2007 just a year after he made his first major tournament appearance at the 2006 World Cup.\n\nA 20-year-old Messi provided just an assist in the group stage, before he finally got on the scoresheet in Argentina's quarter-final demolition.\n\nMessi made an intelligent run inside to collect Rodrigo Riquelme's exquisite through ball and slot home his first-ever goal at the Copa America.\n\nHis finish in the quarter-final may have been regarded as a relatively simple one, but there was nothing ordinary about the sumptuous strike he produced in the last-four success against Mexico.\n\nWith Argentina a goal to the good, Messi picked up the ball on the right side of the box and opened up his body to conjure up an audacious lob that teased the outstretched Oswaldo Sanchez before nestling in the far corner.\n\nUnfortunately for Messi, his maiden Copa America ended in disappointment as Argentina slumped to a devastating 3-0 defeat to rivals Brazil in the final.\n\nCopa America 2011 - 0 goals, 3 assists\n\nAfter failing to trouble the scorers at the 2010 World Cup, Messi would have hoped to experience improved fortunes at the 2011 Copa America in Argentina.\n\nAs it proved, the attacker would endure another goalless tournament, although he did provide three assists in Argentina's four matches.\n\nHe also kept his composure to dispatch Argentina's first penalty in the quarter-final shootout against Uruguay, but Carlos Tevez failed to convert his spot-kick, ensuring La Albiceleste failed to reach the semi-finals for the first time since 1999.\n\nCopa America 2015 - 1 goal, 3 assists\n\nMessi participated in his second Copa America final in 2015 after helping Argentina progress through the group stage and oust Colombia and Paraguay in the knockout rounds.\n\nHe proved to be a thorn in Paraguay's side, scoring in the opening group game before providing three assists when the two nations met again in Argentina's 6-1 semi-final success.\n\nMessi scored his penalty in the quarter-final shootout against Colombia, and he repeated the feat in the final with Chile after the two countries had played out a goalless draw in Santiago.\n\nHowever, Gonzalo Higuain and Ever Banega were unable to follow Messi's lead as they fluffed their lines to hand Chile the trophy at their home tournament.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nCopa America 2016 - 4 goal, 4 assists\n\nJust a year later, Messi and Argentina experienced more penalty shootout heartbreak in another Copa America final against Chile.\n\nMessi sat out Argentina's opening group game with Chile due to a back problem, but he returned with a bang in their next fixture, netting his one and only hat-trick at a major tournament to fire his country to a 5-0 victory.\n\nThe Argentine magician then produced two phenomenal displays in the quarter-final and semi-final, registering a goal and two assists in both games against Venezuela and the USA.\n\nUnfortunately for Messi, those match-winning performances failed to translate into silverware as he and Lucas Biglia missed their penalties in the final shootout with Chile, leaving him to contemplate whether a major international honour would ever come his way.\n\nCopa America 2019 - 4 goals, 4 assists\n\nAfter having three years to reflect on the 2016 disappointment, Messi's return to the Copa America did not go according to plan as he mustered just one goal and one assist in the 2019 tournament.\n\nArgentina's hopes of winning the competition were quashed by a 2-0 semi-final defeat against Brazil, leaving Messi and his colleagues to fight over the third spot with Chile.\n\nMessi teed up Sergio Aguera for the opener in the third-place playoff, but his tournament ultimately ended with a rare red card after he was dismissed for his part in a confrontation with Gary Medel, who was also dismissed in a game that finished 2-1 in Argentina's favour.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nCopa America 2021 - 4 goals, 5 assists\n\nAs Messi entered another international tournament, there were certainly some doubts as to whether he would ever celebrate a title with Argentina after falling short in the 2014 World Cup final and three Copa America finals.\n\nHowever, all those years of anguish and frustration were finally laid to rest as Messi ended his long wait for international success in Brazil three years ago.\n\nMessi set out his stall with a goal and an assist in Argentina's opening two games, before he moved through the gears with a scintillating display in the final group game against Bolivia, setting up Papu Gomez for the opener before netting a brace to fire La Albiceleste to a 4-1 victory.\n\nThe former Barcelona star continued to lead from the front in the 3-0 quarter-final success over Ecuador, grabbing two assists and netting a trademark free-kick.\n\nMessi then registered an assist in the semi-final against Colombia, before he held his nerve to score in Argentina's penalty shootout success, setting up a mouthwatering final against bitter rivals Brazil.\n\nIt was perhaps fitting that 14 years after losing to Brazil in his first major international tournament final, the attacker finally got over the line against the same opponent thanks to Angel Di Maria's at the Maracana, generating the iconic scene of Messi's teammates running towards him as soon as the final whistle blew.\n\nIf there was one drawback to the 2021 triumph it was that the tournament was played behind closed doors due to COVID, so Messi may have that extra motivation to win the Copa America in front of his adoring faithful when he leads Argentina in the 2024 compettion.\n\nID:546129:1false2false3false:QQ:: from db desktop :LenBod:collect9244:", "source": {"uri": "sportsmole.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sports {"uri": "8187568950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:52:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:52:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:51:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/why-is-south-americas-leading-soccer-tournament-being-played-in-the-united-states", "title": "Why Is South America's Leading Soccer Tournament Being Played in the United States?", "body": "On Thursday, at 8 P.M. Eastern Time, Lionel Messi's Argentina will defend its title as the South American champion in the opening game of the Copa Am\u00e9rica, the longest-running international soccer tournament in the world. It won't take place, however, in any country south of the Dari\u00e9n jungle but in the Mercedes-Benz Stadium, in Atlanta, and Argentina's first opponent will be Canada. The United States, Mexico, Jamaica, Panama, and Costa Rica will also participate in this South American tournament, which will be held in Atlanta, East Rutherford, Orlando, Charlotte, Kansas City, Arlington, Houston, Austin, Glendale, Las Vegas, Inglewood, and Santa Clara. The final, on Sunday, July 14th, will be played in Miami Gardens.\n\nHow has it come to this? The first and most simple answer is that South America is in such a mess that it can no longer take care of its most precious tournament. It's not like the Copa has had a smooth history. Conceived as part of the centennial celebrations of Argentina's independence from Spain, in 1816, its first edition took place in Buenos Aires during two weeks in July of 1916, among only four teams -- Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, and Chile. Six more national teams were added in the following decades: Paraguay, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia, and Venezuela, covering almost all the continent. (Guyana and Suriname, the remaining South American nations, became and still are part of CONCACAF, the association that governs North American, Central American, and Caribbean teams, including the U.S. national team. All other South American teams belong to CONMEBOL.)\n\nDifferent crises have interrupted the Copa over the years. It was played annually until 1929, apart from 1918, owing to the flu pandemic, and 1928, when Argentina and Uruguay participated in the Summer Olympics in Amsterdam, instead. In 1930, Uruguay hosted the first-ever World Cup, defeating Argentina in the final; the subsequent beef between the two countries -- and the two leading teams -- prevented the Copa from being played for most of the following decade. Various reasons contributed to only six Copa Am\u00e9ricas being held in the nineteen-forties, six in the fifties, and just two in the sixties, among them a waning interest in some countries before broadcasting rights made the sport hugely profitable.\n\nIn the nineteen-eighties, it was decided that host countries would be appointed in alphabetical order. Argentina and Colombia were scheduled to co-host the Copa in 2020, but it was delayed owing to the COVID pandemic. The following year, the games in Colombia were suspended in the midst of widespread anti-government protests, and in Argentina, owing to health concerns. And then Brazil, which had hosted it in 2019, took over again. The final, won 1-0 by Messi's Argentina over his friend Neymar's Brazil, was played in an almost empty Maracan\u00e3 Stadium, in Rio de Janeiro.\n\nThis year, it was Ecuador's turn to host. But, in November, 2022, the president of the Ecuadorian Football Federation, Francisco Egas, warned in a radio interview that \"we don't have the capacity to organize the Copa Am\u00e9rica.\" In fact, the nation was in an unprecedented crisis, the result of an especially devastating bout of the pandemic that led to the collapse of public services and brutal gang violence, which, at the beginning of this year, resulted in a declaration of national emergency. When Ecuador decided to pass, CONMEBOL and CONCACAF saw an opportunity to offer an expanded Copa Am\u00e9rica in the U.S. in anticipation of the 2026 World Cup, when the U.S. will be one of the host countries. They not only embraced the U.S. as the host of the Copa but changed the structure of the tournament to include six CONCACAF members.\n\n\"Why is Copa Am\u00e9rica played in the United States this year? Simple answer: money,\" Pablo Alabarces, a sociologist and the author of several books on soccer, including \"A Minimal History of Football in Latin America,\" told me. Oscar Barnade, the vice-president of the Argentinean Center for Research on the History of Football, concurred, saying that CONMEBOL's management has \"surrendered to the economic power of the U.S. and the M.L.S. (Major League Soccer).\"\n\nThe Copa had been hosted in the U.S. once before, in 2016, for a special celebration of its centennial. It took place a year into the FIFA corruption case, an investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice which found that federation executives, including a number from CONMEBOL and CONCACAF, had received more than two hundred million dollars in bribes on marketing and broadcast deals. Despite that scandal, the Cup broke records of attendance with nearly 1.5 million spectators, giving a serious boost to the effort, several decades old, to make soccer a popular sport in the United States. More than a hundred million people watched the matches on Univision and Fox. (Broadcasting rights are core to the soccer business: they generated forty-five per cent of FIFA's revenue between 2019 and 2022, which totalled nearly $7.6 billion.)\n\nLast year, Messi, who had led Argentina to victory in both the 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica and the 2022 World Cup, joined Inter Miami, an M.L.S. team. Apple TV+ had recently signed a $2.5-billion, ten-year deal to stream the league's games. The operation has been quite successful. After Messi joined Inter Miami, the club's value increased from six hundred million dollars to more than a billion. On the day he made his d\u00e9but, Apple TV+ saw a 1,690-per-cent increase in subscriptions to its M.L.S. Season Pass. Ticket prices for his first Inter Miami games increased by more than a thousand per cent in the secondary market. The club's Instagram account jumped from 1.1 million to 6.9 million followers immediately after Messi announced his decision; Messi now has more than five hundred million followers of his own. Celebrities have been flocking to see him play, including LeBron James, Serena Williams, Prince Harry, Kim Kardashian, Leonardo DiCaprio, Will Ferrell, and Selena Gomez. Earlier this year, Messi was named America's favorite professional athlete in a national poll conducted by Social Science Research Solutions; it was the first time a soccer player topped the list.\n\nRecent surveys by Gallup and Pew Research show that soccer, the most popular sport in the world, is now the fourth most popular in the U.S., behind football, baseball, and basketball. Additionally, it has a more diverse and younger fan base than other major sports. It is the favorite sport among Latinos, a population of more than sixty-three million people and growing; if U.S Latinos were a country, it would be the third-largest in Latin America, after Brazil and Mexico. Not surprisingly, most of the Copa Am\u00e9rica matches will be played in cities with significant Latino populations.\n\nBeyond the conquest of this tantalizing American market, the transformation of the Copa Am\u00e9rica from a purely South American tournament into a transcontinental one fits perfectly with a global, twenty-first-century trend: the transnationalization of the sport that Americans know as soccer and the rest of the world knows as football. These days, major European teams routinely tour the U.S., Asia, and Australia in the pre-season; players from the Global South are sold as soon as they are turned out by local academies to European clubs owned not only by millionaires from around the world but even by state proxies, as in the case of Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. {"uri": "8184718677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:48:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:48:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:47:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://sports.ndtv.com/football/i-dont-need-to-commit-to-2026-fifa-world-cup-lionel-messi-ahead-of-2024-copa-america-5921473", "title": "\"I Don't Need To Commit To 2026 FIFA World Cup\": Lionel Messi Ahead Of 2024 Copa America | Football News", "body": "World champions Argentina get an expanded Copa America under way on Thursday with Lionel Messi looking to add a second continental title in what is almost certainly his final appearance in the tournament. The 108-year-old competition is being held in the United States with the host nation among six teams from the CONCACAF region joining the 10 South American nations looking for a place in the July 14 final in Miami. While FIFA will be looking closely at the organization of the event, two years out from the World Cup which will be co-hosted by the USA, Canada and Mexico, the tournament's rich history and prestige means it is much, much more than a 'trial event'.\n\nArgentina have won the Copa 15 times but only once, in 2021, during the Messi era and coach Lionel Scaloni has stuck largely with his World Cup-winning squad, with veterans Angel Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi likely taking their final bow in a major tournament.\n\nWhether this is Messi's goodbye to elite international football is yet to be found out - the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner, now playing in Major League Soccer with Inter Miami, will turn 37 four days after Thursday's opener in Atlanta against Canada and has yet to decide whether he will try to play in a record sixth World Cup.\n\n\"It's great to have records and continue to achieve things but I won't take part in a World Cup just to say I've done six,\" Messi told ESPN last week.\n\n\"If I feel good and everything is in place for me to be there, fine, but I won't go just to go. It's very difficult to imagine what can happen because it's still two years away. I don't need to commit right now to whether or not I'll be there,\" he added.\n\nWhat is certain is that Messi, who has managed his workload to try to be in peak condition for the tournament, would relish the chance to win a third straight major tournament with his country after so many years of frustration with his national team.\n\nAfter facing Canada, Argentina take on Chile in New Jersey before finishing their group A action against Peru in Miami but they know that tough opposition awaits in the knock-out stage with rivals Brazil and Uruguay the two expected challengers for the title.\n\nBrazil have struggled in CONMEBOL qualifiers for the 2026 World Cup having won just two of their opening six games and they currently sit in sixth place in the standings having lost to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina.\n\nThe pressure will be on the Real Madrid attacking pair of Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo to translate their club form into success for the Selecao while there is much excitement around the senior tournament debut of 17-year-old talent Endrick, who is set to join Real next month from Palmeiras.\n\nUruguay, also 15-times winners, have impressed under their 68-year-old Argentina coach Marcelo Bielsa, who has brought his trademark high-energy style to the team and raised expectations with recent wins over Argentina and Brazil.\n\nColombia head into the tournament without a loss in over two years and with Liverpool's livewire winger Luis Diaz a constant threat and James Rodriguez enjoying a late career revival, Nestor Lorenzo's team can't be discounted.\n\nThe USA will hope that they can generate some sorely needed excitement after losing their way since a creditable run to the last-16 at the World Cup.\n\nCoach Gregg Berhalter is under some pressure to show he can get his team, which relies on the smart wing play of Christian Pulisic, to compete with teams from outside of CONCACAF.\n\nMexico have guested frequently in the Copa in the past and reached the final in 1993 and 2001, but they look well below their usual level although they can, as always, count on huge support in the USA.\n\nThis is the second time the Copa America is being held in the USA, after the Centenary tournament in 2016, and while that is a break with tradition the presence of significant immigrant communities from all the competing nations, should {"uri": "8185281857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:13:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:13:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/sports/football/argentina-kick-off-copa-america-defense-in-messis-swan-song", "title": "Argentina kick off Copa America defense in Messi's swan song", "body": "Argentina, the reigning world champions, will kick off an extended Copa America campaign on Thursday, with Lionel Messi eyeing his second continental crown in what could be his final tournament appearance.\n\nThe 108-year-old competition unfolds in the U.S., featuring six CONCACAF teams alongside the 10 South American nations, all vying for a spot in the July 14 final in Miami.\n\nWhile FIFA closely monitors the event's organization, given its proximity to the World Cup, co-hosted by the USA, Canada and Mexico in two years, the Copa America's illustrious history and prestige elevate it far beyond a mere \"trial event.\"\n\nArgentina has won the Copa 15 times but only once, in 2021, during the Messi era, and coach Lionel Scaloni has stuck largely with his World Cup-winning squad, with veterans Angel Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi likely taking their final bow in a major tournament.\n\nWhether this is Messi's goodbye to elite international football remains to be seen - the eight-time Ballon d'Or winner, now playing in Major League Soccer with Inter Miami, will turn 37 four days after Thursday's opener in Atlanta against Canada and has yet to decide whether he will try to play in a record sixth World Cup.\n\n\"It's great to have records and continue to achieve things, but I won't take part in a World Cup just to say I've done six,\" Messi told ESPN last week.\n\n\"If I feel good and everything is in place for me to be there, fine, but I won't go just to go. It's very difficult to imagine what can happen because it's still two years away. I don't need to commit right now to whether or not I'll be there,\" he added.\n\nWhat is certain is that Messi, who has managed his workload to try to be in peak condition for the tournament, would relish the chance to win a third straight major tournament with his country after so many years of frustration with his national team.\n\nAfter facing Canada, Argentina takes on Chile in New Jersey before finishing their Group A action against Peru in Miami, but they know that tough opposition awaits in the knockout stage with rivals Brazil and Uruguay the two expected challengers for the title.\n\nBrazil has struggled in CONMEBOL qualifiers for the 2026 World Cup, having won just two of their opening six games, and they currently sit in sixth place in the standings having lost to Uruguay, Colombia, and Argentina.\n\nThere are several familiar names missing from Dorival Junior's Brazil squad with Casemiro, Gabriel Jesus and Thiago Silva left out while Richarlison and Neymar are both missing due to injury.\n\nThe pressure will be on the Real Madrid attacking pair of Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo to translate their club form into success for the Selecao, while there is much excitement around the senior tournament debut of 17-year-old talent Endrick, who is set to join Real next month from Palmeiras.\n\nUruguay, also 15-time winners, has impressed under their 68-year-old Argentina coach, Marcelo Bielsa, who has brought his trademark high-energy style to the team and raised expectations with recent wins over Argentina and Brazil.\n\nLiverpool forward Darwin Nunez will lead the line, although Bielsa has the option of introducing veteran Luis Suarez from the bench.\n\nColombia head into the tournament without a loss in over two years and with Liverpool's livewire winger Luis Diaz a constant threat and James Rodriguez enjoying a late-career revival, Nestor Lorenzo's team can't be discounted.\n\nThe USA team will hope that they can generate some much-needed excitement after losing their way since a creditable run to the last 16 at the World Cup.\n\nCoach Gregg Berhalter is under some pressure to show he can get his team, which relies on the smart wing play of Christian Pulisic, to compete with teams from outside of CONCACAF.\n\nMexico have guested frequently in the Copa in the past and reached the final in 1993 and 2001, but they look well below their usual level although they can, as always, count on huge support in the U.S.\n\nThis is the second time Copa America is being held in the U.S., after the Centenary tournament in 2016, and while {"uri": "8185482902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:28:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:28:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:27:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/soccer/2024/06/19/copa-america-2024-schedule-tickets-cities-odds/74139762007/", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024: Everything you need to know. Schedule, host cities, betting odds, more", "body": "United States Men's Soccer star Christian Pulisic chats about the team's current mindset, as well as his partnership with Michelob Ultra centered around Copa America.\n\nCopa Am\u00e9rica 2024 begins this week in the United States, kickstarting a summer of soccer unlike many others in recent history.\n\nThe tournament begins Thursday with soccer star Lionel Messi and world champion Argentina facing Canada in Atlanta, while the U.S. men's national team begins play Sunday against Bolivia at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas.\n\nWith Euro 2024 ongoing in Germany as well, there will be day and night soccer coverage on FOX and TelevisaUnivision networks.\n\nIt's an exciting time to be a soccer fan in the United States. And if you aren't one already, it's the perfect time to jump onboard.\n\n\"Don't let anybody tell you that we're not a soccer nation. Don't let anybody tell that we don't have a soccer culture,\" FOX analyst and former U.S. men's national team standout Alexi Lalas told USA TODAY Sports. \"It's different. It is unique and it is uniquely American. And that's something I think we should lean into and celebrate.\"\n\nCONMEBOL Copa Am\u00e9rica, or the American cup, is the world's oldest running continental tournament, dating to 1916. It is used to determine the champion of South America, but select teams from North America and Asia have been invited to compete since the 1990s. This year, the 10 CONMEBOL teams will be joined by six Concacaf teams.\n\nThis summer's edition will be the 48 tournament and only the second time it has ever been held outside of South America. The United States also hosted Copa Am\u00e9rica Centenario in 2016, a special edition of the tournament to commemorate 100 years of CONMEBOL and Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nThe tournament is now held every four years, coinciding with the UEFA European Championship.\n\nDefending champions Argentina and Uruguay have won Copa Am\u00e9rica 15 times each, most of any country followed by Brazil (nine, last in 2019).\n\nThe tournament will be held in 14 cities across the U.S., with each location hosting two or three matches over a 25-day period. The opening match is Thursday in Atlanta and the final is July 14 in Miami. The third-place match will be in Charlotte July 13.\n\nMatches will also be played at stadiums in Arizona (Glendale); California (Santa Clara and Inglewood); Florida (Orlando and Miami); Kansas and Missouri (in Kansas City); Nevada (Las Vegas); New Jersey (East Rutherford) and Texas (Arlington, Austin and Houston).\n\nMore than 1 million tickets have been sold for 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica games, according to CONMEBOL. Tickets can be purchased at copamerica.com and other ticketing platforms.\n\nCOPA AMERICA TICKETS: Experience Copa America 2024 in person\n\nHere's the Copa Am\u00e9rica schedule for group play (June 20-July 2), round of 16 (July 4-6), semifinals (July 9 and 10), third-place (July 13) and final (July 14).\n\nBefore the 8 p.m. ET kickoff of Argentina vs. Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, fans will get a show for the opening ceremony of Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nColombian musician Feid is the opening act. He is a nine-time Latin Grammy nominee.\n\nThe U.S. men's national team begins play in Group C against Bolivia on Sunday, then Panama on June 27 and Uruguay July 1.\n\nDuring friendlies to prepare for the tournament, the U.S. played Brazil to a 1-1 draw last Wednesday, rebounding from a disappointing 5-1 defeat to Colombia.\n\nThe Americans' best Copa Am\u00e9rica finish has been fourth place, losing the third-place game in 1995 and 2016.\n\nFOX analyst Alexi Lalas says: \"I think Gregg Berhalter, the head coach, is under pressure to provide one of those seminal types of moments, and to do things that haven't been done in the past. And this group, we have put them on this pedestal, and I think fairly so because we expect them to do things that we haven't seen in the past and that people don't think can be done. And I don't think that that's unfair. But it's up to them to believe that they can do it.\"\n\nMessi and Argentina are the defending Copa Am\u00e9rica 2021 and World Cup 2022 champions, and the favorites to win this summer's Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nMessi, the star of Inter Miami in Major League Soccer, turns 37 on June 24. He's still among the best players in the world, despite nearing the end of his illustrious career. And his participation in Copa Am\u00e9rica is a critical moment for the sport in the United States, which will host the FIFA Club World Cup in 2025 and World Cup 2026.\n\nArgentina (+175) is the betting favorite to win Copa Am\u00e9rica, while the United States is tied among three teams with the fourth-best odds to win, according to BETMGM.\n\nHere's the next Top 5: Brazil (+225), Uruguay (+500), while Colombia, Mexico and the U.S. have +1200 odds.\n\nArgentina and Brazil (+225) are the oddsmakers' favorites to reach the Copa Am\u00e9rica final, to be played at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla. on July 14.\n\nThere will be 41 Major League Soccer players (including one MLS Next Pro player) in Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nUnited States: Sean Johnson (GK, Toronto FC), Shaq Moore (D, Nashville SC), Miles Robinson (D, FC Cincinnati).\n\nArgentina: Lionel Messi (F, Inter Miami CF).\n\nCanada: Ali Ahmed (M, Vancouver Whitecaps FC), Mo\u00efse Bombito (D, Colorado Rapids), Mathieu Choini\u00e8re (M, CF Montr\u00e9al), Maxime Cr\u00e9peau (GK, Portland Timbers), Kyle Hiebert (D, St. Louis CITY SC), Richie Laryea (D, Toronto FC), Kamal Miller (D, Portland Timbers), Tani Oluwaseyi Minnesota United FC), Joel Waterman (CF Montr\u00e9al).\n\nCosta Rica: Alejandro Bran (M, Minnesota United FC), Julio Cascante (D, Austin FC), Ariel Lassiter (M, CF Montr\u00e9al).\n\nEcuador: Carlos Gruezo (M, San Jose Earthquakes).\n\nJamaica: Jon Bell (D, Seattle Sounders FC), Andre Blake (GK, Philadelphia Union), Kevon Lambert (M, Real Salt Lake), Damion Lowe (D, Philadelphia Union).\n\nPanama: Coco Carrasquilla (M, Houston Dynamo FC), An\u00edbal Godoy (M, Panama), Carlos Harvey (M, Minnesota United FC), Omar Valencia (D, New York Red Bulls II).\n\nParaguay: Carlos {"uri": "8184975348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:59:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:59:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:58:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/football-sports/football-don-t-need-to-commit-to-2026-world-cup-lionel-messi-drops-bombshell-ahead-of-copa-america-2024-osf-sfbklp", "title": "'Don't need to commit to 2026 World Cup': Lionel Messi drops bombshell ahead of Copa America 2024", "body": "World champions Argentina kick off an expanded Copa America on Thursday, with Lionel Messi aiming to secure a second continental title in what is likely his final appearance in the tournament. The historic 108-year-old competition is being held in the United States, featuring six CONCACAF teams joining the ten South American nations vying for a spot in the July 14 final in Miami. While FIFA will closely observe the event's organization ahead of the 2026 World Cup, which will be co-hosted by the USA, Canada, and Mexico, the Copa America's rich history and prestige make it far more than just a 'trial event'.\n\nArgentina has claimed the Copa America 15 times, but only once during Messi's era, in 2021. Coach Lionel Scaloni has largely retained the World Cup-winning squad, with veterans Angel Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi likely participating in their final major tournament.\n\nWhether this will be Messi's farewell to elite international football remains uncertain. The eight-time Ballon d'Or winner, now playing in Major League Soccer with Inter Miami, will turn 37 four days after Thursday's opener in Atlanta against Canada and has yet to decide if he will pursue a record sixth World Cup appearance.\n\n\"It's great to have records and continue to achieve things, but I won't take part in a World Cup just to say I've done six,\" Messi told ESPN last week. \"If I feel good and everything is in place for me to be there, fine, but I won't go just to go. It's very difficult to imagine what can happen because it's still two years away. I don't need to commit right now to whether or not I'll be there,\" he added.\n\nOne thing is certain: Messi, who has managed his workload to be in peak condition for the tournament, would cherish the chance to win a third consecutive major title with his country after years of frustration with the national team.\n\nTough Opposition\n\nAfter facing Canada, Argentina will play against Chile in New Jersey and then finish their group stage matches against Peru in Miami. They are aware that tough opposition awaits in the knockout stage, with Brazil and Uruguay expected to be the main challengers for the title.\n\nBrazil has struggled in CONMEBOL qualifiers for the 2026 World Cup, winning only two of their first six games and currently sitting in sixth place after losses to Uruguay, Colombia, and Argentina.\n\nSeveral familiar names are absent from Dorival Junior's Brazil squad, including Casemiro, Gabriel Jesus, and Thiago Silva, while Richarlison and Neymar are out due to injuries. The pressure will be on Real Madrid's attacking duo, Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo, to replicate their club success for the national team. There is also much excitement around 17-year-old talent Endrick, set to join Real Madrid next month from Palmeiras, making his senior tournament debut.\n\nUruguay, also 15-time winners, has impressed under their 68-year-old Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa, who has instilled his high-energy style into the team, raising expectations with recent wins over Argentina and Brazil. Liverpool forward Darwin Nunez will lead the line, although Bielsa can call on veteran Luis Suarez from the bench.\n\nColombia enters the tournament unbeaten in over two years, with Liverpool's dynamic winger Luis Diaz and James Rodriguez, who is experiencing a late-career revival, making Nestor Lorenzo's team a formidable opponent.\n\nThe USA hopes to generate excitement after losing momentum since their last-16 finish at the World Cup. Coach Gregg Berhalter is under pressure to prove that his team, relying on the smart wing play of Christian Pulisic, can compete with teams outside of CONCACAF.\n\nMexico, frequent guests at the Copa America, reached the final in 1993 and 2001, but currently look below their usual level. However, they can always count on massive support in the USA.\n\nThis is the second time the Copa America is being held in the USA, following the Centenary tournament in 2016. {"uri": "8187291045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:22:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:22:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:21:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/sports/lionel-scaloni-expects-difficult-copa-america-for-argentina-as-defending-champions-gear-up-for-title-defence-733596", "title": "Lionel Scaloni expects 'difficult' Copa America for Argentina as defending champions gear up for title defence", "body": "The tournament brings together 10 South American teams and six from North and Central America and the Caribbean in the second Copa hosted by the United States.\n\nWorld Cup winners Argentina must put recent success behind them when they begin their Copa America title defence, coach Lionel Scaloni said on Wednesday ahead of their opening game against Canada.\n\nThe tournament brings together 10 South American teams and six from North and Central America and the Caribbean in the second Copa hosted by the United States.\n\nScaloni said his team must raise their game to win the title again, as facing CONCACAF teams was no easier than playing a European or South American sides.\n\nALSO READ: Kylian Mbappe's broken nose pushes France to deploy Plan B at Euros 2024\n\n\"We are talking about things that have already passed. (Winning the World Cup and the Copa America) was very nice but it's over,\" the Argentine manager told a news conference. \"Football matches are all different, there are no easier games than others. A lot of things can happen. The difficulty of France, Brazil or Canada can be the same.\n\n\"It will be a difficult Copa America as always, we are prepared for what is to come. We are doing well, with clear ideas and knowing the difficulty of this tournament.\"\n\nAhead of their opening match against Canada on Thursday, the 46-year-old said enjoying the game had been the key to his team's success after failing to win the 2015 and 2016 Copa finals and a semi-final exit in 2019.\n\n\"Beyond the titles, we have enjoyed a lot. It's a pleasure to watch how (the players) give their all,\" he said. \"That leads to being able to achieve things. We have shown that even if we didn't win like in 2019, we were able to continue and show you can do things.", "source": {"uri": "wionews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WION"}, "authors": [], "https://cdn.wionews.com/sites/default/files/2024/06/20/438969-argentinas-scaloni-expects-difficult-copa-america-for-defending-champions.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9658543", {"uri": "8184286568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "21:18:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T21:18:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T21:16:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/sports/the-buzzer-newsletter-copa-america-preview-june-18-1.7238923", "title": "The Canadian men's soccer team takes on South America's best at the Copa America | CBC Sports", "body": "This is an excerpt from The Buzzer, which is CBC Sports' daily email newsletter. Stay up to speed on what's happening in sports by subscribing here.\n\nWhat a time for soccer fans. With the men's European Championship underway in Germany and the Olympic tournaments in Paris just five weeks away, another big international event kicks off on Thursday night in Atlanta as Canada faces World Cup champion Argentina in the Copa America opener.\n\nHere are a few key things to know about the Copa and what it means for Canada:\n\nThis is South America's version of the European Championship.\n\nIt's not as large, as deep or as widely celebrated as the 24-team Euro, which includes eight of the world's top 10 teams. But the Copa features No. 1 ranked Argentina (the reigning Copa and World Cup champion) and No. 5 Brazil (winner of a record five World Cups) among its 16 entries. The other top South American countries in the tournament are 12th-ranked Colombia and No. 15 Uruguay, along with Ecuador, Peru, Chile, Venezuela, Paraguay and Bolivia (all ranked outside the top 30).\n\nWith the United States hosting this year, six teams from the CONCACAF confederation (North and Central America and the Caribbean) were invited to play. The top qualifiers from the region are the 11th-ranked United States and No. 15 Mexico. They're joined by Canada, ranked 49th, and Panama, Costa Rica and Jamaica (all ranked between 45th and 55th).\n\nThe teams are divided into four groups of four for round-robin play in various U.S. cities, with the top two in each group advancing to the quarterfinals starting July 4 in Texas, Arizona and Las Vegas. The semifinals are July 9 and 10 in New Jersey and North Carolina, and the final takes place July 14 in Miami.\n\nLionel Messi is nearing the end.\n\nIn the 2021 Copa final, Messi captained Argentina to a 1-0 win over rival Brazil at famed Maracana Stadium in Rio, giving La Albiceleste their first South American title since 1993 and Messi the first senior international trophy of his career. The following year in Qatar, Messi led Argentina to its first World Cup title since Diego Maradona's iconic Hand of God-assisted victory in 1986.\n\nNow that Messi has silenced (at least some of) his Maradona-worshipping critics in Argentina, there's speculation that the Copa could be the final international tournament for the almost-37-year-old superstar. But with the 2026 World Cup taking place mostly in the United States, and Messi still playing brilliantly for Inter Miami of U.S.-based Major League Soccer (he has 12 goals in 12 games this season) it seems like there's a good chance he'll stick around.\n\nBrazil is trying to regain continental supremacy.\n\nAn Argentina-Brazil rematch is expected for the final. Messi's team is the slight betting favourite to win the title over the Brazilians, who have fallen on tough times by their lofty standards. The Selecao's last World Cup title came more than two decades ago, in 2002, and they were eliminated in the quarterfinals in four of the five World Cups since then, including the last two.\n\nNeymar, who last year overtook Pel\u00e9 to become Brazil's all-time leading men's scorer, is out with a knee injury. But Brazil still has plenty of stars at the Copa, including Champions League MVP Vinicius Junior, his Real Madrid teammate Rodrygo and 17-year-old phenom Endrick, who already has three goals in six matches for the senior national team and is about to join the others on Real Madrid.\n\nThis is a big test for Canada.\n\nQualifying for the Copa for the first time gave the Canadian men's team a valuable opportunity to face quality opponents from outside their region in a high-pressure environment as they prepare for the 2026 World Cup, which Canada is co-hosting with the U.S. and Mexico. But they nearly blew it, losing a home-and-home qualifier against Jamaica in November after taking a two-goal lead into the final half.\n\nThe Canadians ducked into the Copa by defeating 98th-ranked Trinidad and Tobago in a last-chance play-in game in March. They later replaced interim head coach Mauro Biello with Jesse Marsch, a 50-year-old American who has guided teams in the English Premier League, the German Bundesliga and Major League Soccer. Biello filled the role after John Herdman left for Toronto FC after guiding Canada to its first World Cup appearance in 36 years.\n\nMarsch's results since taking over last month have been mixed. His team got outclassed 4-0 by the seventh-ranked Netherlands on June 7 before battling No. 2 France to a scoreless draw in another away friendly three days later.\n\nFor his first tournament in charge of Canada, Marsch named 23-year-old Alphonso Davies as team captain. The Bayern Munich star replaces Atiba Hutchinson, who retired last year with a Canadian men's record 104 appearances. Vice captain Stephen Eustaquio (FC Porto), Jonathan David (Lille) and Tajon Buchanan (Inter Milan) are also among the holdovers from the 2022 World Cup, where Canada lost all three of its matches and scored just one goal. Marsch was forced to make a late change on Sunday, replacing injured winger Junior Hoilett with Joel Waterman. Read more about the Canadian roster here.\n\nAfter their date with Messi's Argentina on Thursday at 8 p.m. ET in Atlanta, Canada will play 32nd-ranked Peru on June 25 at 6 p.m. ET in Kansas City and No. 42 Chile on June 29 at 8 p.m. ET in Orlando.\n\nAs the lowest-ranked team in Group A, Canada is not expected to advance. The betting markets give them only about a 30 per cent chance of placing in the top two, putting them well behind Argentina (above 90 per cent) and Chile (above 50 per cent) but slightly ahead of Peru (about 27 per cent). \"We know it's a big challenge,\" Marsch said. Read more about Canada's outlook for the Copa in this story by CBC News' Jamie Strashin.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
