{"uri": "2024-06-392569938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "17:22:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T17:22:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T17:04:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/lionel-messi-and-argentina-will-try-for-a-3rd-straight-major-title-in-copa-america/article_1769bbe2-6f01-55b3-a013-d8ba0bdc8fa6.html", "title": "Lionel Messi and Argentina will try for a 3rd straight major title in Copa America", "body": "FILE - Brazil's Endrick, right, celebrates with Rodrygo after scoring his side's second goal during a friendly soccer match between Spain and Brazil at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid, Spain, Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Messi and Argentina will try to win their third straight major title when they defend their Copa America championship while Brazil hopes 17-year-old Endrick will combine with Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo for success.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain's feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.\n\nComing off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\n\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nHe has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina's national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nA look at the tournament:\n\nExpanded field\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nBack in the USA\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.\n\nCONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nU.S. team\n\nThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup -- the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada -- and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.\n\nChristian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\n\n\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we'll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It's a special time for this sport in America.\"\n\nWorld Cup test?\n\nIn 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.\n\nAt MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\n\n\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... Not only can we track the drone, but more importantly, we can track where the operator is.\"\n\nAP sports: https://apnews.com/sports", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8186938666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:42:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:42:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:41:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/copa-am-rica-2024-lionel-110355193.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024: Lionel Messi's final 'Last Dance' with Argentina?", "body": "For just the second time in the tournament's 108-year history, the Copa Am\u00e9rica will be played outside of South America.\n\nAs it did in 2016 for the special centenary, the United States will host this year's expanded edition that will feature 16 teams rather than the customary 12 and will be something of a dress rehearsal for the 2026 World Cup, which will be hosted in the US, Mexico and Canada.\n\nTaking part will be the 10 CONMEBOL nations as usual, plus the US, Mexico, Jamaica and Panama, which all qualified as semifinalists of the CONCACAF Nations League.\n\nAdditionally, Costa Rica and Canada also qualified via the playoffs contested between the losing Nations League quarterfinalists.\n\nThree years ago, Messi helped the Albiceleste to glory at the Covid-delayed 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica, beating host Brazil in the final, his first major trophy with the national team and the country's first in 28 years.\n\nThat victory lifted the weight of expectation off his shoulders and more than likely acted as a catalyst for Argentina's World Cup victory in Qatar 18 months later, with Messi finally getting his hands on the one trophy he had craved most.\n\nPreviously tormented by his failures with Argentina, even retiring temporarily from international football after a second straight Copa Am\u00e9rica final defeat to Chile in 2016, Messi told Argentine outlet Infobae recently that he's now \"achieved everything.\"\n\nThere is the real possibility that the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica will be the last major international tournament Messi plays. After previously stating that the 2022 World Cup would be his last, Messi told Star+ in December that \"time will tell.\"\n\n\"As long as I feel I am well and that I am able to help, I will do it,\" Messi, who will turn 37 during the Copa Am\u00e9rica, said. \"Today, all I think about is to get well to the Copa Am\u00e9rica and play it. Fight for it again, as we always do, try to be the champions.\n\n\"If we do well at Copa Am\u00e9rica and I can keep playing, maybe it happens.\"\n\nBut Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni, who has overseen just four defeats in the team's last 50 games, had a message for Messi fans: Don't worry about the future, just enjoy the now.\n\n\"We Argentines are too melancholic and we are already thinking about the day when he is gone while he's still playing,\" Scaloni said last week. \"So let's enjoy him and we'll see what happens tomorrow. I think the present is so important for the whole world - not only for Argentina - because, in the end, Leo plays for everyone who likes football.\"\n\nOne player who will definitely be making his last tournament appearance for Argentina is \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda.\n\nThe 36-year-old has made 140 appearances for the national team and enjoys legendary status back home thanks to his winner in the final of the 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica and a goal in the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nDi Mar\u00eda also won the U20 World Cup in 2007 and an Olympic gold medal at Beijing 2008.\n\nBrazil\n\nPreviously thought of as one of, if not the greatest football nation on earth, Brazil currently finds itself navigating a complicated transitional period.\n\nThe squad for the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica is largely inexperienced, with 15 players on less than 10 caps for their country. Only one player, West Ham's Lucas Paquet\u00e1, has reached 10 goals for Brazil, making the omissions of Casemiro and Richarlison all the more surprising.\n\nThe Sele\u00e7\u00e3o is still reeling from the absence of star man Neymar Jr., who ruptured his ACL playing for the national team in October. Brazil's all-time record goalscorer and a player with the ability to change a game in an instant, Neymar will be sorely missed for his contributions on the pitch, but also his leadership and status as an icon in an inexperienced dressing room.\n\nBrazil recently suffered back-to-back World Cup qualifier set-backs for the first time in its history, before going on to lose a third in a row. That third defeat - a 1-0 loss to Argentina at the Maracan\u00e3 - was historic, too, marking the first time Brazil had ever lost a home World Cup qualifier.\n\nInterim coach Fernando Diniz was sacked in January, less than halfway through his one-year deal, and replaced by journeyman manager Dorival J\u00fanior, who has so far overseen narrow wins against England and Mexico and draws against the USA and Spain.\n\nBut despite the team's recent struggles, the pressure and expectation will still be high back home - in particular with Vin\u00edcius Jr. leading the attack.\n\nThe Real Madrid forward has enjoyed a sensational season for Los Blancos, helping the team to a La Liga and Champions League double and making himself the favorite to win the Ballon d'Or.\n\nUruguay\n\nPerennial overachiever Uruguay once again goes into a Copa Am\u00e9rica among the favorites to win the title.\n\nThe nation of just 3.5 million people holds the joint record alongside Argentina for most Copa Am\u00e9rica titles won with 15.\n\nUnder new manager Marcelo Bielsa, who took charge in May 2023, a new, youthful Uruguay has made a tremendous start to World Cup qualifying, winning four of its six matches so far - including 2-0 wins over Brazil and Argentina - to sit second in the standings.\n\nWhile Bielsa has called up many inexperienced and uncapped players during his tenure so far to better implement his high intensity press, national team icon Luis Su\u00e1rez made the cut and will be supported by a talented cast that includes Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez, Ronald Ara\u00fajo and Federico Valverde.\n\nThe USA enters the Copa Am\u00e9rica off the back of winning a third straight Nations League title, beating bitter rival Mexico 2-0 in the final less than two months ago.\n\nHowever, preparations for the tournament got off to the worst possible start with a 5-1 hammering at the hands of Colombia in Washington.\n\nAfter the defeat, goalkeeper Matt Turner said the team needed to \"bounce back in a big way,\" and a much-improved performance followed in a morale-boosting 1-1 draw against Brazil.\n\nDespite boasting several talented players, including Tim Weah, Christian Pulisic, Yunus Musah and Folarin Balogun, serious questions remain about whether the US men can consistently compete against teams outside of the weaker CONCACAF bubble.\n\nFortunately for the US, the group draw has been kind. First up is a weak Bolivia side which has endured an abysmal start to World Cup qualifying, losing five of its first six matches, before a clash against familiar CONCACAF opponent Panama.\n\nThe sternest test will come last against Uruguay, but Gregg Berhalter's side should have enough quality to at least advance to the knockout stages. Anything less could be a disaster as the team attempts to drum up support across the country ahead of a home World Cup.\n\nChile\n\nOnly a couple of months ago, you will likely have been hard pressed to find a Chile fan optimistic enough to predict that the team would make it past the group stages.\n\nThe failure to qualify for back-to-back World Cups in 2018 and 2022 has been a bitter pill to swallow for everyone involved after the country's 'Golden Generation' won successive Copa Am\u00e9ricas in 2015 and 2016 and reached the final of the 2017 Confederations Cup.\n\nSince Juan Antonio Pizzi was sacked as manager after the team missed out on Russia 2018, three successive coaches failed to get a tune out of the team - then Ricardo Gareca was hired.\n\nGareca, who impressively took Peru to the 2018 World Cup and the final of the 2019 Copa Am\u00e9rica, has had an immediate impact on the team since taking over in January, leading La Roja to comprehensive 3-0 wins over Paraguay and Albania and pushing France close in a 3-2 defeat in Marseille.\n\nBig names such as Alexis S\u00e1nchez and Claudio Bravo remain in the squad, but there is no place for Arturo Vidal or Gary Medel.\n\nIt might be a bit much to say expectations are now high, but fans are finally excited about watching La Roja playing again.\n\nColombia\n\nColombia arrives in the US as arguably the most in-form team in the tournament, if not the world.\n\nLos Cafeteros are currently on a 23-game unbeaten run that includes wins in their last eight matches. With three wins and three draws so far in World Cup qualifying, the team has soared to third place in the standings to put the failure of reaching Qatar 2022 behind it.\n\nLiverpool's Luis D\u00edaz will be Colombia's main man at the Copa Am\u00e9rica, supported by well-known veterans such as James Rodriguez, David Ospina and Yerry Mina.\n\nThe main issue for Colombia is its brutal potential route to the final, during which it will likely have to face Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": {"uri": "8182472403", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "20:04:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T20:04:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T20:04:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/17/lionel-messi-argentina-shoot-for-third-straight-major-title-at-copa-america/", "title": "Lionel Messi, Argentina shoot for third straight major title at Copa America", "body": "Argentina's Lionel Messi celebrates with the trophy after beating Brazil 1-0 in the 2021 Copa America. Messi and Argentina will try to win their third straight major title when they defend their Copa America championship. Bruna Prado/Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK -- Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain's feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.\n\nComing off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\n\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nHe has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina's national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina Coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. Coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nA look at the tournament:\n\nEXPANDED FIELD\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBACK IN THE USA\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.\n\nCONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nU.S. TEAM\n\nThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup - the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada - and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChristian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\n\n\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we'll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It's a special time for this sport in America.\"\n\nWORLD CUP TEST\n\nIn 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.\n\nAt MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\n\n\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... Not only can we track the drone, but more importantly, we can track where the operator is.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. (Winning the World Cup and the Copa America) was very nice but it's over,\" the Argentine manager told a news conference.\n\n\"Football matches are all different, there are no easier games than others. A lot of things can happen. The difficulty of France, Brazil or Canada can be the same.\n\n\"It will be a difficult Copa America as always, we are prepared for what is to come. We are doing well, with clear ideas and knowing the difficulty of this tournament.\"\n\nAhead of their opening match against Canada on Thursday, the 46-year-old said enjoying the game had been the key to his team's success after failing to win the 2015 and 2016 Copa finals and a semi-final exit in 2019.\n\n\"Beyond the titles, we have enjoyed a lot. It's a pleasure to watch how (the players) give their all,\" he said. \"That leads to being able to achieve things. {"uri": "2024-06-393441402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "12:16:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T12:16:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T12:16:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.europesun.com/news/274417131/copa-america-preview-eight-things-to-look-out-for", "title": "Copa America preview: Eight things to look out for", "body": "WASHINGTON, June 18 (Xinhua) -- The Copa America will kick off on Thursday when defending champions Argentina meet Canada at the Mercedes-Benz stadium in Atlanta, Georgia.\n\nThis year's tournament, to be played in 14 cities across the United States, will feature the 10 South American nations, plus six from the Confederation of North America, Central America and the Caribbean (CONCACAF).\n\nHere are eight things to look out for in the 48th edition of the world's oldest continental football competition.\n\n1. Can Argentina be champions again?\n\nHow times have changed for Argentina. Three years ago, the country's press and fans were openly wondering if the Albiceleste would ever win another major trophy as their title drought approached three decades. That changed when Lionel Scaloni's men beat Brazil in the final of the 2021 Copa America at Rio de Janeiro's Maracana stadium.\n\nLess than 18 months later, they went one better by lifting the World Cup trophy for the first time since 1986 with a penalty shootout victory over France in Qatar.\n\nBut can the South American giants make it three major trophies in a row?\n\nRecent results would suggest so. The Albiceleste have been in ominous form of late, having scored three goals or more in three of their past four matches, including a 4-1 rout of Guatemala in their final Copa America warmup fixture last Friday (June 14).\n\nAnother triumph in the United States would make Scaloni's side the first team to successfully defend the Copa America while simultaneously holding the World Cup trophy.\n\n2. Is this really the United States' Golden Generation?\n\nManager Gregg Berhalter has what is arguably the strongest playing list ever assembled by the United States for a major football tournament.\n\nEighteen of the 26 players named in Berhalter's squad ply their trade in one of Europe's top leagues (England, Spain, Italy, France, Germany and the Netherlands).\n\nThe midfield looks particularly dangerous, marshaled by Juventus star Weston McKennie, AC Milan's Yunus Musah and Nottingham Forest playmaker Giovanni Reyna.\n\nThe attack will be led by Christian Pulisic, who says he is in career-best form after a superb season at AC Milan.\n\n3. Brazil's new Golden Boy\n\nEndrick this month became the youngest player since Pele to score in three consecutive matches for Brazil. But the 17-year-old is no certainty to start for the Selecao at the Copa America.\n\nHead coach Dorival Junior has promised not to ask too much of Endrick during the Copa America as the attacker vies for a place in the starting lineup alongside Vinicius Junior, Rodrygo, Raphinha, Savinho and Gabriel Martinelli.\n\n\"I have always been in favor of giving chances to young players but I just ask for a little patience with the boy so that things can happen naturally,\" Dorival told reporters earlier this month.\n\n4: Uruguay: The Bielsa effect\n\nUpon his appointment as Uruguay's manager in May last year, Marcelo Bielsa said his role would involve daring the Celeste's players to dream. The team's impressive sequence of results under the Argentine would suggest he is succeeding.\n\nThe Celeste have won seven, drawn three and lost two matches under Bielsa's stewardship, a run that has included World Cup qualifying victories over Brazil and Argentina.\n\nBielsa's 26-man Copa America list includes a balanced mix of youth and experience while boasting an array of world-class talent such as Real Madrid midfielder Federico Valverde, Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo, Atletico Madrid defender Jose Gimenez and Liverpool forward Darwin Nunez.\n\nVeteran marksman Luis Suarez will likely be an option off the bench, despite his prolific recent scoring form for Inter Miami. Suarez's long-time national team strike partner Edinson Cavani is not a part of the Celeste squad after announcing his retirement from international football in May.\n\n5. Colombia's formidable form\n\nColombia will deservedly enter the Copa America as one of the tournament favorites. The Cafeteros are unbeaten in 20 matches since Argentine Nestor Lorenzo replaced Reinaldo Rueda as manager in June 2022.\n\nThe sequence has included victories over Germany, Spain, Brazil, Mexico and the United States over the past year.\n\nColombia's strength is a stable defense - led by the center-back pairing of Jhon Lucumi and Carlos Cuesta - and an attack spearheaded by Liverpool winger Luis Diaz.\n\nPerhaps one weak spot is the middle of the park. James Rodriguez and Jhon Arias are the central pieces of a midfield that could lack depth, particularly if injuries strike.\n\n6. Gareca's Copa America record\n\nChile boss Ricardo Gareca, has a Midas touch in the Copa America, having guided Peru to second and third places in the previous two editions.\n\nThe 66-year-old Argentine, who was appointed Chile manager in January, has shown that he is not afraid to make tough decisions as he oversees a generational overhaul of La Roja's squad.\n\nAmong those missing from Chile's current playing group are Arturo Vidal and Gary Medel, integral members of the side that won back-to-back Copa America titles in 2015 and 2016.\n\nOne veteran who has remained in Gareca's plans is Eduardo Vargas, who was the Copa America's leading scorer in both 2015 and 2016, with four and six goals, respectively.\n\nThe 34-year-old Atletico Mineiro forward has 14 Copa America goals, three shy of the record that is jointly held by Argentine midfielder Norberto Mendez and Brazil playmaker Zizinho.\n\n7. The last dance?\n\nWhile Lionel Messi has not yet entertained the idea of retirement - at least publicly - this will almost certainly be his last Copa America.\n\nArgentina's talismanic captain will turn 37 during the tournament's group stage and he will be 41 when the next edition comes around.\n\nOne player who has already made a decision about his future is Messi's long-time national teammate and close friend, Angel Di Maria.\n\nThe 36-year-old has confirmed that he will end his 16-year international career after the Copa America.\n\nThe Benfica winger has been capped 140 times for his country and, with one World Cup trophy and a Copa America triumph to his name, he is already guaranteed legend status for the Albiceleste. Who would deny him one last shot at glory?\n\n8. Venezuela's high hopes\n\nVenezuela have never progressed beyond the quarterfinals of the continental tournament, having reached the last eight in 2011 and 2016.\n\nBut the Vinotinto have good reason to believe this could be their best ever Copa America campaign.\n\nSince Fernando Batista replaced Jose Pekerman as head coach in March 2023, Venezuela have played 12 matches, winning five, drawing five and losing just two.\n\nThe encouraging run of results has included victories over Chile and Paraguay and a draw against Brazil in 2026 World Cup qualifiers.", "source": {"uri": "europesun.com", {"uri": "8184407560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:43:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:43:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:42:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/messi-takes-center-stage-again-232958138.html", "title": "Messi takes center stage again for Copa America", "body": "World champions Argentina get an expanded Copa America under way on Thursday with Lionel Messi looking to add a second continental title in what is almost certainly his final appearance in the tournament.\n\nThe 108-year-old competition is being held in the United States with the host nation among six teams from the CONCACAF region joining the 10 South American nations looking for a place in the July 14 final in Miami.\n\nWhile FIFA will be looking closely at the organization of the event, two years out from the World Cup which will be co-hosted by the USA, Canada and Mexico, the tournament's rich history and prestige means it is much, much more than a 'trial event'.\n\nArgentina have won the Copa 15 times but only once, in 2021, during the Messi era and coach Lionel Scaloni has stuck largely with his World Cup-winning squad, with veterans Angel Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi likely taking their final bow in a major tournament.\n\nWhether this is Messi's goodbye to elite international football remains to be seen - the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner, now playing in Major League Soccer with Inter Miami, will turn 37 four days after Thursday's opener in Atlanta against Canada and has yet to decide whether he will try to play in a record sixth World Cup.\n\n\"It's great to have records and continue to achieve things but I won't take part in a World Cup just to say I've done six,\" Messi told ESPN last week.\n\n\"If I feel good and everything is in place for me to be there, fine, but I won't go just to go. It's very difficult to imagine what can happen because it's still two years away. I don't need to commit right now to whether or not I'll be there,\" he added.\n\nWhat is certain is that Messi, who has managed his workload to try to be in peak condition for the tournament, would relish the chance to win a third straight major tournament with his country after so many years of frustration with his national team.\n\n- Tough opposition -\n\nAfter facing Canada, Argentina take on Chile in New Jersey before finishing their group A action against Peru in Miami but they know that tough opposition awaits in the knock-out stage with rivals Brazil and Uruguay the two expected challengers for the title.\n\nBrazil have struggled in CONMEBOL qualifiers for the 2026 World Cup having won just two of their opening six games and they currently sit in sixth place in the standings having lost to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina.\n\nUruguay, also 15-times winners, have impressed under their 68-year-old Argentina coach Marcelo Bielsa, who has brought his trademark high-energy style to the team and raised expectations with recent wins over Argentina and Brazil.\n\nLiverpool forward Darwin Nunez will lead the line although Bielsa has the option of introducing veteran Luis Suarez from the bench.\n\nColombia head into the tournament without a loss in over two years and with Liverpool's livewire winger Luis Diaz a constant threat and James Rodriguez enjoying a late career revival, Nestor Lorenzo's team can't be discounted.\n\nThe USA will hope that they can generate some sorely needed excitement after losing their way since a creditable run to the last-16 at the World Cup.\n\nCoach Gregg Berhalter is under some pressure to show he can get his team, which relies on the smart wing play of Christian Pulisic, to compete with teams from outside of CONCACAF.\n\nMexico have guested frequently in the Copa in the past and reached the final in 1993 and 2001, but they look well below their usual level although they can, as always, count on huge support in the USA.\n\nThis is the second time the Copa America is being held in the USA, after the Centenary tournament in 2016, and while that is a break with tradition the presence of significant immigrant But that does not make us believe that we are going to win this Copa America by walking,\" Messi said.\n\nRanked number one in the FIFA world rankings, Argentina will face 49th-ranked Canada.\n\nWith newly appointed American coach Jesse Marsch, Canada are using the tournament as preparation for the 2026 World Cup which they will co-host with the U.S. and Mexico.\n\nCanada's Copa America squad features only two players over age 30 -- goalkeeper Maxime Crepeau (30) and midfielder Jonathan Osorio (32) -- and 15 are aged 25 or younger.\n\n\"I think it's been good for this new group. It's kind of a new era and guys are responding really well,\" Osorio said.\n\nThe youthfulness contrasts with Messi, who turns 37 on Monday and has shown no signs of slowing down, with 12 goals in 12 matches for Inter Miami in the MLS this season.\n\nCanada's next match is against Peru on Tuesday, the same day Argentina face Chile. Copa America tournament affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and relocated to Brazil.\n\nArgentina defeated Brazil 1-0 at Maracana Stadium in Rio de Janeiro, winning its first major title since 1993.\n\nWhen the match triumphantly ended, a crying Messi knelt and placed his hands over his face.\n\nHe was then joyfully tossed into the air by his adoring teammates.\n\n\"We dreamed of getting undisputed leader of Argentina.\n\nBut late heartbreak, bad luck and poor timing had seen Messi's home country team lose, lose and lose again on huge stages.\n\nThe 2007 Copa final went to Brazil {"uri": "2024-06-395796793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:08:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:08:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/20/sport/copa-america-2024-preview-lionel-messi-argentina-spt-intl/index.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024: Lionel Messi's final 'Last Dance' with Argentina?", "body": "For just the second time in the tournament's 108-year history, the Copa Am\u00e9rica will be played outside of South America.\n\nAs it did in 2016 for the special centenary, the United States will host this year's expanded edition that will feature 16 teams rather than the customary 12 and will be something of a dress rehearsal for the 2026 World Cup, which will be hosted in the US, Mexico and Canada.\n\nTaking part will be the 10 CONMEBOL nations as usual, plus the US, Mexico, Jamaica and Panama, which all qualified as semifinalists of the CONCACAF Nations League.\n\nAdditionally, Costa Rica and Canada also qualified via the playoffs contested between the losing Nations League quarterfinalists.\n\nThis year's tournament runs from June 20 to July 14.\n\nThe favorite\n\nUnsurprisingly, Lionel Messi's Argentina is the favorite to lift the trophy for a record-breaking 16th time.\n\nThree years ago, Messi helped the Albiceleste to glory at the Covid-delayed 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica, beating host Brazil in the final, his first major trophy with the national team and the country's first in 28 years.\n\nThat victory lifted the weight of expectation off his shoulders and more than likely acted as a catalyst for Argentina's World Cup victory in Qatar 18 months later, with Messi finally getting his hands on the one trophy he had craved most.\n\nPreviously tormented by his failures with Argentina, even retiring temporarily from international football after a second straight Copa Am\u00e9rica final defeat to Chile in 2016, Messi told Argentine outlet Infobae recently that he's now \"achieved everything.\"\n\nThere is the real possibility that the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica will be the last major international tournament Messi plays. After previously stating that the 2022 World Cup would be his last, Messi told Star+ in December that \"time will tell.\"\n\n\"As long as I feel I am well and that I am able to help, I will do it,\" Messi, who will turn 37 during the Copa Am\u00e9rica, said. \"Today, all I think about is to get well to the Copa Am\u00e9rica and play it. Fight for it again, as we always do, try to be the champions.\n\n\u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda is retiring after the tournament.\n\nCatherine Ivill/Getty Images\n\n\"If we do well at Copa Am\u00e9rica and I can keep playing, maybe it happens.\"\n\nBut Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni, who has overseen just four defeats in the team's last 50 games, had a message for Messi fans: Don't worry about the future, just enjoy the now.\n\n\"We Argentines are too melancholic and we are already thinking about the day when he is gone while he's still playing,\" Scaloni said last week. \"So let's enjoy him and we'll see what happens tomorrow. I think the present is so important for the whole world - not only for Argentina - because, in the end, Leo plays for everyone who likes football.\"\n\nOne player who will definitely be making his last tournament appearance for Argentina is \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda.\n\nThe 36-year-old has made 140 appearances for the national team and enjoys legendary status back home thanks to his winner in the final of the 2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica and a goal in the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nDi Mar\u00eda also won the U20 World Cup in 2007 and an Olympic gold medal at Beijing 2008.\n\nThe best of the rest\n\nBrazil\n\nPreviously thought of as one of, if not the greatest football nation on earth, Brazil currently finds itself navigating a complicated transitional period.\n\nThe squad for the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica is largely inexperienced, with 15 players on less than 10 caps for their country. Only one player, West Ham's Lucas Paquet\u00e1, has reached 10 goals for Brazil, making the omissions of Casemiro and Richarlison all the more surprising.\n\nThe Sele\u00e7\u00e3o is still reeling from the absence of star man Neymar Jr., who ruptured his ACL playing for the national team in October. Brazil's all-time record goalscorer and a player with the ability to change a game in an instant, Neymar will be sorely missed for his contributions on the pitch, but also his leadership and status as an icon in an inexperienced dressing room.\n\nVin\u00edcius Jr. has been one of the best players in the world this season.\n\nCatherine Ivill/Getty Images\n\nBrazil recently suffered back-to-back World Cup qualifier set-backs for the first time in its history, before going on to lose a third in a row. That third defeat - a 1-0 loss to Argentina at the Maracan\u00e3 - was historic, too, marking the first time Brazil had ever lost a home World Cup qualifier.\n\nInterim coach Fernando Diniz was sacked in January, less than halfway through his one-year deal, and replaced by journeyman manager Dorival J\u00fanior, who has so far overseen narrow wins against England and Mexico and draws against the USA and Spain.\n\nBut despite the team's recent struggles, the pressure and expectation will still be high back home - in particular with Vin\u00edcius Jr. leading the attack.\n\nThe Real Madrid forward has enjoyed a sensational season for Los Blancos, helping the team to a La Liga and Champions League double and making himself the favorite to win the Ballon d'Or.\n\nUruguay\n\nPerennial overachiever Uruguay once again goes into a Copa Am\u00e9rica among the favorites to win the title.\n\nThe nation of just 3.5 million people holds the joint record alongside Argentina for most Copa Am\u00e9rica titles won with 15.\n\nUnder new manager Marcelo Bielsa, who took charge in May 2023, a new, youthful Uruguay has made a tremendous start to World Cup qualifying, winning four of its six matches so far - including 2-0 wins over Brazil and Argentina - to sit second in the standings.\n\nMarcelo Bielsa has made a great start as Uruguay manager.\n\nAnder Gillenea/AFP/Getty Images\n\nWhile Bielsa has called up many inexperienced and uncapped players during his tenure so far to better implement his high intensity press, national team icon Luis Su\u00e1rez made the cut and will be supported by a talented cast that includes Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez, Ronald Ara\u00fajo and Federico Valverde.\n\nThe host\n\nThe USA enters the Copa Am\u00e9rica off the back of winning a third straight Nations League title, beating bitter rival Mexico 2-0 in the final less than two months ago.\n\nHowever, preparations for the tournament got off to the worst possible start with a 5-1 hammering at the hands of Colombia in Washington.\n\nAfter the defeat, goalkeeper Matt Turner said the team needed to \"bounce back in a big way,\" and a much-improved performance followed in a morale-boosting 1-1 draw against Brazil.\n\nDespite boasting several talented players, including Tim Weah, Christian Pulisic, Yunus Musah and Folarin Balogun, serious questions remain about whether the US men can consistently compete against teams outside of the weaker CONCACAF bubble.\n\nThe US won a third straight CONCACAF Nations League title.\n\nRon Jenkins/Getty Images\n\nFortunately for the US, the group draw has been kind. First up is a weak Bolivia side which has endured an abysmal start to World Cup qualifying, losing five of its first six matches, before a clash against familiar CONCACAF opponent Panama.\n\nThe sternest test will come last against Uruguay, but Gregg Berhalter's side should have enough quality to at least advance to the knockout stages. Anything less could be a disaster as the team attempts to drum up support across the country ahead of a home World Cup.\n\nDark Horses\n\nChile\n\nOnly a couple of months ago, you will likely have been hard pressed to find a Chile fan optimistic enough to predict that the team would make it past the group stages.\n\nThe failure to qualify for back-to-back World Cups in 2018 and 2022 has been a bitter pill to swallow for everyone involved after the country's 'Golden Generation' won successive Copa Am\u00e9ricas in 2015 and 2016 and reached the final of the 2017 Confederations Cup.\n\nSince Juan Antonio Pizzi was sacked as manager after the team missed out on Russia 2018, three successive coaches failed to get a tune out of the team - then Ricardo Gareca was hired.\n\nChile is finding form at the right time.\n\nMarcelo Hernandez/Getty Images\n\nGareca, who impressively took Peru to the 2018 World Cup and the final of the 2019 Copa Am\u00e9rica, has had an immediate impact on the team since taking over in January, leading La Roja to comprehensive 3-0 wins over Paraguay and Albania and pushing France close in a 3-2 defeat in Marseille.\n\nBig names such as Alexis S\u00e1nchez and Claudio Bravo remain in the squad, but there is no place for Arturo Vidal or Gary Medel.\n\nIt might be a bit much to say expectations are now high, but fans are finally excited about watching La Roja playing again.\n\nColombia\n\nColombia arrives in the US as arguably the most in-form team in the tournament, if not the world.\n\nLos Cafeteros are currently on a 23-game unbeaten run that includes wins in their last eight matches. With three wins and three draws so far in World Cup qualifying, the team has soared to third place in the standings to put the failure of reaching Qatar 2022 behind it.\n\nColombia is on a long unbeaten run.\n\nGonzalo Arroyo Moreno/Getty Images\n\nLiverpool's Luis D\u00edaz will be Colombia's main man at the Copa Am\u00e9rica, supported by well-known veterans such as James Rodriguez, David Ospina and Yerry Mina.\n\nThe main issue for Colombia is its brutal potential route to the final, during which it will likely have to face Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", Record of host nations for previous tournaments and how many have won", "body": "The USA is all set to welcome the top national sides from CONCACAF and CONMEBOL for this summer's Copa America tournament.\n\nAs part of their build up to hosting the 2026 FIFA World Cup, alongside Canada and Mexico, the USA will host games from coast to coast, with fixtures on the schedule in New Jersey, Florida, Texas and California.\n\nThe pressure of being a host nation can have a galvanizing impact on both the team and the nation, as seen in previous Copa America tournaments and the FIFA World Cup.\n\nGregg Berhalter will be hoping to use the home crowd as a huge motivator this summer, with the USA looking to build on their semifinal spot in 2016.\n\nMORE: Copa America full bracket, schedule and latest results from USA | Copa America Stadiums: Where are games being played in USA?\n\nThe short answer is yes. The USA hosted the 2016 Copa America, as the first non-CONMEBOL nation to do so, and 2024 will be their second hosting of the tournament.\n\nThe tournament in 2024 will be the fifth time the USA has been invited to or qualified for the Copa America since their first appearance in 1993. They have reached the semifinals twice, in 1995 and 2016.\n\nThe USA reached the semifinals as hosts back in 2016, as they became the 11th country to host the tournament. Argentina has hosted the Copa America on the most occasions, with nine, and La Albiceleste are the joint most successful side in the competition's history, with 15 titles, alongside Uruguay.\n\nStretching back to the first tournament in 1916, the Copa America has been won by the host nation on 22 occasions, with the most recent being Brazil in 2019.\n\nBelow is the full details on host nations who have emerged victorious in the Copa America.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil feature an attack headed by Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The US, Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nBack in the USA\n\nEcuador were picked to host the tournament under the rotation of Conmebol, the South American governing body, but declined. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nWorld Cup test?\n\nIn 2016, Conmebol partnered with the US Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. {"uri": "8182284190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "17:12:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T17:12:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T17:11:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/copa-america-preview-c2ee7698dab6fae3b13664a930994252", "title": "Lionel Messi and Argentina will try for a 3rd straight major title in Copa America", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain's feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.\n\nComing off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\n\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nHe has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina's national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nA look at the tournament:\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.\n\nCONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup -- the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada -- and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.\n\nChristian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\n\n\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we'll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It's a special time for this sport in America.\"\n\nIn 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.\n\nAt MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\n\n\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... Not only can we track the drone, but more importantly, we can track where the operator is.\"", "source": {"uri": "apnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AP NEWS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": In this article, we will tell you how you can watch and keep up to date with the 2024 Copa America.\n\nThe United States will host the 2024 Copa America having only been involved in the tournament four times previously.\n\n14 different stadiums will be used across the entire country, meaning local kick-off times will also be varied due to the different time zones in the US.\n\nThe final will be played at the Hard Rock Stadium in Florida, home of the Miami Dolphins, while the semi-finals will take place in New Jersey and North Carolina.\n\nChampions Argentina will kick off the tournament against Group A opponents Canada in the early hours of Friday morning for UK viewers.\n\nFollowing that, a minimum of two group games a day will be played until 3 July, before the quarter-finals take place on 5, 6 and 7 July.\n\nA few days break will come after the first round of knockouts before the semi-finals on 10 and 11 July, before the grand final in Miami on 15 July.\n\nArgentina are on an incredible run in major competitions, having won the last two they have competed in.\n\nMessi has only got so many years left on the international stage but his hunger to win another title with his country will be as fierce as ever.\n\nLa Albiceleste have not lost a friendly game since 2019 and have only suffered defeat in all competitions once since the Saudi Arabia loss in the World Cup two years ago.\n\nThey rounded off their warm-up fixtures with a win over Guatemala and enter the tournament as strong favourites.\n\nBrazil - 2021 finalists and nine-time winners of the Copa America - are going to be a huge threat to Argentina. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil feature an attack headed by Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" US coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. They will also face Peru and Chile in Group A.\n\n\"Today, we can say that we are the best because we are the world champions. But that does not make us believe that we are going to win this Copa Am\u00e9rica by walking,\" Messi said.\n\n\"It is going to be very level, all the teams are complicated. Ecuador has a generation of very good youngsters, who know well what they want, they are intense with the ball, they are clear about what they do and they are physically strong. And like them, you also have Colombia, Uruguay, not to mention Brazil. That's why I say it will be even and our team is aware that we are going to have to continue doing the same and more to win again.\"\n\nArgentina beat Brazil 1-0 at the Maracana stadium to win the Copa Am\u00e9rica three years ago, the country's first major title in 28 years.\n\nThe Albiceleste have since been in spectacular form, lifting the 2022 World Cup and winning five of their six World Cup qualifiers.\n\nMeanwhile, Argentina's longtime rivals Brazil go into the Copa Am\u00e9rica under new coach Dorival Junior but without their men's all-time leading scorer Neymar, who is injured.\n\nThey lost on penalties to Croatia in the quarterfinals of the World Cup and have won just two of their World Cup qualifiers.\n\n\"It [Neymar's absence] is a shame, but they have a million players,\" Messi said. \"Brazil always has plenty of players because they are continually different. They have a very strong, very competitive team. Brazil is like Argentina: it's a candidate and wants to win the Copa Am\u00e9rica.\"\n\nMessi, 36, said he plans to enjoy the Copa Am\u00e9rica that will be staged in the United States and is not thinking about his future.\n\n\"I value all those moments [with the squad] very much because I know that there is less and less time left until everything is over and that in some way I am going to miss all of that,\" the Inter Miami forward said. \"The truth is that it was very difficult for me at first to take the step and leave European football to come here [United States], but once I was here I adapted very quickly and live day to day and think in the moment. Today I feel that I am still fine, that I can continue competing, I continue training, I continue taking care of myself just as I always did, or even more, and I live for the moments. For now I don't think about the future.\"\n\nMessi's Inter Miami coach Gerardo \"Tata\" Martino does not know if the Copa Am\u00e9rica will be the player's last for Argentina.\n\n\"You see Messi play and you don't sense the end is near, even though perhaps the calendar indicates otherwise,\" Martino said. \"But I think what we have is more of an expression of wish than an analysis for something we really know. I don't know and I hope he enjoys it as he has been enjoying it until now, and then he will decide.\"\n\nMartino, who is Argentinian, said he believes his country has a great chance of lifting the Copa but added there are other teams that are hungry and capable.\n\n\"Unlike other Copa Am\u00e9ricas, there are several teams besides Argentina and Brazil that are very good, that have a lot of potential and are willing to fight for it,\" Martino said. \"It seems to me that it will be a very attractive competition. {"uri": "8182336211", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "17:55:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T17:55:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T17:54:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.tsn.ca/soccer/lionel-messi-and-argentina-will-try-for-a-3rd-straight-major-title-in-copa-america-1.2135850", "title": "Lionel Messi and Argentina will try for a 3rd straight major title in Copa America | TSN", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Lionel Messi and Argentina will try to match Spain's feat of three consecutive major titles when the Copa America kicks off Thursday night.\n\nComing off championships in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, Messi will be four days shy of his 37th birthday when the Albiceleste take the field against Canada at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\nWatch the opening game and every match of the tournament LIVE on TSN, TSN.ca and the TSN App.\n\n\"I want to enjoy a couple of more matches being a world champion,\" Messi said after Argentina beat France on penalty kicks to win the 2022 World Cup final.\n\nHe has 10 goals in 10 international appearances since, raising his total to 108 in 182 games for Argentina's national team. He is either tied for second with Ali Daei or one behind, depending on whether a disputed goal by the Iranian is counted, trailing only Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo at 128.\n\n\"It is not easy to compete again after winning it all,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said.\n\nArgentina and Uruguay are tied with 15 Copa titles each, followed by Brazil with nine. No other nation has won more than two.\n\nBrazil features an attack headed by Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior and Rodrygo, just off a Champions League title with Real Madrid, and Raphinha. The emerging star is 17-year-old Endrick, who joins Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"If you look at every position in their proposed starting 11, it's probably one of the world's best players,\" U.S. coach Gregg Berhalter said.\n\nSpain is the only nation to win three consecutive major titles: the European Championship in 2008 and 2012 around the 2010 World Cup.\n\nThere will be 16 teams, just as in 2016. The U.S., Mexico, Canada, Costa Rica, Panama and Jamaica join the 10 South American nations after qualifying from North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nBack in the USA\n\nEcuador was to host the tournament under the rotation of CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, but declined. The tournament was then moved to the U.S., which also hosted the special centennial Copa America in 2016 as Chile won on penalty kicks over Argentina at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.\n\nEleven NFL stadiums are being used, including eight of the 11 U.S. venues for the 2026 World Cup, plus three smaller MLS homes. The final will be at Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14, starting five hours after the European Championship final in Berlin.\n\nCONMEBOL says more than 1 million tickets have been sold for the 32 matches. The 2016 tournament drew just under 1.5 million, and the 2019 tournament in Brazil about 850,000. The 2021 Copa was played mostly without fans because of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nU.S. team\n\nThis will be the biggest test for the U.S. team before the World Cup -- the Americans get an automatic berth as co-host along with Mexico and Canada -- and most Europe-based players are expected to skip next year's CONCACAF Gold Cup.\n\nChristian Pulisic, Tyler Adams and Weston McKennie are the core of a team that returns 18 players from the 2022 World Cup roster.\n\n\"A World Cup on home soil is the biggest thing that you know we'll probably do in our career,\" Pulisic said. \"It's a special time for this sport in America.\"\n\nWorld Cup test?\n\nIn 2016, CONMEBOL partnered with the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was in charge of most of the logistics. This time, CONMEBOL is co-organizing the tournament with CONCACAF, the governing body of North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnlike during the World Cup, the organizers have only short-term access to venues. At Hard Rock, a concert is scheduled for July 6, between the last group stage game and the final, and a new grass surface will be installed.\n\nAt MetLife Stadium, where a semifinal will be played July 9, staff will look at it as a preview for the World Cup final on July 19, 2026. The stadium has a camera system designed by Arecont Vision and managed by Genetec Security Center that was installed before the 2014 Super Bowl and a new system by Axis Communications is being put in place this summer in the seating bowl with 80 8K, 41-megapixel cameras.\n\n\"We can see every seat all the time. I think it serves as a good deterrent,\" said Daniel DeLorenzi, vice president of security and safety services. \"We have three drone detection systems. ... Schedule, dates, times, roster and how to watch USMNT matches", "body": "The U.S. Men's National Team kicks off their 2024 Copa America adventure on June 23 against Bolivia.\n\nThe USMNT begins their journey in the Lone Star State, at the glimmering AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas. This tournament is of huge importance to coach Gregg Berhalter and his staff because it's one of the last times he will get to see his players in action in a competitive tournament ahead of the 2026 World Cup, which the USA is co-hosting.\n\nWith mostly friendly matches and no World Cup qualifiers, this is a crucial test for the USMNT to see how they match up with the best from the Western Hemisphere and how far they still have to go.\n\nThe USMNT last played in the Copa America when it was last in the U.S., in 2016 to celebrate Copa America's centenary. The U.S. finished in fourth place, beating Ecuador in the quarterfinals after winning Group A, but being crushed by Argentina in the semifinals. The U.S. then lost the third-place match to Colombia.\n\nPrior to that, the U.S. had three other Copa America appearances, the best of which was a legendary fourth place finish in Uruguay with mostly amateur players in 1995, a year before MLS came into being and a year after the rag-tag USMNT bunch got out of their group at the 1994 World Cup on home soil.\n\nMORE: Where to watch Copa America 2024: Full broadcast schedule for all matches on FOX and Fubo\n\nThe Sporting News looks at the key details ahead of this game, including how to watch it across the world, kickoff times and the latest lineup news.\n\nThe USA begin their Copa America run against Bolivia on Sunday, June 23 at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas. Kickoff is at 5:00 p.m. local time.\n\nFans from across the region will be tuning in to watch the USMNT's Copa America opener. Here's how that kickoff time translates across the United States and the rest of the world:\n\nHere's how to watch this Copa America 2024 match across selected areas of the world's major regions:\n\nUSA: Copa America 2024 matches will be broadcast in English on Fox Sports with streaming options available on Fubo where new users can sign up to a FREE trial. Of the 27-man squad that took part in a pre-tournament training camp, only midfielder Timothy Tillman was cut. Josh Sargent, a pre-tournament injury worry, was included for the time being.\n\nU.S. Soccer has until Saturday at 6:00 p.m. ET to make any last minute injury replacements.\n\nAges, caps are correct as of June 17, 2024 and the start of Copa America.\n\nThe USMNT has competed at Copa America on four previous occasions, finishing in fourth place twice. {"uri": "2024-06-394031648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:43:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:43:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:31:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240618-messi-takes-center-stage-again-for-copa-america", "title": "Messi takes center stage again for Copa America", "body": "Atlanta (AFP) - World champions Argentina get an expanded Copa America under way on Thursday with Lionel Messi looking to add a second continental title in what is almost certainly his final appearance in the tournament.\n\nThe 108-year-old competition is being held in the United States with the host nation among six teams from the CONCACAF region joining the 10 South American nations looking for a place in the July 14 final in Miami.\n\nWhile FIFA will be looking closely at the organization of the event, two years out from the World Cup which will be co-hosted by the USA, Canada and Mexico, the tournament's rich history and prestige means it is much, much more than a 'trial event'.\n\nArgentina have won the Copa 15 times but only once, in 2021, during the Messi era and coach Lionel Scaloni has stuck largely with his World Cup-winning squad, with veterans Angel Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi likely taking their final bow in a major tournament.\n\nWhether this is Messi's goodbye to elite international football remains to be seen - the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner, now playing in Major League Soccer with Inter Miami, will turn 37 four days after Thursday's opener in Atlanta against Canada and has yet to decide whether he will try to play in a record sixth World Cup.\n\n\"It's great to have records and continue to achieve things but I won't take part in a World Cup just to say I've done six,\" Messi told ESPN last week.\n\n\"If I feel good and everything is in place for me to be there, fine, but I won't go just to go. It's very difficult to imagine what can happen because it's still two years away. I don't need to commit right now to whether or not I'll be there,\" he added.\n\nWhat is certain is that Messi, who has managed his workload to try to be in peak condition for the tournament, would relish the chance to win a third straight major tournament with his country after so many years of frustration with his national team.\n\nTough opposition\n\nAfter facing Canada, Argentina take on Chile in New Jersey before finishing their group A action against Peru in Miami but they know that tough opposition awaits in the knock-out stage with rivals Brazil and Uruguay the two expected challengers for the title.\n\nBrazil have struggled in CONMEBOL qualifiers for the 2026 World Cup having won just two of their opening six games and they currently sit in sixth place in the standings having lost to Uruguay, Colombia and Argentina.\n\nThere are several familiar names missing from Dorival Junior's Brazil squad with Casemiro, Gabriel Jesus and Thiago Silva left out while Richarlison and Neymar are both missing due to injury.\n\nThe pressure will be on the Real Madrid attacking pair of Vinicius Junior and Rodrygo to translate their club form into success for the Selecao while there is much excitement around the senior tournament debut of 17-year-old talent Endrick, who is set to join Real next month from Palmeiras.\n\nUruguay, also 15-times winners, have impressed under their 68-year-old Argentina coach Marcelo Bielsa, who has brought his trademark high-energy style to the team and raised expectations with recent wins over Argentina and Brazil.\n\nLiverpool forward Darwin Nunez will lead the line although Bielsa has the option of introducing veteran Luis Suarez from the bench.\n\nColombia head into the tournament without a loss in over two years and with Liverpool's livewire winger Luis Diaz a constant threat and James Rodriguez enjoying a late career revival, Nestor Lorenzo's team can't be discounted.\n\nThe USA will hope that they can generate some sorely needed excitement after losing their way since a creditable run to the last-16 at the World Cup.\n\nCoach Gregg Berhalter is under some pressure to show he can get his team, which relies on the smart wing play of Christian Pulisic, to compete with teams from outside of CONCACAF.\n\nMexico have guested frequently in the Copa in the past and reached the final in 1993 and 2001, but they look well below their usual level although they can, as always, count on huge support in the USA.\n\nThis is the second time the Copa America is being held in the USA, after the Centenary tournament in 2016, and while that is a break with tradition the presence of significant immigrant communities from all the competing nations, should ensure big crowds at the mostly NFL stadiums being used.", {"uri": "8182340161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "18:00:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T18:00:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T17:59:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/copa-america-kicks-off-thursday-175251857.html", "title": "Copa America kicks off Thursday. Here's a group-by-group preview and predictions", "body": "Copa America kicks off Thursday night in Atlanta, with Inter Miami icon Lionel Messi and his defending champion Argentina team facing Canada at Mercedes Benz Stadium.\n\nLa Albiceleste (sky blue and white) are not only the reigning Copa champions, but also the World Cup champions, so they are the team to beat as the month-long tournament gets underway. Other teams expected to advance include Uruguay, Colombia, Brazil, Mexico and the host United States.\n\nHow it Works: The 16-team field is comprised of 10 teams from South America and six from North and Central America and the Caribbean. The tournament begins with four groups of four teams. During the group phase, teams earn three points for a win, one for a tie, and zero for a loss. After each team has played its group opponents once, the top two will advance.\n\nHere's a look at the groups, and predictions of which teams will move on to the knockout stage...\n\nGROUP A: Argentina, Peru, Chile, Canada\n\nDefending champion Argentina is the heavy favorite to raise the trophy again. Inter Miami star Messi, the eight-time Ballon d'Or winner, led La Albiceleste to the 2022 World Cup title and since their 2-1 loss to Saudi Arabia in the opening game of that World Cup, Argentina has won 17 of its past 18 matches. Their only loss was 2-0 to Uruguay in a World Cup qualifier.\n\nMessi is joined by a loaded roster that includes Julian Alvarez (Manchester City), Lautaro Martinez (Inter Milan), Rodrigo De Paul (Atletico de Madrid), Alexis Mac Allister (Liverpool), Enzo Fernandez (Chelsea), Cristian Romero and Lisandro Martinez.\n\nChile is expected to be the second-strongest team with veteran Alexis Sanchez among the players to watch. Chile beat Argentina twice in 2015 and 2016 in penalty kicks in the Copa America final.\n\nCanada has a shot to pull off an upset or two under new American coach Jesse Marsch. Peru lost 2-0 to both Argentina and Chile in World Cup qualifying and will have a tough time getting through the group, but if Edison Flores scores goals, La Rojiblanca could pull a surprise.\n\nOnce upon a time, Mexico would have been a lock to win this group, but things are more unpredictable these days.\n\nEl Tri has played in 10 Copa Americas, finished runner-up twice and third three times. But the team has struggled in recent years and lost two Copa warmup matches last week, 4-0 to Uruguay and 3-2 to Brazil, after a 1-0 win against Bolivia. The Mexican team is in a rebuild under coach Jaime Lozano, who left out some of the old guard and called up several Under-23 players. They could still advance, but maybe not win the group.\n\nEcuador has never won the Copa, and its best finish in the past four decades was fourth place in 1993, but this year's team is good enough to finish atop Group B. Coach F\u00e9lix Sanchez Bas has a talented roster, including Piero Hincapie of Bayer Leverkusen, Moises Caicedo of Chelsea and veteran leader Enner Valencia.\n\nThe host USA is the headliner of the group and will have home-field advantage (although South American fans often outnumber the red, white and blue on U.S. soil). This U.S. team, led by captain Christian Pulisic, is arguably the most talented in the nation's history with nearly all its players based overseas. Pulisic and Yunus Musah play for AC Milan. Weston McKennie and Tim Weah play for Juventus. Matt Turner and Gio Reyna are teammates at Nottingham Forest. But the team had mixed results in Copa warmup matches, losing 5-1 to Colombia before rebounding with a 1-1 tie against Brazil.\n\nCo-favorite to advance is Uruguay, the 15-time South American champions, who are hungry to win for the first time since 2011. They have a good shot under the direction of Marcelo Bielsa and with Liverpool's Darwin Nunez leading the attack. Since last June, Uruguay has only lost two of 10 games under Bielsa and the team sits in second place in the CONMEBOL World Cup Qualifiers, three points behind Argentina. Inter Miami star Luis Suarez, 37, is on Uruguay's squad and eager to go far in what will likely be his last Copa.\n\nPanama and Bolivia would have to pull off shockers to survive this group. MLS duo Anibal Godoy and Adalberto 'Coco' Carrasquilla are two Panamanian players to watch. Panama has beaten the USA and made strides in recent years, but advancing will be tough. Bolivia's best player, Marcelo Martins Moreno, retired.\n\nBrazil is desperate to have a good showing after stumbling to sixth place in World Cup qualifying so far. Things are so bad that former star Ronaldinho slammed the team last week, posting on social media: \"That's it folks. l've had enough. This is a sad moment for those who love Brazilian soccer. It's getting hard to find the spirit to watch the games. This is perhaps one of the worst teams in recent years. It has no respectable leaders, only average players for the majority.\"\n\nThe pressure is on Brazil, which was eliminated from the 2022 World Cup by Croatia in the quarterfinals. The team has shown improvement in recent friendlies under new coach Dorival Junior, including wins over England and Mexico and a 1-1 tie against the USA last week.\n\nThe most in-form team in the group is Colombia, which is unbeaten in 23 games since 2022. Los Cafeteros, under coach Nestor Lorenzo, are unbeaten after their opening six group matches in the CONMEBOL World Cup qualifiers with wins over Venezuela, Brazil and Paraguay, the latter two of which are in their Copa group.\n\nParaguay has won just two of its past 11 matches and Costa Rica has won four of its most recent 14 international matches.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com",
