{"uri": "8187344156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:58:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com/stories/soccer/copa-america-oral-history-former-usmnt-players-recall-copas-past-it-was-wild", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica oral history: Former USMNT players recall tournaments past. 'It was wild'", "body": "The history of the U.S. men's national team dates back more than a century, and even with a 40-year drought between World Cup appearances mixed into that lore, the Americans have still participated in soccer's premier event 10 times.\n\nThe USMNT's history in the Copa Am\u00e9rica is shorter. All four of the program's appearances have come since 1993. Their fifth arrives in just a few days, as coach Gregg Berhalter's squad hosts the best teams in the Western Hemisphere in sport's longest running international tournament.\n\nTo help us prepare for USA 2024, FOX Sports spoke to six former U.S. players -- Berhalter, Alejandro Bedoya, Jonathan Bornstein, Brad Guzan, Tony Meola and Tab Ramos -- who were members of Copa Am\u00e9rica rosters past and kind enough to share their experiences.\n\nMuch like the current U.S. team, the Americans used the 1993 Copa Am\u00e9rica to help them prepare for a fast-approaching World Cup at home. Unlike this year, then-coach Bora Milutinovi\u0107 was missing a number of key players who had just competed in the U.S. Cup, a friendly tournament in which the U.S. stunned England 2-0. One week later, a different U.S. team made the country's Copa debut in a hard-fought 1-0 loss to Uruguay. Ramos was the captain.\n\nTab Ramos: It's hard to believe now, but our players looked at the U.S. Cup as the more important competition at the time. Some of the guys didn't really know much about Copa Am\u00e9rica. They didn't know the magnitude of it.\n\nTony Meola: I have family in Argentina, so I knew how big it was. I knew what it meant to Colombia or Brazil or Uruguay.\n\nRamos: In general, most of our guys treated it as just another tournament, an opportunity to showcase themselves. It was a little bit of a tryout. We still had college guys on that team.\n\nThe U.S. lost its second game to the host nation, ending any chance of advancing. But they were up 3-0 over Venezuela in the group finale before settling for a 3-3 tie.\n\nRamos: We're playing in South America, against South American teams, in games you have to win. We saw an intensity that we weren't used to seeing. Back then, Venezuela was the worst team in CONMEBOL, and yet they fought back to tie us. It was a real eye-opener.\n\nMeola: Bora's big thing was making sure we'd never be in awe of meeting a team at the World Cup for the first time, so he wanted to play everyone. It did kind of take away the mystique of playing against some of these teams. That helped quite a bit in 1994.\n\nRamos: I wish we had represented ourselves better, but in 1993 we were still getting our feet wet at the international level. The U.S. Cup was really our only major competition. We had big results, but they were friendlies. Teams didn't take us seriously until we knocked Colombia out of the 1994 World Cup. That was really our first legit win, the first time we earned a little bit of respect by winning a game that really mattered. But the summer of 1993 was a turning point. After that, we became a competitive national team worldwide.\n\nMeola: For me, and I think the guys in '95 will tell you the same thing: It's as close to being in a World Cup as it gets.\n\nThe U.S. returned to the Copa Am\u00e9rica as a battle-tested side. The Americans had reached the second round of the World Cup a year earlier before losing to eventual champ Brazil. They played with no fear, routing Argentina 3-0 in the group stage and advancing to the semifinals, where Brazil once again eliminated them with a 1-0 victory.\n\nRamos: The feeling was completely different in 1995. Now we knew the magnitude of Copa Am\u00e9rica. We wanted to have the best team we could have.\n\nGregg Berhalter: I had two caps coming into the tournament, so it wasn't like I was a main part of the team. I viewed it as an amazing experience for a young player. I looked up to a lot of the older guys who had starred at the World Cup the year before.\n\nTo see the intensity we brought and to compete the way we did, it was really special. We had a lot of confidence. I remember specifically the performance Alexi Lalas and Frank Klopas had against Argentina. It was a great group to learn from and just a fun ride -- that's the best way to describe it.\n\nRamos: By 1995, all of our players were playing on clubs somewhere overseas. We knew -- and I'm gonna say this with a straight face -- that we could beat anyone. We might have to get lucky, but we could beat anyone.\n\nBerhalter: Maradona came to watch the game before ours, and he sat down in the seat right in front of me. He saw our tracksuits, turned around and shook our hands. Within five minutes the entire stadium was chanting his name. It's one of the best experiences I ever had in soccer.\n\nTo go out and beat Argentina 3-0 is an amazing accomplishment. That's a marquee win in the program's history. The American spirit shined through in that tournament.\n\nThe U.S. returned to Copa for the third time as an invited guest. But most of the regulars didn't go after helping the Americans beat Mexico in the Concacaf Gold Cup final, which was played in Chicago three days before the 2007 Copa kicked off. Left back Jonathan Bornstein was one of the few players who competed in both events. The U.S. opened the tournament with a 4-1 loss to Argentina and a youngster named Lionel Messi, who had just turned 20.\n\nJonathan Bornstein: The Gold Cup roster was pretty much all European-based. But the European players needed to go back to before their seasons, so that Copa America squad was a majority of MLS guys.\n\nBrad Guzan: It was more or less a completely different group.\n\nBornstein: Everybody was aware of Messi, but there were a lot of very high quality players on Argentina: Carlos Tevez, Javier Mascherano. I can still remember the intensity with which they passed the ball. It was like nothing I'd ever seen. I remember a really hard driven ball into [Juan Rom\u00e1n] Riquelme, and he just cushions in front of him like it was like a soft pass. Just the speed and the pace at which they did things, it was another level. I was like, 'Damn, that's how I have to play.' It was a great learning experience for the entire team.\n\nIt was an experience off the field, too. Political relations between Venezuela and the U.S. had deteriorated significantly in the years before that edition of the Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nBornstein: We weren't very welcome. We always had to have security with us. For our safety, we couldn't leave our hotel compound. When we would drive from the hotel to the practice field, we'd have a helicopter overhead with soldiers holding machine guns leaning out the door. That's the thing I remember the most.\n\nGuzan: The helicopter was only 100 feet above us. We had a decoy bus, we had Humvees in front and behind, had to take different routes to training. The training pitch was surrounded by armed soldiers. It was wild.\n\nThe U.S. narrowly lost its next two games, to Paraguay and Colombia.\n\nBornstein: We might not have been playing in Europe at the time, but we were quality soccer players representing our country. I remember Bob [Bradley, the U.S. coach] mentioning, like, 'This is the team that was chosen, and this is the team that's got to get the job done.\" That was the mentality of the group, even if we didn't get the results we wanted. The last two games we were in. If a couple of bounces had gone our way, for sure we could've gotten points out of them.\"\n\nTo celebrate the 100th anniversary of the inaugural Copa Am\u00e9rica, CONMEBOL and Concacaf joined forces to organize an expanded 16-team event to be hosted in packed NFL Stadiums across the U.S.\n\nBedoya: It was special to play in that Copa Am\u00e9rica Centenario. I grew up in a Colombian household, and we always watched the Copa. Colombia won it in 2001, when the tournament was held there. My family was so happy. After the World Cup, it's the biggest trophy there is for South American teams.\n\nGuzan: It was exciting to be part of a Copa Am\u00e9rica again. Hosting it added another element to it.\n\nThe U.S. dropped its opener to Colombia, then reeled off victories against Costa Rica and Paraguay to top the group. That set up a quarterfinal with Ecuador in Seattle, which the home team won 2-1.\n\nGuzan: The pitch wasn't great. It was super heavy. That said, we were up for it. We knew we put ourselves in a perfect spot to get a big result, and we did. It was a fantastic day for U.S. Soccer.\n\nThe only downside? Bedoya and fellow midfielder Jermaine Jones were suspended for the semifinal against Messi's Argentina.\n\nBedoya: That's one of my biggest regrets. I wish me and Jermaine were available for that Argentina game, because we all know what happened.\n\nThe shorthanded U.S. lost 4-0. Messi opened the scoring early by beating Guzan with an inch-perfect free kick, and Argentina never looked back.\n\nGuzan: It's not every day you have someone who can get the ball up and over the wall and still have it move away from you into the top corner. You're trying to allow the wall to do its job and not cheat. Obviously, he scored. But I'm not sure we even touched the ball during the first 20 minutes of that game.\n\nThe defeat sent the Americans to the third place match, where they again faced -- and lost to -- Colombia.\n\nBedoya: It's not a final, but it's still a match you want to win. You want to finish as high as possible. I grew up cheering for the Colombian team. It's a special game for myself and my family. But I represent USA. I'm American. So yeah, I definitely wanted to win the third place game. Unfortunately, we fell short again. But overall, we had a good Copa Am\u00e9rica. I thought we played pretty well given the opponents we faced.", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Anyone can win any football match. Don't rule it out. Of course, it's a long shot. Argentina are an excellent side. They've been in great form since Qatar and they're the favourites for Copa America. It's going to be incredibly tough,\" Caldwell said on TSN Radio Thursday morning.\n\n\"I think for Canada, they've got to just play the best game possible for their 11. I think the start of the match is going to be very fast with lots of emotion and energy inside the stadium. Canada will have to manage that and just break this game up into little blocks. Get through the first 15 minutes and start to feel comfortable.\"\n\nThursday's match in Atlanta will be the first in a competitive fixture for Canada's new manager, Jesse Marsch. His side has been tasked with stopping an Argentina squad that has not lost since dropping their opening match of the World Cup to Saudi Arabia nearly two years ago.\n\nCaldwell believes Canada, who moved up one spot in FIFA's ranking to No. 48 ahead of Copa America, has a path to upsetting their heavily favoured opponents.\n\n\"I think Canada can score, I really do. In terms of attack, Canada can hurt Argentina. They're a little vulnerable down the sides. Just getting the chances in the right areas and actually being able to counter on them. I think Canada can score,\" Caldwell said. \"The best result for me is probably a 1-1 draw, but you never know. If Canada gets that goal with a little bit of luck and the goalkeeper plays great, you can come away with a victory.\"\n\nFans from around the world have descended on Atlanta to watch Argentina and their globally renowned superstar. Messi, who will be playing his seventh Copa, will be the focus for Canada as they attempt to pull off the monumental upset.\n\n\"To stop him takes a lot of plans. It's not one person's responsibility. It's the whole team being aware and concentrating on his possession the entire game,\" said Caldwell. \"He relies on his intelligence and game knowledge to inject energy and pace. That is the task ahead for Canada. To prevent him from getting to areas where he's unstoppable, to hone in on where he wants to be effective and do your absolute best to stop him.\n\n\"He'll still go to other positions and he can still be very effective with his playmaking but I think that's the lesser of two evils when it comes to Messi hurting you as an opposition team.\"\n\nDespite being heavy favourites to win the match, Argentina manager Lionel Scaloni says his team needs to be prepared for a motivated Canadian side.\n\n\"Canada is a very good team, they have important players and a new coach who has brought in new ideas,\" Scaloni said. \"They are a complicated opponent, but we are prepared to play our game.\"\n\nWith the world's eyes set on Mercedes Benz Stadium, Caldwell says much of the pressure will be on Argentina to set the tone in the opening match of the 48th Copa America.\n\n\"[Argentina] is a brilliant team. They're tough but they're also very skilled and talented. They don't expect anything. They fight for everything, they have a great spirit and determination under Lionel Scaloni,\" he said. \"It's going to be fascinating because the pressure is on them to go out and entertain these fans It's almost time to be permanently glued to your screens. The Copa America kicks off on Thursday with reigning champions Argentina taking on Canada, delivering a double dose of soccer to go with the Euros. I'm Pardeep Cattry with a midweek check-in as the summer of soccer kicks into high gear.\n\n\ud83d\udcfa Footy fix\n\nAll times U.S./Eastern\n\nWednesday, June 19\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euros: Germany vs. Hungary, 12 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f FS1\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euros: Scotland vs. Switzerland, 3 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f Fox\n\n\ud83c\uddfa\ud83c\uddf8 MLS: FC Cincinnati vs. Philadelphia Union, 7:45 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f FS1\n\n\ud83c\uddfa\ud83c\uddf8 NWSL: Angel City vs. Racing Louisville, 10 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f CBS Sports Network\n\nThursday, June 20\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euros: Slovenia vs. Serbia, 9 a.m. \u27a1\ufe0f FS1\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euros: Denmark vs. England, 12 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f FS1\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euros: Spain vs. Italy, 3 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f Fox\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Copa America: Argentina vs. Canada, 8 p.m. \u27a1\ufe0f FS1\n\nFriday, June 21\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euros: Slovakia vs. Ukraine, 9 a.m. \u27a1\ufe0f Vix, Fubo Sports\n\n\u26bd The Forward Line\ud83c\uddeb\ud83c\uddf7 Goals galore and a broken nose at the Euros\n\nMbappe set to mask up\n\nTwo days after France's 1-0 win over Austria on Monday in their opening match of the Euros, Kylian Mbappe's broken nose remains the main topic of conversation as Les Bleus sweat over his availability for the rest of the group stage.\n\nFrance's medical team and manager Didier Deschamps have spent much of the last couple of days offering updates on Mbappe's condition, and another is expected sometime on Wednesday. So far, the news is mixed -- he has not been ruled out of the whole tournament and does not immediately need surgery, but his availability for France's high-stakes Group D match against the Netherlands on Friday \"remains uncertain.\" Here's more from the medical team's initial statement on the World Cup winner's condition.\n\nFrance's medical team: \"Kylian Mbappe has suffered a broken nose. He is back in camp with the rest of the squad and will undergo treatment in the coming days without undergoing immediate surgery. A mask will be constructed in order to enable the French team's No. 10 to consider resuming competition after a period of treatment.\"\n\nPlaying without Mbappe in arguably their most competitive group stage match is far from ideal for France, especially since he created the chance that led to Maximilian Wober's own goal in the opening match. Deschamps is not without options, though. Olivier Giroud seems like his most obvious replacement even at the age of 37, but is still in strong form after a 17 goal, nine assist season for AC Milan. Antoine Griezmann and Ousmane Dembele, who both started on Monday, can also be counted on for goals -- Griezmann scored 24 goals for Atletico Madrid last season, while Dembele had 12 assists for Paris Saint-Germain.\n\nEnd-to-end action\n\nFrance's victory is in trend with the other favorites to win the tournament, most of whom won their opening matches. That includes Portugal, who began their Euros campaign with a come-from-behind win over Czechia courtesy of a stoppage time game-winner from Francisco Conceicao. Not all of the top-ranked teams fared well, though -- Belgium lost 1-0 to Slovakia despite taking 16 shots, marking the most lopsided victory in the competition's history based on FIFA rankings.\n\nIt was not the only historic moment in Germany this week, either. Romania collected their first win at the Euros in 24 years when they beat Ukraine 3-0 on Monday, while Turkey spoiled Georgia's major tournament debut with a 3-1 win that might go down as one of the most entertaining matches of the competition. Earlier on Wednesday, Albania dramatically drew 2-2 with Croatia as both teams earned their first points of the competition.\n\nSponsored by Paramount+\ud83d\udd17 Midfield Link Play\ud83c\udde6\ud83c\uddf7 Argentina begin Copa America title defense\n\nThe Copa America begins on Thursday with all eyes on -- who else? -- Argentina, who might be at a major tournament with Lionel Messi for the last time.\n\nExpectations are high for Argentina, three years after winning the Copa America and a year and a half removed from winning the World Cup. They did not earn top spot in Chuck Booth's power rankings solely on their recent history, though -- Argentina have found a way to blend experience with promising youngsters in recent years, demonstrating that they are far more than just a one-man team.\n\nMessi, who turns 37 next week, is unlikely to shed his status as Argentina's focal point as long as he is on the national team but manager LIonel Scaloni has been able to bridge the age gap that exists in his multigenerational squad. Their Copa America roster includes promising young attackers like 19-year-olds Alejandro Garnacho, who registered 10 goals and five assists for Manchester United last season, and Valentin Carboni, who spent last season at Monza on loan from Inter and has two caps for the national team. Messi himself has praised Carboni's talent following their 4-1 win over Guatemala last week, and CBS Sports Golazo Network contributor Felipe Cardenas teases that he might play a sizable role at this summer's competition.\n\nCardenas: \"Messi was coaching him throughout that first half. They were on the same side together and every once in a while, Messi would just give him a hand gesture, tell him to go out a bit wider, tell him to tuck in a little bit. ... Messi really does value his talent. He came out after the game and said, 'This is a player we need to take care of, we need to take advantage of.' He's been watching him since his U-20 days.\"\n\nArgentina will open up their title defense against Canada in Atlanta, the first match in a favorable group that includes Chile and Peru. A path to the final seems probable for the reigning champions, too -- other favorites to win the competition like Brazil, Uruguay and Colombia are all on the other side of the bracket. The aim for Argentina, then, will be to build a long-awaited era of dominance in the international game, especially if it's Messi's competitive sendoff.\n\n\ud83d\udd17 Top Stories\n\n\ud83d\udde3\ufe0f Anti-discrimination in MLS: Black Players for Change executive director Allen Hopkins Jr. stops by Morning Footy to describe the new anti-discrimination policy in MLS and room for improvement in hiring Black coaches and executives around the league.\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Euro check-in: Here's the latest batch of Euro power rankings, as well as a discussion on the incredibly competitive nature of the competition so far. Plus, here's a look at favorites England and France and Belgium post-defeat.\n\n\ud83c\udfc6 Copa preview: Here are predictions for every game at the Copa America, a look at the can't miss games during the group stage and a list of the 20 players from the Golazo 100 who will take center stage in the U.S. this summer.\n\n\ud83c\uddfa\ud83c\uddf8 NWSL solo efforts: Last weekend's NWSL action was all about standout players with Gotham's superteam era finally underway and rookie Ally Sentnor standing out for the Utah Royals.\n\n\ud83e\udd1d Transfer talk: England's Kiera Walsh is nearing a move to Arsenal, who are in discussions with Barcelona over a transfer, while Giorgos Giakoumakis makes the move to Cruz Azul from Atlanta United.\n\n\ud83d\udcfa McBride on Kickin' It: USMNT legend Brian McBride was the latest guest on Kickin' It and discussed his memories from the 2002 World Cup, his first impressions of Clint Dempsey, his all-time best XI and the expectations for the 2026 World Cup.\n\n\ud83d\udcb0 The Back Line\ud83d\udcb5 Best betsEuro 2024: Spain vs. Italy, Thursday, 3 p.m.\n\n\ud83d\udcb0 THE PICK: Alvaro Morata to score (+195) -- At 31 years old, Alvaro Morata has finally become a reliable goalscorer. He comes to the Euros off the back of a 21 goal season for Atletico Madrid and scored in Spain's 3-0 win over Croatia on Saturday, making him an ideal choice to score in a high-stakes matchup against reigning champions Italy.Copa America: Argentina vs. Canada, Thursday, 8 p.m.\n\n\ud83d\udcb0 THE PICK: Argentina to win 2-0 (+500) -- The Copa America opener is poised to be a lopsided affair between the reigning champions and an up-and-coming Canada. Expect Argentina to get the job done with little fuss with attackers like Lionel Messi and Lautaro Martinez able to ensure they open the competition on a strong note.\n\n\ud83d\udcfa What's on CBS Sports Golazo Network\n\n\u2600\ufe0f Morning Footy (Weekdays 8-10 a.m.): Hosts Susannah Collins, Charlie Davies, Nico Cantor and Alexis Guerreros help fans get their day started on the network's flagship morning show with highlights, interviews and the biggest soccer storylines. Morning Footy is also available in podcast form, so you'll never have to miss an episode.\n\n\ud83d\udce6 Box 2 Box (Weekday afternoons): The news-driven show quickly recaps all the latest headlines from around the world with panelists previewing the top matchups of the day. Catch Box 2 Box on CBS Sports Golazo Network on the CBS Sports app, PlutoTV and Paramount+.\n\n3\ufe0f\u20e3 Attacking Third (Monday, Thursday): The leading women's soccer podcast and social brand is now a live studio show. The NWSL season is back and our coverage of the women's game is stronger than ever. Our analysts will be breaking down the USWNT, NWSL and European domestic season all year long.\n\n\ud83d\udc5f Kickin' It (Tuesdays): CBS Sports Golazo Network's unfiltered interview show releases Tuesday. Hosted by Kate Abdo, Clint Dempsey, Mo Edu and Charlie Davies, the group chat candidly with the biggest names from the Beautiful Game and share their stories from on and off the pitch.\n\n\u26bd Call it What You Want (Monday night): A weekly podcast where Jimmy Conrad, Charlie Davies and friends cover all things USMNT and the state of the beautiful game in the United States.\n\n\ud83e\udd45 Scoreline (Daily): Scoreline is the newest place for fans to catch up on all the biggest news and results impacting global football, match highlights from the top soccer competitions and all the can't-miss goals from the day's action, starting Thursday and airing seven days a week.\n\n\ud83d\udcfa How to watch: CBS Sports Golazo Network is a free 24/7 channel exclusively dedicated to offering unparalleled coverage of all the top soccer competitions worldwide. Mexico is experiencing an identity crisis and Canada has overtaken Costa Rica as the region's third power, led by top players like Alphonso Davies and Jonathan David.\n\nThe three nations needn't fret over World Cup qualification thanks to being co-hosts in 2026, so the 2024 Copa America represents their only meaningful competition between now and then.\n\nWhile this year's tournament takes place in CONCACAF territory, its narratives and thrills will be dictated by CONMEBOL. Few tournaments can match the passion stirred by a Copa America.\n\nDo you like stars? Of course you do. There are world-class players aplenty to be found in the 16-team field.\n\nYou've read plenty about his exploits in heron pink for Inter Miami over the past 12 months, but even his greatest skeptics have to admit: there's something special about him when he pulls on the white and sky blue of Argentina.\n\nThis will be his first major tournament since Argentina won the 2022 World Cup and we could see the soon-to-be 37-year-old in a rare, pressure-free headspace. It may also be our last chance to catch him on a big international stage, as it's unclear whether he'll retire before 2026.\n\nDrink it in, one and all. There's something on this tournament menu for every appetite.\n\nYou can subscribe to The Athletic using our discount code for the tournament here. Did you know Jonathan David has the best goals-per-cap rate of any player at the tournament whose name isn't Lionel Messi? No, me neither.\n\nThe United States were host nation and a dark horse in 2016, reaching the semifinal before falling to Messi and Argentina. That proved to be an aberration, as they failed to qualify for the 2018 World Cup, but they are back at the top of the CONCACAF pecking order and trying to size up if a deep run is possible in two years' time.\n\nIt still is a bit odd when a guest nation joins a continental tournament, whether it's Qatar in the CONCACAF Gold Cup or, well, the United States hosting a second South American jamboree in under a decade. Elias Burke charted the past performances of these guest entries. Perhaps this tournament will see its first champion outside the confines of CONMEBOL...\n\nAntonee Robinson had a career-best season for Fulham, proving to be among the Premier League's best left-backs. His focus now shifts to the international arena; as he tells Peter Rutzler, it's time for the USMNT to take the next step toward being a global contender.\n\nJohnny Cardoso is among the squad's fastest risers in recent years, going from a mysterious prospect in Brazil to a mainstay of Real Betis' midfield. He gave a rare interview to Jack Lang, giving insight into what motivates him and what he aspires to be.\n\nThe USMNT exited the 2022 World Cup in the round of 16, but no player was harder done by than Gio Reyna. Eighteen months have passed since the drama around his lack of playing time and the signs a relationship with Berhalter needed mending. Last week, Reyna spoke with USMNT expert Paul Tenorio about getting his career back on track.\n\nAnd here's my comprehensive scouting guide to each member of the USMNT squad, updating you on their recent form and highlighting strengths and weaknesses.\n\nElsewhere, our writers have given their predictions for the tournament: who will win it? Which players will shine brightest? And which dark horses could bust the bracket open?\n\nMessi's greatest rival Cristiano Ronaldo is playing across the Atlantic at Euro 2024 and their two-man dynasty has been explored here in a detailed look at their international goal records.\n\nThe sport cannot live off those two forever and a rising generation of talent has been desperate to get more time in the spotlight. This tournament boasts quite a few of them...\n\nThis Copa America provides a platform for some elder statesmen to shine, too.\n\nBut wait, there's more!\n\nThis is as straightforward as brackets get: four groups of four teams, with the top two finishers advancing to the quarterfinal. It's a fixed bracket from there:\n\nIn the group stage, the tiebreaking protocol for any two teams on level footing -- well, save for irrelevant ties between third and fourth -- is as follows:\n\nGroup stage games will conclude after 90 minutes, even if they're played to a draw. A tie game at full time in the knockout rounds will advance to two 15-minute halves of extra time and advance to a penalty shootout if the game is still deadlocked after two hours of action.\n\nOn top of all this, we will be covering all the off-pitch news as it happens, bringing you details from the team camps, media conferences, and any other breaking news.\n\nAway from the Copa America, we will All-time top scorers in the same tournament", "body": "Ever since its first edition in 1916, the Copa America has brought together the best players from across the Americas to battle it out for continental glory.\n\nThe 2024 tournament in the United States gets underway on June 20, with 16 teams competing in an expanded tournament that will see CONCACAF's best go up against the traditional powerhouses from the CONMBEOL region.\n\nThere will be plenty of star power on display. Lionel Messi is back on the big stage, two years on from leading Argentina to World Cup triumph at Qatar 2022, while Brazil will have their own big guns to call on. Despite an injury that has ruled out Neymar, their squad is still packed with talent from the likes of Vinicius Jr and wonderkid Endrick.\n\nYou can expect all those names to trouble the scoresheet this summer, but they will have to go some to match the feats of some of the legendary strikers from tournament's past.\n\nHere, The Sporting News look at some of those names, and the players who have scored the most goals in a single edition of the Copa America.\n\nMORE: Copa America 2024 full schedule and bracket, updated LIVE\n\nTo answer the question of who is the player with the most goals in a single edition of the Copa America we have to think in plural, because the accolade does not belong only to one footballer but is in fact shared by three: Jair, Humberto Maschio and Javier Ambrois, each with nine goals.\n\nThe first to achieve that feat was the Brazilian Jair Rosa Pinto in the 1949 South American Championship (the forerunner to the modern-day Copa America) in Brazil.\n\nIn a tournament in which the Selecao, who at that time wore an unfamiliar white shirt, scored 46 goals in eight games, Jair, who played his club football with Flamengo, netted nine of those in the five games he played.\n\nThat benchmark was equaled in 1957, twice in the same tournament.\n\nThat year, Uruguayan Javier Ambrois, of Nacional de Montevideo, and the Argentine Humberto Maschio, of Racing, scored nine goals each. The tournament, which was played in Peru, was the breakthrough for a new star in the form of Maschio for Argentina.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting {"uri": "2024-06-392702305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "20:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T20:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T19:04:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/canada-faces-massive-test-in-copa-america-debut/", "title": "Canada Faces 'Massive' Test in Copa America Debut", "body": "The Canadian men's soccer team is set to embark on a challenging journey in their inaugural appearance at the Copa America tournament, facing a formidable test against some of the world's best teams, including World Cup champions Argentina led by Lionel Messi.\n\n\"It's a massive tournament. It's the South American equivalent of the Euros. You're talking about nations like Brazil and Argentina who've won the World Cup multiple times between them,\" said John Molinaro, founder of the website TFC Republic and a long-time observer of Canada's national team. \"This is a chance for Canada to sort of rub shoulders with some of the best teams in the world.\"\n\nRanked 49th in the FIFA world rankings, Canada is one of six CONCACAF qualifiers invited to the event, alongside Mexico and the U.S. With a roster that mirrors the one used at the World Cup, Canada will rely on international stars such as Alphonso Davies (Bayern Munich), Jonathan David (Lille), and Tajon Buchanan (Inter Milan).\n\nFollowing their match against world No. 1 Argentina, Canada will face Peru (No. 32) on June 25 in Kansas City and Chile (No. 42) on June 29 in Orlando to conclude the group stage. Molinaro views the tournament as a crucial preparatory step for Canada's role as co-host of the 2026 World Cup.\n\n\"This is a great opportunity for them to go up against the best teams in the world and possibly set themselves up for success in 2026,\" Molinaro added.\n\nCopa America marks the first international tournament for new Canadian head coach Jesse Marsch, who succeeded John Herdman in October. Marsch, previously a club-level coach in Europe, faced an immediate test with friendlies against the Netherlands and France. Despite a 4-0 loss to the Netherlands, Canada rebounded with a surprising 0-0 draw against the second-ranked French team.\n\n\"To go up against the No. 2 team in the world and earn a draw in Bordeaux.... Considering Jesse Marsch has only been in charge for not even a month, I think it was an impressive result,\" Molinaro said.\n\nBrendan Dunlop, co-founder of Canadian Soccer Daily and radio commentator for Canada's Copa America games, praised Marsch's tactical acumen and ability to connect with players. Dunlop believes Marsch's approach will make the Canadian team more exciting and adaptable.\n\nThe tournament's opening match against Argentina and Messi, likely participating in his final international tournament, promises to be a significant challenge. Dunlop noted Messi's continued motivation and the strength of Argentina and Brazil as the tournament favorites, with Uruguay and Colombia also poised to compete strongly.\n\nFor Canada, the expectations are more modest. After a disappointing World Cup showing in Qatar, where they lost all three games and scored only one goal, Dunlop anticipates a more competitive performance in the Copa America. While a win against Argentina seems unlikely, Canada could achieve victories against Chile or Peru and possibly advance beyond the group stage.\n\n\"They'll go and make the country proud. 16 teams are from the Confederation of North, Central America and Caribbean Association Football (Concacaf).\n\nIt was also the same for the special edition 2016 Copa America Centenario - but this is the first regular staging of the tournament to be played outside of the continent.\n\nMany of the host cities are in southern states such as California, Texas and Florida - but there are stadia further north too including in New Jersey.\n\nThe tournament is being seen as preparation for the 2026 World Cup, which will be hosted by the United States - along with Canada and Mexico.\n\nThe US, Mexico, Jamaica, Canada, Costa Rica and Panama will be the six North and Central American countries joining all 10 South American nations to compete.\n\nMost Copas since 1993 have had 12 countries, {"uri": "8185583618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:39:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:39:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:38:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://worldsoccertalk.com/copa-america/copa-america-top-earners-scaloni-berhalter-not-even-in-top-5/", "title": "Copa America top earners: Scaloni, Berhalter not even in top 5", "body": "The anticipation for this year's Copa America is palpable, with Argentina emerging as the favorite to clinch the title. The team's recent successes have established them as a dominant force in international soccer.\n\nUnder Lionel Scaloni, Argentina secured the Copa America trophy in 2021, followed by a triumph in the 2022 World Cup. As the tournament approaches, Argentina will likely aim for a historic third consecutive international title.\n\nScaloni's impact on Argentina's national team cannot be overstated. Taking over the reins in 2018, he has revitalized the team, leading them to significant victories on the international stage. His tactical acumen and ability to foster a cohesive unit have been pivotal in Argentina's recent achievements.\n\nDespite his success, Scaloni's salary reflects a surprising disparity, La Opinion reveals. He earns $2.6 million annually, placing him sixth among the best-paid managers in South America.\n\nIn the financial hierarchy of coaches at the 2024 Copa America, Uruguay's Marcelo Bielsa leads the pack with an annual salary of $4 million. Bielsa has transformed Uruguay into a formidable force, making them serious contenders for the Copa America title. Then, Brazil's Dorival Junior follows closely, also earning around $4 million. Despite some criticism of his appointment, he remains a key figure in Brazil's quest for glory.\n\nRicardo Gareca, who now coaches the Chilean national team, earns $3.7 million. Gareca's reputation as a seasoned tactician precedes him. Therefore, his new role with Chile is seen as a fresh start for the team. Paraguay's Daniel Garnero and Venezuela's Fernando Batista each earn $3 million, reflecting the competitive salaries for top managerial talent in the region.\n\nBelow Scaloni in the pay scale are Ecuador's Felix Sanchez and Colombia's Nestor Lorenzo, both earning $2.4 million. Interestingly, Gregg Berhalter's $2.2 million salary is barely enough for ninth place, as Peru's Jorge Fossati receives $2 million, while Bolivia's Antonio Carlo Zago earns the least at $1.1 million.\n\nAs the 2024 Copa America approaches, the spotlight will not only be on star players like Vinicius, Messi, or even Pulisic, but also on the managers who command from the sidelines. Managers like Scaloni and Berhalter, despite their lower salaries, will be crucial in steering their teams through the tournament. Their strategic decisions, ability to motivate players, and tactical prowess will be under intense scrutiny.\n\nFor nations like Chile and Peru, now led by Ricardo Gareca and Jorge Fossati respectively, this tournament marks a significant evaluation of their progress under new management. Meanwhile, Gregg Berhalter, the USMNT manager, faces a crucial period for his future. One of the lowest-paid managers at the Copa America is under pressure following a disappointing 5-1 loss to Colombia. His ability to turn the team's fortunes around will be closely watched.\n\nHis squad will have one more chance to play against top teams in a tournament setting in the Copa America before the 2026 World Cup. Therefore, improving his team management skills is something he must demonstrate. A glance at the rosters reveals some astonishing talent. {"uri": "8182353855", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "18:23:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T18:23:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T18:10:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13539529/Lionel-Messi-Argentina-set-defend-Copa-America-title.html", "title": "Lionel Messi, Argentina set to defend Copa America title", "body": "The 2024 Copa America will be only the second to feature 16 teams in four groups, with six guest teams from CONCACAF participating in CONMEBOL's continental championship.\n\nPlay begins with four games over three days in Groups A and B between June 20-22 across the United States.\n\nHere's the first of Field Level Media's two-part series previewing the action from what promises to be a memorable event.\n\nGroup A\n\nThe teams: Argentina, Peru, Chile, Canada\n\nThe favorite: When you have the greatest living player on Earth, you're going to be a favorite. That's certainly the case with Lionel Messi's Argentina, who have an extremely high-quality supporting cast around the still-magical, soon-to-be-37-year-old. Among the best are longtime international sidekick Angel Di Maria, Manchester City striker Julian Alvarez, Liverpool midfielder Alexis Mac Allister and Aston Villa goalkeeper Emi Martinez.\n\nBest matchup: Argentina's second group game against Chile will be a rematch of the 2016 final played in the United States. The current Chilean squad is a long way off from that group which upset Messi's team on penalties back then, but Alexis Sanchez will still be roaming the pitch as a potential Messi foil.\n\nHistory lesson: Defending champion Argentina's 15 Copa America titles are tied with Uruguay for the most in the history of the competition, which is the oldest in international soccer -- even predating the Olympic and World Cup tournaments.\n\nPlayers to watch: Beyond Messi, Sanchez and others we've already mentioned, Argentina teenager Alejandro Garnacho scored the Premier League Goal of the season for Manchester United. Canada's Alphonso Davies is considered one of the best left backs in the world and is a two-way weapon for his national team and Bayern Munich.\n\nUp Next: Frankly, it would be extremely surprising if Argentina doesn't progress from a relatively straightforward group. It would be less of a surprise if that means they face 2022 World Cup group foes Mexico in the second round if an unimpressive El Tri squad can't top Group B.\n\nGroup B\n\nThe teams: Mexico, Ecuador, Venezuela, Jamaica\n\nThe favorite: Oddsmakers have installed Mexico as the most likely team to top the group, and given the enormous Mexican-American population in the United States, they'll probably be playing with a home-field advantage in every game. But this is not a vintage El Tri side, and Ecuador in particular could wrest away the top spot. Jamaica also has a roster with several Premier League stars, but they have underachieved recently relative to their talent.\n\nBest Matchup: Mexico and Ecuador will meet on the final day of group B, and while each could've already booked their place in the next round, there should be plenty to play for anyway; namely, the potential right to avoid a quarterfinal clash with defending Copa America and World Cup champion Argentina, who still have that Messi guy.\n\nHistory Lesson: Mexico is by far the most frequent guest team to compete at Copa America and will be making its 11th appearance since 1993 in the traditional South American event. They've reached the semifinals an impressive five times and the final twice but haven't been beyond the quarters since 2001.\n\nPlayers to watch: Edson Alvarez quickly became one of West Ham's most important players after his move to the Premier League, and the defensive midfielder might be even more significant for El Tri's hopes. Chelsea's Enner Valencia is another world-class central midfielder who will pull the strings for Ecuador. Veteran striker and Alvarez's club teammate Michail Antonio can strike from anywhere in the attacking half for Jamaica.\n\nUp Next: As mentioned before, finishing top of the group here carries the prize of most likely avoiding Messi in the second round. It's anyone's guess whom the group winner could face though, with Canada, Peru and Chile all reasonable picks to finish second in Group A.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8187325379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:48:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:48:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:45:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/five-big-questions-ahead-canadas-150800594.html", "title": "\u2753Five big questions ahead of Canada's Copa Am\u00e9rica debut \ud83e\udd14", "body": "Canada have another shot at international glory after qualifying for their debut Copa Am\u00e9rica tournament.\n\nJoined by World Cup winners Argentina, Chile and Peru in Group A. Their first introduction won't be easy.\n\nThere was beauty, and there was pain for Canadian soccer fans during the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.\n\nAfter a historic qualification run (in which they pipped rivals USA to the top spot and reached the big stage for the first time in 36 years), there was a huge reality check.\n\nCanada certainly made an impression, but truly lacked experience and maturity -- two characteristics they still haven't quite mastered.\n\nSince the World Cup, they lost the CONCACAF Nations League final to the USA and drew against both Guadeloupe and Guatemala in the Gold Cup. They later imploded against Jamaica in the CONCACAF Nations League quarters and needed to face Trinidad and Tobago via a playoff to even reach the Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nThere may be light at the end of the tunnel, though, with a new manager and new general secretary/CEO. Add to that the individual development of star players over the last two years.\n\nWill Canada finally establish themselves as men and not boys?\n\nSome of the aforementioned struggles weren't under former boss John Herdman, who moved to coach Toronto FC in late August. Canada worked with interim coach Mauro Biello to qualify for the Copa Am\u00e9rica before ultimately announcing American Jesse Marsch as the new permanent head coach.\n\nHis appointment came just over one month before the team's headline tournament opener against Argentina. To prepare on such short notice, Canada booked two high-level friendlies.\n\nMarsch's first game in charge ended in a 4-0 thumping to the Netherlands (however, it was goalless at half-time). Next was a much, much better result, as they held European superpower France to a 0-0 draw. The teams had the same passing accuracy (89%) and almost the same number of passes (France led 521 to 513).\n\nThe ex-Leeds United boss still needs to tweak the attack, though. Under his guidance, Canada only registered two shots on target in their first 180 minutes.\n\nStill, Marsch has instilled some missing confidence in this squad despite limited time knowing them. The result against France will act as a huge motivator for the Copa Am\u00e9rica. What exactly is to come of this new era is yet to be determined.\n\nIt was a struggle to get here, but Canadians nationwide were in awe after finding out the Canucks would face Argentina in the Copa Am\u00e9rica, let alone a tournament opener.\n\nBut can they actually go toe-to-toe with the best in the world? La Albiceleste are notably the reigning World Cup champions and Copa Am\u00e9rica holders. This is as big as it gets.\n\nTalk about a dream opportunity. And what weight it would carry not only throughout the tournament but across the footballing world if they can pull off any result against the World No. 1. France first, Argentina next?\n\nNo ifs, ands, or buts; the pressure lies on Alphonso Davies (Bayern Munich), Jonathan David (Lille), Stephen Eust\u00e1quio (Porto), Alistair Johnston (Celtic), Tajon Buchanan (Inter Milan), and company. But a few other names are ready to share the limelight.\n\nWatford's 22-year-old midfielder Isma\u00ebl Kon\u00e9 comes to mind. The youngster was heavily relied upon by the Championship side with seven goal contributions from 42 league appearances last year. He's integrated into the national team with ease, too.\n\nAnother name from England's second tier is Liam Millar. The Preston North End winger registered five goals and five assists in 35 league games in 2023/24. He brought a much-needed spark against France, seeing a long-range effort hit the woodwork.\n\nThen don't forget about the Major League Soccer crew. Maxime Cr\u00e9peau (Portland Timbers) and Dayne St. Clair (Minnesota United) battle for first-choice goalkeeper. Mo\u00efse Bombito (Colorado Rapids) and Jacob Shaffelburg (Nashville SC) are also turning into fan favourites.\n\nMarsch will obviously still be tinkering with his preferred starting XI after just two games in charge, but there's an honest selection headache in front of him.\n\nIf you haven't watched this Canadian side before, well, they play with a chip on their shoulder. Perhaps that's because Canada is widely known globally as only a hockey country,\n\nCanada loves the underdog tag, so when they face their opponents, they say, 'Bring it on' in full force. But is that tag enough to inspire them during this tournament?\n\nAfter the semi-disastrous World Cup and with the Copa Am\u00e9rica arriving on the eve of hosting the next World Cup, how the Canucks perform against quality opposition is crucial.\n\nThe 48th-ranked country has come a long way. But it's time to actually play the game at the required level and not rely solely on attitude, grit, and skyrocketing mood levels if things go their way.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8187155786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:55:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:55:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:54:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5032650", "title": "Just Enjoy Messi and Di Maria While You Can Urges Scaloni", "body": "Argentina's head coach Lionel Scaloni says he has a full strength team for Thursday's Copa America opener against Canada. - AFP\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni has urged his compatriots to not worry about when Lionel Messi and Angel Di Maria will hang up their boots and to instead just enjoy watching them in the Copa America.\n\nWorld champions and defending Copa America title holders, Argentina get the 16-team tournament under way against Canada at Mercedes Benz Stadium on Thursday.\n\nMessi, the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner who turns 37 on Monday, will captain Scaloni's team in what is surely his final edition of the continental championship.\n\nAnd with winger Angel Di Maria, 36, also reaching the final stages of his career, the end of an era is on the horizon for the 15-times Copa winners.\n\nBut Scaloni said that shouldn't be the focus around the team in the coming tournament, AFP reported.\n\n\"It doesn't make much sense to think about when they're gone. Let's enjoy them now, we'll see what happens later. Messi is fine, he's happy. I'm with renewed ideas and strength. It's a nice challenge to defend the title,\" he said.\n\nScaloni said he has a full strength side to pick from for the opening game against Jesse Marsch's Canada.\n\nChelsea midfielder Enzo Fernandez underwent a hernia operation in April but returned to action in the World Cup winners' recent friendlies against Ecuador and Guatemala and Scaloni said he is ready to go.\n\n\"We'll see if he plays tomorrow but he is in condition to start,\" the Argentine coach told a news conference where he appeared alongside midfielder Leandro Paredes.\n\nScaloni hinted that AS Roma midfielder Paredes is likely to start however and said that while he was keeping his starting eleven to himself, he had made his mind up.\n\n\"I have the line-up, I have no doubts. I'm going to give it to them this afternoon, they don't know yet. They're all available for tomorrow's game, the ones we think are the best will play,\" he said.\n\n\"I could be wrong, but we always think about putting out the best. With me, whoever is best always plays. Paredes had to come off in the first game of the World Cup because we thought there were other guys who were better. And there's a reason why I have him next to me now,\" said Scaloni.\n\nShould Scaloni start with Fernandez on the bench his midfield trio is likely to be made up of Rodrigo De Paul, Paredes and Alexis Mac Allister\n\nArgentina have started their CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying campaign positively with five wins out of six games but Scaloni said he was looking forward to match-ups with teams from outside of South America.\n\nThis edition of the Copa America features six teams from the CONCACAF region with Argentina facing Canada as well as Chile and Peru in Group A.\n\nWhile the USA and Mexico are traditionally the strongest teams from CONCACAF, Scaloni said he has been impressed by Canada's progress.\n\n\"They have a very good team, with important players and a new coach who has brought new ideas. In the last World Cup they played very well, but didn't get the luck they deserved,\" he said, before warning against complacency.\n\n\"They are a difficult opponent. Anyone who thinks it's all been said and done is wrong. They're the best in their country and it's extremely difficult, especially at the start of a tournament. {"uri": "8184598130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:48:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:48:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:47:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/football/copa-america-all-mascots-pets-names-origin-meaning-history-full-list-1987-to-2021/article68217859.ece", "title": "Copa America 2024: Full list of competition mascots over the years", "body": "The 48th edition of the Copa America will get underway on June 20 with the USA set to host the tournament.\n\nThe tournament will have 10 teams from the South America and six from the North America taking part, with the final set to take place on July 14 in Florida.\n\nThe Mascot of the 2024 Copa America is an eagle named Capitan.\n\nAs per the tournament organisers, the inspiration for the choice of an eagle as the mascot was born from the symbolism that this majestic animal has in various cultures of the Americas, illustrating strength, boldness, and excellence.\n\nFrom 2021 to 1987, here is the full list of Copa America mascots - also know as pets - down the history lane.\n\n2021 - PIBE (BRAZIL) Pibe, Copa America 2021 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nPibe, Copa America 2021 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nPibe, the dog, was the mascot for the 2021 edition of Copa America which was held in Brazil.\n\nPibe was described as a funny, cheerful, agile and unique mascot with which the organization of the competition described the dog that would represent the Copa Am\u00e9rica as 'The maximum specimen of the New South American Race.'\n\nCopa Am\u00e9rica had arranged an online voting through its official Twitter handle to decide the selection of the mascot on 2 December 2019.\n\nThe designers also claimed that the pet had the best traits of each South American dog breed.\n\n2019 - ZIZITO (BRAZIL) Zizito, Copa America 2019 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nZizito, Copa America 2019 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nZizito, a capybara, was named as the mascot for the 2019 Copa America in Brazil.\n\nThe name pays tribute to former Brazil star Zizinho, one of Pele's childhood idols, and was picked with an online poll.\n\nZizinho scored 17 Copa American goals, tied for most in tournament history with Argentina's Norberto Mendez. He died in 2002 at the age of 80.\n\n2015 - ZINCHA (CHILE) Zincha, Copa America 2015 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nZincha, Copa America 2015 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nZincha, a culpeo fox, was the mascot for the 2015 Copa America in Chile.\n\nA canid species that lives throughout Chile and several places in South America, particularly in the countries surrounding the Andes Mountains. It had characteristic designs on the body that allude to the indigenous culture of Chile.\n\nThe name of Zincha is derived from a mixture between the words Zorro (fox) and Fan.\n\n2011 - TANGOLERO (ARGENTINA) Tangolero, Copa America 2011 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nTangolero, Copa America 2011 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nTangolero, a bird, was the mascot of the 2011 Copa America in Argentina.\n\nA \u00f1and\u00fa, also known as Rhea, is a bird native from South America. It is dressed in the uniform of the Argentine National Team and has the official ball of the tournament.\n\n2007 - GUAKY (VENEZUELA) Guaky, Copa America 2007 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nGuaky, Copa America 2007 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nThe 2007 Copa America held in Venezuela had a Guaky, a macaw, as its mascot.\n\nIt was dressed in the Venezuelan national team's jersey and on its wings the country's flag. To choose the official mascot, a contest was held, which was entered by 4.5 million Venezuelan children. The winning entry came from 15-year-old Jhoyling Zabaleta.\n\n2004 - CHASQUI (PERU) Chasqui, Copa America 2004 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nChasqui, Copa America 2004 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nThe 2004 Peru Copa America's mascot was Chasqui, an indigenous Peruvian character.\n\nChasqui is a name that raises from the ancient Inca couriers (runners). He was dressed in the Peruvian team's shirt. On his head he wore a multicolored band with two feathers and played bare feet with a ball.\n\n2001 - AMERIKO (COLOMBIA) Ameriko, Copa America 2001 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nAmeriko, Copa America 2001 mascot. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nAn Alien named 'Americo' was the 2001 Copa America mascot which was held in Colombia.\n\nThe turquoise alien with blue eyes' name comes from the translation of America to Esperanto.\n\n1999 - TAGUA (PARAGUAY)\n\nThe Copa Am\u00e9rica Paraguay 1999 mascot was Tagua a peccary but also known as a boar.\n\nTagua appeared with a ball, black boots and dressed in the Paraguay flag colours holding a popular drink called Terer\u00e9, the official drink of Paraguay.\n\n1997 - TATU (BOLIVIA)\n\nTatu, an armadillo, was the mascot of the 1997 Copa America held in Bolivia.\n\nThe nine-banded armadillo wore the shirt of the Bolivian National Team under its shell.\n\n1995 - TORITO (URUGUAY)\n\nFor Uruguay's 1995 Copa America, Torito, a bull as the mascot.\n\nTorito was chosen to spread awareness and signify the importance of livestock in Uruguay during the time. The bull donned the Uruguay national team kit colours.\n\n1993 - CHOCLITO (ECUADOR)\n\nChoclito named after Ecuadorian corn, is one of the most traditional food of Ecuador and was the mascot of the 1993 Copa America.\n\nThe corn is painted in the colours of Ecuador national team.\n\n1991 - GUASO (CHILE)\n\nGuaso was chosen as the mascot of the 1991 Copa America in Italy.\n\nGuaso was a stylised drawing representing the Chilean Huaso (peasants), dressed in the Chilean flag and a ball.\n\n1989 - TICO (BRAZIL)\n\nFor the 1989 Copa America hosted at Brazil, Tico - Zorzal Sabia - a typical bird of the region was announced as the mascot.\n\nThis species of birds is mainly found in the wooded habitats in eastern and northern South America. Tico wore a blue shirt, white shorts and blue boots and socks.\n\n1987 - GARDELITO (ARGENTINA)\n\nAfter 71 years since the commencement of tournament, Copa America introduced the concept of mascots in its quadrennial tournament in 1987.\n\nFor the 1987 Copa America held in Argentina, Gardelito was the first and official mascot of the tournament.\n\nThe mascot is based on the famous Argentinian tango singer Carlos Gardel.\n\nLatest on SportstarIND-W vs SA-W head-to-head, ODI series: India vs South Africa overall stats, top performers, recordsTeam SportstarT20 World Cup 2024: Adapting to conditions is a mark of good batsmanship, says Suryakumar Yadav PTIEURO 2024: What are the matches in the European Championship today?Team SportstarGermany vs Hungary LIVE streaming info, Euro 2024: When, where to watch GER v HUN; Group A PreviewTeam SportstarEuro 2024 Group F points table: Turkey tops standings despite Portugal beating Czechia 2-1Team SportstarREAD MORE STORIES", "source": Argentina will try to retain its title, but other teams like Brazil and Uruguay will try to prevent it.\n\nThe rights to broadcast the tournament in Spain are held by Movistar Plus+, but the good news is that any user, regardless of the operator, you will be able to see all matches. Next, we will tell you where, when and at what price you can enjoy the meetings.\n\nThe best competition of American countries starts in the early hours of Thursday, June 20 to Friday, June 21 and will last until July 14, the date on which the final will be played. Total, there will be 16 national teamsdivided into four groups, which will fight to become champion of the Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nArgentina, with Messi at the helm, will be the rival to beat. Brazil, with Vinicius Jr. and Rodrygo, the Uruguay of Fede Valverde or Ronald Ara\u00fajo, or the Colombia of James Rodr\u00edguez, are other of the great favorites to win the title.\n\nThe groups of the first phase of the Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 are the following:\n\nArgentina - Canada It will be the opening match of the Copa Am\u00e9rica and will be played in the early hours of Thursday the 20th to Friday the 21st (at 02:00, Spanish peninsular time) at the Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.\n\nBut let's get to the important thing, where can we see the matches? All matches will be seen on Movistar Plus+ (dial 7) and #Vamos (dial 8), two channels available on the Movistar Plus+ OTT for customers of any operator for 9.99 euros per month. Since it has no permanence, you can subscribe by paying those 9.99 euros, watch the entire tournament and unsubscribe before they charge you for the second month.\n\nIn addition, Movistar has enabled a specific channel for the tournament where we can also watch the matches: Copa Am\u00e9rica on M+ (dial 61). There's certainly photos of the Manchester City icon with some goats, though there's no other Argentinian players to be found. The whole thing is of course a publicity stunt, arranged by gambling company Stake.com.\n\nThe whole thing is a play on the term 'GOAT', an acronym for 'Greatest Of All Time', which Stake wisely precede with 'one of the' when talking about Aguero given he played alongside the superior Lionel Messi.\n\nWhy England Dominated Serbia (And Then Why They Didn't)\n\nAguero said: \"I've played with the GOAT, and it was great to spend the day with some more of his kind! If Argentina can win Copa America, then they can cement their legacy as one of the Greatest Teams of All Time.\"\n\nArgentina will be looking to defend their Copa America crown having won the tournament in 2021, with Angel Di Maria scoring the only goal of the game in the final against Brazil. They will kick off this year's campaign by facing Canada, Chile and Peru in the group stage.\n\nOn his country's prospects, Aguero said: \"Argentina is always a candidate... but, pressure? I don't think so. I think we're used to this. Now, it's about preserving the style and team concept we've developed. We won what we've won because of this.\n\n\"The players that were part of that process should pass it on to the newcomers. It's great that it happens naturally. The national squad is richer for all the new talent, and they'll keep growing because of this.\"\n\nNow plying his trade for Inter Miami, Messi will be in familiar surroundings at Argentina's Florida base, which Argentina also used to warm up for a pre-World Cup friendly in 2022 before going on to win the tournament. Hey, why change a winning formula?\n\nAguero added: \"There's a big expat community in Miami of Argentinians, and many other Latin Americans who support our side.\n\n\"With Leo playing [for] the local Inter [Miami], that sentiment grows even more. But there are a lot of Mexicans, Colombians, Venezuelans too.\n\n\"We can say that Miami is likely the place with the most people rooting for different teams of Copa America at least.\"\n\nAguero {"uri": "8185631156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:14:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:14:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:13:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.wfaa.com/article/sports/soccer/copa-america-first-female-referee-edina-alves-neuza-back/287-543e416d-3b70-4d81-8346-ccfe8d7b5174", "title": "Brazil's Edina Alves to be 1st female official for Copa America in 108-year history", "body": "ARLINGTON, Texas -- Copa America is the oldest international soccer tournament in the world.\n\nThe inaugural tournament was held in 1916 and has been hosted 47 times in the past 100-plus years. For the 48th Copa America, hosted here in the United States, female referees will officiate matches for the first time in the tournament's history.\n\nThe referees, both men and women, belong to CONMEBOL and UEFA, in a strategic exchange agreement between the confederations, and to Concacaf as guests. There have been 101 referees called to the tournament, and seven of them are women. Of the seven, four are representing CONMEBOL and three are representing Concacaf. They are:\n\n\"It's a dream, a dream come true. I and seven other women are here at this CONMEBOL Copa America. So, for us, it is something very big, something inexplicable, the emotion and the feeling of experiencing all this here,\" Alves said in a Copa America news release.\n\nAlves, of Brazil, will be the first woman to ever officiate a Copa America match. She was assigned to work the June 21 match between Peru and Chile at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas. The only Copa America match prior to it, the tournament opener between Argentina and Canada, will be officiated by men, according to the referee assignments.\n\nAlves will serve as the fourth official. Back, also from Brazil, was assigned to be the fifth official for the Peru vs. Chile match, which is essentially the substitute for either of the assistant referees, in case one of them should become unable to continue in that role.\n\nThe very next day, on June 22 for Mexico versus Jamaica at NRG Stadium in Houston, Maria Penso has been dubbed as the fourth referee. Thursday's Copa opener is nevertheless sold out for the clash between one of the best teams in the world and a Canadian squad led by recently hired American Manager Jesse Marsch.\n\nArgentina vs. Canada Copa America Odds\n\nThe reigning World Cup champs are the clear favorites to win this tournament, so it's no surprise that they're heavily favored in the first match of the Copa America.\n\nCanada boasts a few stars including Bayern Munich's Alphonso Davies, who is captaining the squad at just 23 years old, but appears overmatched against Argentina. La Albiceleste return every key contributor from the lineup that won the World Cup two years ago.\n\nArgentina vs. Canada Over/Under\n\nAt BetMGM, the Over/Under in Argentina vs. Canada is set at 2.5 (Over -145, Under +105), while FanDuel also has the total at 2.5 (Over -138, Under +112) and DK prices Over 2.5 at -145 and Under 2.5 at +115.\n\nThe total being set at just 2.5 shows that oddsmakers expect a shutout, which makes how many goals Argentina will score the biggest question. In fact, at DraftKings, the Both Teams to Score prop pays out at \"Yes\" (+125), \"No\" -155, while the Argentina Win to Zero prop is not cheap at -135.\n\nOne other example of DraftKings' confidence in the Argentina back line is apparent in the Canada: Team Total Goals -- Over 0.5 (+100); Under 0.5 (-135).\n\nA few fun props to consider whenever eight-time Ballon d'Or winner Lionel Messi takes the pitch are his goal-scorer markets. For Thursday, FanDuel's Anytime Goalscorer (ATGS) market prices Messi at -115, while BetMGM lists him at -130, with DK's Messi ATGS price set at -125. Obviously, if this is where you're looking -- and who can blame you -- FD offers the best bang for your buck on this play.\n\nAnd if you're looking for a bigger payout, take a look at playing Messi First Time Goal Scorer (+260 at BetMGM; +270 at DraftKings; +280 at FanDuel). FanDuel also offers props for player hat tricks -- a successful play on that bold swing would pay out at +1800.\n\nLautaro Martinez, Julian Alvarez Goal Scorer Props\n\nOther interesting ATGS options include Argentina forwards Lautaro Martinez (+115 at DK; +110 at BetMGM) and Julian Alvarez (+145 at DK; +140 at BetMGM).\n\nThe fact that the Canadian with the shortest ATGS odds is Jonathan David at nearly 4-to-1 (+370 at DK; +375 at BetMGM) illustrates how one-sided this match-up looks as well as any betting market for this game.\n\nArgentina vs. Canada Betting Analysis, Picks\n\nWhen the underdog is as long as +1100, that leaves little to break down as far as who will win and why.\n\nThe more compelling questions for Thursday night appear to be, \"How long can Canada keep it close?\" and \"Will Argentina pour it on if it builds an early lead?\"\n\nIn the last major competition where we saw Argentina, Manager Jorge Vilda's team played seven matches in the 2022 World Cup, going 4-2-1 in 90 minutes (obviously, it won both \"draws\" -- against the Netherlands in the quarters and, memorably, against France in the final). Of Argentina's four wins in 2022, just one came by a margin of more than two goals.\n\nThis year's team could very well show a lot more interest in blowing teams out, but for the opener, Canada seemingly has a chance to keep the final score respectable.\n\nWith that in mind, below are a couple conservative plays that offer odds long enough for a solid payout. The first play here cashes as long as Argentina has a lead at halftime and Canada has not scored by the time the teams head to the locker rooms.\n\nBetting Picks: 1st Half -- Argentina to win and {"uri": "8182036504", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "14:12:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T14:12:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T14:11:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/every-premier-league-player-at-copa-america-2024/", "title": "Every Premier League club ranked by how many players they have at 2024 Copa America", "body": "Highlights Only a handful of players get to represent their country at major tournaments like the World Cup or European Championships. 41 stars from the Premier League are heading to Copa America this summer, with Fulham boasting five of them. Clubs like Ipswich Town, Southampton, Leicester City, Everton, and Brentford have no players representing their countries at the tournament.\n\nDomestic football is all well and good - but for footballers, there is no better feeling than representing your country. The majority of players are continually snubbed by their respective nations, meaning that just a handful are given the opportunity to play at a major tournament - most notably, the World Cup or European Championships.\n\nThere is the Copa America, too, which typically goes under the radar. Nations from across North and South America go to battle this summer in the United States, with reigning champions Argentina looking to retain their title.\n\nWith the Premier League finished for the summer and all focus now on the respective summer tournaments - Euro 2024 included - which players from the top tier are heading to Copa America this summer?\n\nIn total, there are 41 stars heading to the United States this summer and one club boasts five of them but, for reference, there are no players from Ipswich Town, Southampton, Leicester City, Everton and Brentford that have been picked to represent their country at this summer's tournament.\n\nOne Player Manchester City Close\n\nAt club level, there is uncertainty over Julian Alvarez's future with him linked with a move to Chelsea, but what is for certain is that he'll be in the United States throughout the summer being utilised in all manner of constellations by Lionel Scaloni.\n\nThe forward, who plays for Manchester City, has proven time and time again why his employers are lucky to have him - and despite playing second fiddle to none other than Erling Haaland, his 2023/24 return of 11 goals and nine assists is commendable.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: The last Argentina matchday squad not to include Julian Alvarez was in October 2021.\n\nPotentially looking to secure a switch away from the Etihad Stadium in the coming months, the 2000-born magician, valued at \u00a380 million, will be hoping to enjoy a summer of glory with his compatriots - the same roster of players who were crowned World Cup champions in 2022.\n\nOne Player - Copa America 2024\n\nClub\n\nPlayer\n\nManchester City\n\nJulian Alvarez\n\nTwo Players Newcastle United, Manchester United, Chelsea, Bournemouth, Arsenal Close\n\nBrazilian duo Gabriel Martinelli and Gabriel Magalhaes are the two from Arsenal's roster to get the call-up this summer, while Gabriel Jesus misses out after a poor season by his own standards.\n\nBruno Guimaraes' representatives could continue to scour for potential would-be buyers while their client is attempting to help guide Brazil, alongside the aforementioned Arsenal duo, to glory in the United States. His colleague, Miguel Almiron, will be plying his trade for Paraguay with him likely to hit the 60-cap international mark.\n\nRelated 12 Top Scorers in Copa America History (Ranked) Some of the best South American players in history have lit up the continental competition. Here's a rundown of the Copa America's leading scorers.\n\nOn the back of a difficult season on the south coast for Bournemouth, USMNT captain Tyler Adams will be spotted leading his compatriots out to battle this summer, with assistant coach B.J. Callaghan insisting that he is \"looking fit\" ahead of the tournament.\n\nChelsea's two \u00a3100 million plus midfielders, Moises Caicedo and Enzo Fernandez, will be representing Colombia and Argentina, respectively. The latter, after helping his nation lift glory in Qatar two years ago, will be vying for another piece of silverware to add to his bow.\n\nFor Manchester United, Argentine duo Lisandro Martinez and Alejandro Garnacho are both on the plane for La Albiceleste. The latter enjoyed a glittering campaign in an otherwise turbulent Red Devils side, notching 15 goal contributions (ten goals, five assists) in 50 appearances across all competitions, while the former struggled for fitness.\n\nTwo Players - Copa America 2024\n\nClub\n\nPlayers\n\nArsenal\n\nGabriel Magalhaes (Brazil), Gabriel Martinelli (Brazil)\n\nBournemouth\n\nLuis Sinisterra (Colombia), Tyler Adams (USMNT)\n\nChelsea\n\nEnzo Fernandez (Argentina), Moises Caicedo (Ecuador)\n\nManchester United\n\nAlejandro Garnacho (Argentina), Lisandro Martinez (Argentina)\n\nNewcastle United\n\nBruno Guimaraes (Brazil), Miguel Almiron (Paraguay)\n\nThree Players West Ham United, Tottenham Hotspur, Crystal Palace, Aston Villa Close\n\nFour of the Premier League's 20 clubs have three players that will rack up further international caps this summer at the competition's 48th instalment: West Ham United, Tottenham Hotspur, Crystal Palace and Aston Villa. Douglas Luiz has an important summer ahead. Not only can he help lead Brazil to glory but a switch to Juventus could also be on the horizon. The midfielder is a menace from 12 yards out, too, which could prove valuable in the coming weeks.\n\nEmiliano Martinez, one of the best goalkeepers in the world, and Jhon Duran are also going. From Crystal Palace's revitalised squad, thanks to the appointment of Oliver Glasner, Colombian duo Daniel Munoz and Jefferson Lerma will most likely be mainstays in Los Cafeteros' Copa America campaign, while Chris Richards will provide the USMNT with defensive solidity.\n\nRelated USA's Road to the Copa America Final The USA host the 2024 Copa America and they will be hoping to reach the latter stages of the tournament.\n\nWest Ham's Michail Antonio will be, despite being born in London, representing Jamaica this summer, having scored three goals in 12 outings for the Caribbean-based nation. His colleagues Edson Alvarez and Lucas Paqueta will be there, too, for Mexico and Brazil, respectively.\n\nTottenham Hotspur have enjoyed something of a resurgence under Ange Postecoglou - and, as a result, have three players from their north London squad heading to the United States in the coming week. Cristiano Romero, Giovanni Lo Celso and Rodrigo Bentancur will all be spending their off-season with a trophy in mind.\n\nThree Players - Copa America 2024\n\nClub\n\nPlayers\n\nAston Villa\n\nDouglas Luiz (Brazil), Emiliano Martinez (Argentina), Jhon Duran (Colombia)\n\nCrystal Palace\n\nChris Richards (USMNT), Daniel Munoz (Colombia), Jefferson Lerma (Colombia)\n\nTottenham\n\nCristian Romero (Argentina), Giovanni Lo Celso (Argentina), Rodrigo Bentancur (Uruguay)\n\nWest Ham\n\nEdson Alvarez (Mexico), Lucas Paqueta (Brazil), Michail Antonio (Jamaica)\n\nFour Players Wolverhampton Wanderers, Nottingham Forest, Liverpool, Brighton Close\n\nTo have four players representing your club at an international tournament is no mean feat, but Wolverhampton Wanderers, Nottingham Forest, Liverpool and Brighton & Hove Albion can hold their heads high with them watching a quartet of their players going to the United States this summer.\n\nFrom a Wolves perspective, Manchester United-linked Joao Gomes will be looking to impressive as a means of bumping up interest in his signature with a career-defining move inevitably around the corner. Liverpool's Alexis Mac Allister, on the back of a fruitful inaugural season with his current employers, will be on hand in the centre of the park to keep things compact for Argentina, while the Reds' primary shot stopper Allison Becker is on the plane for Brazil.\n\nRelated Every Winner in Copa America History GIVEMESPORT provides a detailed breakdown of every winner in Copa America history.\n\nGiven the competition from Manchester City's Ederson, whether the 31-year-old will get much game time, however, remains to be seen. Someone who is likely to play the majority of his nation's minutes is Liverpool and Uruguay sensation Darwin Nunez.\n\nBrighton also have four players heading to the United States this summer. The young and relatively inexperienced trio of Argentina's Valentin Barco and Julio Enciso alongside Ecuador's Jeremy Sarmiento will be looking to stake a claim on their respective squads.\n\nFour Players - Copa America 2024\n\nClub\n\nPlayers\n\nBrighton\n\nJeremy Sarmiento (Ecuador), Julio Enciso (Argentina), Tom McGill (Canada), Valentin Barco (Argentina)\n\nLiverpool\n\nAlexis Mac Allister (Argentina), Alisson (Brazil), Darwin Nunez (Uruguay), Luis Diaz (Colombia)\n\nNottingham Forest\n\nBrandon Aguilera (Costa Rica), Giovanni Reyna (USMNT), Gonzalo Montiel (Argentina), Matt Turner (USMNT)\n\nWolves\n\nDexter Lembikisa (Jamaica), Joao Gomes (Brazil), Santiago Bueno (Uruguay), Yerson Mosquera (Colombia)\n\nFive Players Fulham Close\n\nInterestingly, Fulham are the only club from the Premier League to have a quintet of players going to Copa America: Antonee Robinson and Tim Ream of USMNT, Brazil's Andreas Pereira, Canada ace Luc de Fougerolles and Jamaican talisman Bobby Decordova-Reid, many of whom are attracting interest in the off-season period.\n\nAn undeniable moment of joy and pride for the west London-based outfit, the likes of Robinson and Decordova-Reid could be the difference-makers for their respective nations once the competition gets underway. Robinson, alongside Ream, will form one half of the USMNT defence and will lean on their experience working together in England's top flight in order to boost their chances of reigning supreme on home soil.\n\nFive Players - Copa America 2024\n\nClub\n\nPlayers\n\nFulham\n\nAntonee Robinson (USMNT), Andreas Pereira (Brazil), Bobby Decordova-Reid (Jamaica), Luc de Fougerolles (Canada), Tim Ream All but two South American nations - Venezuela and Ecuador - have tasted glory before, while a guest team never has won. While the Copa Am\u00e9rica itself is a prize worth fighting for on its own, teams who enjoy a successful tournament also have the benefit of generating some serious positive momentum and good vibes ahead of the 2026 World Cup.\n\nWho are the true contenders and who will be leaving the U.S. on one of the first flights out?
