{"uri": "8186208082", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "02:41:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T02:41:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T02:34:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/just-enjoy-messi-and-di-maria-while-you-can-urges-scaloni/article_3751ac1e-d5f1-59be-8aca-a6e98dcc9fd3.html", "title": "Just enjoy Messi and Di Maria while you can urges Scaloni", "body": "Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni has urged his compatriots to not worry about when Lionel Messi and Angel Di Maria will hang up their boots and to instead just enjoy watching them in the Copa America.\n\nWorld champions and defending Copa America title holders, Argentina get the 16-team tournament under way against Canada at Mercedes Benz Stadium on Thursday.\n\nMessi, the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner who turns 37 on Monday, will captain Scaloni's team in what is surely his final edition of the continental championship.\n\nAnd with winger Angel Di Maria, 36, also reaching the final stages of his career, the end of an era is on the horizon for the 15-times Copa winners.\n\nBut Scaloni said that shouldn't be the focus around the team in the coming tournament.\n\n\"It doesn't make much sense to think about when they're gone. Let's enjoy them now, we'll see what happens later. Messi is fine, he's happy. I'm with renewed ideas and strength. It's a nice challenge to defend the title,\" he said.\n\nScaloni said he has a full strength side to pick from for the opening game against Jesse Marsch's Canada.\n\nChelsea midfielder Enzo Fernandez underwent a hernia operation in April but returned to action in the World Cup winners' recent friendlies against Ecuador and Guatemala and Scaloni said he is ready to go.\n\n\"We'll see if he plays tomorrow but he is in condition to start,\" the Argentine coach told a news conference where he appeared alongside midfielder Leandro Paredes.\n\nScaloni hinted that AS Roma midfielder Paredes is likely to start however and said that while he was keeping his starting eleven to himself, he had made his mind up.\n\nMore from this section Central China farmers face crop failures in 'withering' drought New mystery monolith appears in Nevada desert Two brand-new pools unveiled at Harry S. Truman High School\n\n\"I have the line-up, I have no doubts. I'm going to give it to them this afternoon, they don't know yet. They're all available for tomorrow's game, the ones we think are the best will play,\" he said.\n\n\"I could be wrong, but we always think about putting out the best. With me, whoever is best always plays. Paredes had to come off in the first game of the World Cup because we thought there were other guys who were better. And there's a reason why I have him next to me now,\" said Scaloni.\n\nShould Scaloni start with Fernandez on the bench his midfield trio is likely to be made up of Rodrigo De Paul, Paredes and Alexis Mac Allister\n\nArgentina have started their CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying campaign positively with five wins out of six games but Scaloni said he was looking forward to match-ups with teams from outside of South America.\n\nThis edition of the Copa America features six teams from the CONCACAF region with Argentina facing Canada as well as Chile and Peru in Group A.\n\nWhile the USA and Mexico are traditionally the strongest teams from CONCACAF, Scaloni said he has been impressed by Canada's progress.\n\n\"They have a very good team, with important players and a new coach who has brought new ideas. In the last World Cup they played very well, but didn't get the luck they deserved,\" he said, before warning against complacency.\n\n\"They are a difficult opponent. Anyone who thinks it's all been said and done is wrong. They're the best in their country and it's extremely difficult, especially at the start of a tournament. They can put us in trouble and we have to be prepared,\" he said.\n\nsev/rcw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186826347", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:33:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:33:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:32:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/football/copa-america-2024-biggest-win-margin-in-history-scoreline-argentina-brazil/article68304322.ece", "title": "Top three biggest margin of victories in Copa America history", "body": "There are wins and then, there are thumpings. Over the years, the Copa America has seen some heavily one-sided matches, where the opposition was completely blown away.\n\nSportstar looks at the three highest margin of victories in the history of the Copa America.\n\nArgentina 12-0 Ecuador\n\nJoint-record-time Copa America champion Argentina (15 titles) has the enviable record of securing the highest margin of victory in the competition's history.\n\nArgentina beat Ecuador 12-0 at the Estadio Centenario, Montevideo, Uruguay, on 22 January 1942. Ecuador lost all of its games that year and was already beaten 7-0 by Uruguay in its opening match.\n\nEcuador was already 6-0 down by half-time. Argentina's Manuel Moreno netted five goals in total, with Enrique Garcia, Adolfo Pedernera, Angel Perruca and Herminio Masantonio scoring four each.\n\nArgentina, however, did not win that edition, with Uruguay grabbing the title after finishing top with 12 points (In the earlier format, each team played against each of the other teams. Two points were awarded for a win, one point for a draw and no points for a defeat). Argentina finished runner-up with 10 points.\n\nArgentina 11-0 Venezuela\n\nArgentina also holds the record of having the second-highest margin of victories in the Copa America, where the Albiceleste beat Venezuela 11-0 in the 1975 edition.\n\nMario Killer, Mario Kempes and Mario Zanabria scored a brace each, with the other goals coming from Americo Gallego, Osvaldo Ardiles, Daniel Killer, Ramon Boveda and Leopoldo Luque.\n\nHowever, Argentina did not win that year too, with Peru grabbing the title.\n\nBrazil 10-0 Bolivia\n\nBrazil has the third-highest margin of victory in Copa America history with a 10-0 win against Bolivia in the 1949 edition.\n\nNininho scored a hat-trick in the match, while Zizinho, Simao and Claudio C Pinto scored a brace each. Jair scored the other goal of the match.\n\nBrazil followed up on this dominating win by going on to win that year.\n\nThey were 6-0 down by half-time against Argentina, with Manuel Moreno netting four goals (he would score five in total), Enrique Garcia, Adolfo Pedernera, Angel Perruca and Herminio Masantonio (4) would contribute the other goals. Argentina managed an 11-0 win against Venezuela in 1975 while Brazil are the only other side to reach double figures beating Bolivia 10-1 in 1949.\n\nLatest on SportstarIndia vs Afghanistan Live Messi has finally made his mark for the national team, securing a Copa Am\u00e9rica and World Cup title in the last three years.\n\nMessi is still showing his special talents at the age of 36 now as an Inter Miami player, and he will make everything tick for Argentina at this tournament once again.\n\nFlores is perhaps one of the lesser-known players on our list, but the 30-year-old has shown flashes of brilliance throughout his injury-riddled career.\n\nDespite never truly breaking out of the Americas, Flores has scored 16 goals in 73 appearances for his nation and will be called upon to provide a spark up top for La Bicolor in a tough Group A.\n\nYes, it is 2024 and we're still highlighting Alexis S\u00e1nchez as Chile's player to watch heading into a summer tournament.\n\nThe Chilean legend is still starting in every big game for his nation and will continue to do so in the United States during Copa Am\u00e9rica this summer.\n\n51 goals for your nation is already enough for legend-status, but S\u00e1nchez is not done yet.\n\nWhile it may have been easy to choose the likes of Alphonso Davies or Jonathan David for Canada's player to watch, Tajon Buchanan is truly starting to make a name for himself on the wing.\n\nThe Inter Milan man could become a key cog in the new Jesse Marsch machine out on the flank, with bags of pace and composure in the final-third.\n\nThe Feyenoord man has struggled when on the pitch for El Tri, but surely his superb club form will translate to international duties at some point.\n\nGim\u00e9nez is certainly the present and future of Mexico's attack, with 29 goal contributions in 30 Eredivisie games last season, but he will have to find that same form this summer if his nation are to get anything out of the tournament.\n\nMost football fans will know the name Mois\u00e9s Caicedo after the midfielder made a big-money move to Premier League giants Chelsea.\n\nWhile his form at Stamford Bridge has not been nearly as mercurial as when he was Brighton's midfield stalwart, Caicedo has the ability to control a game all on his own, and his passing range is wide enough to open up the defence of any of Ecuador's Group B rivals.\n\nGone are the days of Salom\u00f3n Rond\u00f3n strutting his stuff for West Brom, but that doesn't mean the 34-year-old is out of commission.\n\nThe Venezuelan just recently led Mexican side Pachuca to a CONCACAF Champions Cup title and will lead the line for La Vinotinto once again this summer.\n\nJamaica's new generation of players has yet to truly prove itself, but a player like Michail Antonio is just the level needed to make a splash in a tournament like Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nThere was plenty of off-field turmoil between the Reggae Boyz and the federation, but with that seemingly in the rearview mirror, Antonio and his mates can focus on the task at hand.\n\nWest Ham's record Premier League goalscorer has bagged just under 70 league goals with the Hammers, but now is the time to show his stuff for Jamaica.\n\nLike a few of our other players on this list, Reyna may not be the first name that jumps off a United States team sheet comprised of Christian Pulisic, Weston McKennie, Folarin Balugon and others, but the midfielder saves his best work for the Stars and Stripes.\n\nReyna is the creative flare in a usually industrious midfield for the United States, and will be the link between attack and defence as Gregg Berhalter's side play out of the back.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez seemingly became the butt of a running joke last season at Liverpool, garnering a reputation for missing big chances, but like Gio Reyna before him, N\u00fa\u00f1ez has turned it on for his nation as of late.\n\nThe striker bagged a hat-trick against fellow participants Mexico in a 4-0 rout just last week, and he'll head into the tournament in superb form for Uruguay as a result.\n\nCarrasquilla has made a name for himself in North America as one of the top midfielders in Major League Soccer, leading Houston to a U.S. Open Cup triumph over Lionel Messi and Inter Miami.\n\nThe 25-year-old has already earned over 50 caps for Panama and will be the key man in midfield if his nation are to stun the world and finish in the top-two of Group C.\n\nMiguel Terceros is likely a name that few people have heard heading into the tournament, but the Bolivian youngster could be poised for breakout summer in a side with relatively low expectations.\n\nThe 20-year-old Santos man can dribble with the best of them and could be the creative spark La Verde need as strong underdogs in Group C.\n\nLike their rivals Argentina, Brazil's player to watch was an easy choice -- Real Madrid star Vin\u00edcius J\u00fanior.\n\nBrazil's form heading into the tournament leaves plenty to be desired, but with stars like Vini and his supporting cast, they should be able to turn it on at any time.\n\nNo matter how poor the mood in the camp is, Vini can be the most electric player in Copa Am\u00e9rica if he feels like it.\n\nLuis D\u00edaz may not be the most prolific in front of goal, but as far as crafty South American wingers go, the Liverpool man is up there with the best.\n\nAfter a Premier League season in which he amassed 13 goal contributions, D\u00edaz is the face of a team that still boasts one-time Colombian saviour James Rodriguez, and it's his attacking flare that Los Cafeteros could rely on if they are to play a major role at the Copa this year.\n\nThe Brighton and Hove Albion youngster is another name on the list of burgeoning stars who could get their name in lights with a good showing in Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nBefore his move to the Premier League, Enciso became a household name in South America after becoming one of the youngest players to score in the Copa Libertadores. But can he now make a similar impact for his nation in a star-studded Group D?\n\nDespite not participating in the last World Cup cycle due to off-field differences with manager former Luis Fernando Suarez, Ugalde comes into the tournament as one of the brightest young talents in the Americas.\n\nThe 22-year-old's most prolific spell as a striker came for Dutch side FC Twente when he bagged 22 goals in 84 games before making the move to Spartak Moscow.\n\nUgalde found the back of the net against World Champions Argentina back in March, and Costa Rica will need something similar if they are Lionel Messi-starred Argentina will target the record 16th title while Canada are making their debut in one of the oldest and biggest international tournaments in the world.\n\nThe USA are hosting the tournament for the second time in history and fans will witness six new teams from North America participating in the 48th edition of the tournament. Brazil, the nine-time winners, will be without their captain Neymar due to an injury but are tipped to mount a title challenge once again with the likes of Vinicius Jr and Alisson Becker leading the start-studded side.\n\nArgentina famously equalled Uruguay's record for most titles after beating Brazil in the previous edition of the tournament in 2021. The Argentine captain Lionel Messi needs only five goals to surpass legendary Norberto M\u00e9ndez and Zizinho's record for most goals in the tournament.\n\nThe organisers changed the format of the tournament with six teams from the North American continent joining ten teams from South America. 16 teams are equally divided into groups of four with the defending champions Argentia getting comparatively easy opponents in Group A.\n\nAll teams will play once against other teams in their respective groups. The top two teams from each group will progress to the knockout stages - quarterfinals, semifinals and final.\n\nThe organisers are yet to announce official broadcasters for the Indian viewers. Sony Sports Network and FanCode are expected to be named TV broadcast and online streaming partners a day before the tournament begins on June 20.\n\n14 venues across the United States of America will host a total of 32 matches. {"uri": "2024-06-395011781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:34:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:34:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:22:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.kansascity.com/sports/article289392864.html", "title": "What to watch for when the 2024 Copa America (with the USMNT) comes to Kansas City", "body": "If you're interested in the 2026 World Cup coming to Kansas City, how about an international soccer appetizer?\n\nThe Copa America brings the oldest non-Olympic international soccer tournament stateside from June 20 to July 14.\n\nLike the 2026 World Cup, Kansas City is a host city for Copa America games, hosting two group-stage matches. Canada and Peru will face off on June 25 at Children's Mercy Park for their second match in Group A. Then, the United States Men's National Team will host Uruguay at GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium on July 1 for the final group play match in Group C.\n\nThe Copa America has been held regularly since 1916. This edition is the second time the tournament has been held in the United States, following the 2016 Copa America Centenario. This edition of the tournament brings together the 16 best national soccer teams in the Western Hemisphere.\n\nHere's a preview of each of the teams coming to Kansas City this summer:\n\nExpectations: Canada will make its first Copa America appearance in this tournament and is also coming off its second World Cup appearance in 2022. Getting out of the group stage would be a momentous step forward as the northern nation prepares to host its part of the 2026 FIFA World Cup.\n\nThree key players: Alphonso Davies is a global superstar playing at Bayern Munich in Germany, with rumors he's headed to Real Madrid, soccer's equivalent to the New York Yankees. You can't take your eyes off him when he's on the field. Jonathan David is a do-it-all type of striker with the speed to burn defenses. Canada's prospects of getting out of the group increase heavily if he's in form. Isma\u00ebl Kon\u00e9 is another talented midfielder who has enjoyed a quick rise. He's fast, skilled and can put out fires all over the midfield with his workmanlike ability.\n\nExpectations: Peru is nearing a generational turnover, as a significant portion of its international roster is filled with players in their mid-30s. After making the World Cup in 2018 and narrowly missing out on qualification for 2022, this might be the last swan song for Peru's most recent golden generation.\n\nThree key players: Goalkeeper Pedro Gallese, nicknamed \"El Pulpo\" or the octopus, is arguably Peru's best defensive player. Gallese spent the last few years playing in MLS with Orlando City and was one of the league's best shot-stoppers annually. He's somewhat eccentric and has a flair for the dramatic. Christian Cueva is a bit of a club journeyman but has been routinely important to Peru's hopes. He holds the No. 10 jersey for this tournament. Paolo Guerrero is a South American legend. He's the active leading goalscorer at the Copa America and has still found the back of the net for club and country even as he turned 40 this January.\n\nExpectations: Getting out of the group is a bare minimum. For the first time ever, the United States Men's National Team (USMNT) fileds a team comprised entirely of players who play their club trade in the top five European leagues. The USMNT talent is starting to come into its collective prime, which means expectations are raised. The bar for success has surpassed just getting out of the group.\n\nKey Players: Christian Pulisic scored 15 goals and provided eight assists in his first season with AC Milan, and had the best season of any American attacker. If Pulisic isn't at his best, the USMNT will struggle in the attack. Tyler Adams brings intensity and bite into the midfield when he's there, and the USMNT looks better for it. Adams is still returning from injury, so the more he can play for the USMNT, the better. Timothy Weah plays a more attacking role with the USMNT than he does with Juventus. The USMNT needs a secondary option for the attack to flow through, and Weah has the game-changing speed to bring it.\n\nExpectations: Uruguay has been phenomenal in World Cup Qualifying, defeating Argentina and Brazil in the last calendar year. With its pedigree in this tournament, getting out of the group is also a bare minimum. Uruguay is tied with Argentina for the most Copa America championships ever.\n\nKey Players: While Darwin Nu\u00f1ez doesn't finish with consistency at Liverpool, he has done so recently for his country. The minutes load over the days will limit Luis Suarez to super-sub minutes, so Nu\u00f1ez will be the guy for Uruguay up top. Federico Valverde is arguably the best box-to-box midfielder in the world right now. He's a workhorse with pace, power and a nose for the spectacular strike from distance. Ronald Araujo has been one of the best center backs in the world with Barcelona and is just as good as the right back for Uruguay. {"uri": "2024-06-395329865", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:02:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:02:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:22:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/just-enjoy-messi-and-di-maria-while-you-can-urges-scaloni/article_f1e8d43f-e300-56d5-8291-8c6482f22078.html", "title": "Just enjoy Messi and Di Maria while you can urges Scaloni", "body": "Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni has urged his compatriots to not worry about when Lionel Messi and Angel Di Maria will hang up their boots and to instead just enjoy watching them in the Copa America.\n\nWorld champions and defending Copa America title holders, Argentina get the 16-team tournament under way against Canada at Mercedes Benz Stadium on Thursday.\n\nMessi, the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner who turns 37 on Monday, will captain Scaloni's team in what is surely his final edition of the continental championship.\n\nAnd with winger Angel Di Maria, 36, also reaching the final stages of his career, the end of an era is on the horizon for the 15-times Copa winners.\n\nBut Scaloni said that shouldn't be the focus around the team in the coming tournament.\n\n\"It doesn't make much sense to think about when they're gone. Let's enjoy them now, we'll see what happens later. Messi is fine, he's happy. I'm with renewed ideas and strength. It's a nice challenge to defend the title,\" he said.\n\nScaloni said he has a full strength side to pick from for the opening game against Jesse Marsch's Canada.\n\nChelsea midfielder Enzo Fernandez underwent a hernia operation in April but returned to action in the World Cup winners' recent friendlies against Ecuador and Guatemala and Scaloni said he is ready to go.\n\n\"We'll see if he plays tomorrow but he is in condition to start,\" the Argentine coach told a news conference where he appeared alongside midfielder Leandro Paredes.\n\nScaloni hinted that AS Roma midfielder Paredes is likely to start however and said that while he was keeping his starting eleven to himself, he had made his mind up.\n\n\"I have the line-up, I have no doubts. I'm going to give it to them this afternoon, they don't know yet. They're all available for tomorrow's game, the ones we think are the best will play,\" he said.\n\n\"I could be wrong, but we always think about putting out the best. With me, whoever is best always plays. Paredes had to come off in the first game of the World Cup because we thought there were other guys who were better. And there's a reason why I have him next to me now,\" said Scaloni.\n\nShould Scaloni start with Fernandez on the bench his midfield trio is likely to be made up of Rodrigo De Paul, Paredes and Alexis Mac Allister\n\nArgentina have started their CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying campaign positively with five wins out of six games but Scaloni said he was looking forward to match-ups with teams from outside of South America.\n\nThis edition of the Copa America features six teams from the CONCACAF region with Argentina facing Canada as well as Chile and Peru in Group A.\n\nWhile the USA and Mexico are traditionally the strongest teams from CONCACAF, Scaloni said he has been impressed by Canada's progress.\n\n\"They have a very good team, with important players and a new coach who has brought new ideas. In the last World Cup they played very well, but didn't get the luck they deserved,\" he said, before warning against complacency.\n\n\"They are a difficult opponent. Anyone who thinks it's all been said and done is wrong. They're the best in their country and it's extremely difficult, especially at the start of a tournament. They can put us in trouble and we have to be prepared,\" he said.\n\nsev/rcw\n\nMore from this section\n\nLatinx Festival on L. (Winning the World Cup and the Copa America) was very nice but it's over,\" the Argentine manager told a news conference.\n\n\"Football matches are all different, there are no easier games than others. A lot of things can happen. The difficulty of France, Brazil or Canada can be the same.\n\n\"It will be a difficult Copa America as always, we are prepared for what is to come. We are doing well, with clear ideas and knowing the difficulty of this tournament.\"\n\nAhead of their opening match against Canada on Thursday, the 46-year-old said enjoying the game had been the key to his team's success after failing to win the 2015 and 2016 Copa finals and a semi-final exit in 2019.\n\n\"Beyond the titles, we have enjoyed a lot. It's a pleasure to watch how (the players) give their all,\" he said. \"That leads to being able to achieve things. We have shown that even if we didn't win like in 2019, we were able to continue and show you can do things.\n\n(Reporting by Janina Nuno Rios in Mexico City, editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187305081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:31:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:31:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:30:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.batimes.com.ar/news/sports/just-enjoy-messi-and-di-maria-while-you-can-urges-scaloni.phtml", "title": "Just enjoy Messi and Di Maria while you can, urges Scaloni", "body": "Lionel Scaloni urges compatriots to not worry about when Lionel Messi and \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda will hang up their boots and to instead just enjoy watching them play.\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni has urged his compatriots to not worry about when Lionel Messi and \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda will hang up their boots and to instead just enjoy watching them in the Copa America.\n\nWorld champions and defending Copa Am\u00e9rica title holders, Argentina get the 16-team tournament under way against Canada at Mercedes Benz Stadium on Thursday.\n\nMessi, the eight-times Ballon d'Or winner who turns 37 on Monday, will captain Scaloni's team in what is surely his final edition of the continental championship.\n\nAnd with winger \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda, 36, also reaching the final stages of his career, the end of an era is on the horizon for the 15-times Copa winners.\n\nBut Scaloni said that shouldn't be the focus around the team in the coming tournament.\n\n\"It doesn't make much sense to think about when they're gone. Let's enjoy them now, we'll see what happens later. Messi is fine, he's happy. I'm with renewed ideas and strength. It's a nice challenge to defend the title,\" he said.\n\nScaloni said he has a full strength side to pick from for the opening game against Jesse Marsch's Canada.\n\nChelsea midfielder Enzo Fern\u00e1ndez underwent a hernia operation in April but returned to action in the World Cup winners' recent friendlies against Ecuador and Guatemala and Scaloni said he is ready to go.\n\n\"We'll see if he plays tomorrow but he is in condition to start,\" the coach told a press conference where he appeared alongside midfielder Leandro Paredes.\n\nScaloni hinted that AS Roma midfielder Paredes is likely to start however and said that while he was keeping his starting 11 to himself, he had made his mind up.\n\n\"I have the line-up, I have no doubts. I'm going to give it to them this afternoon, they don't know yet. They're all available for tomorrow's game, the ones we think are the best will play,\" he said.\n\n\"I could be wrong, but we always think about putting out the best. With me, whoever is best always plays. Paredes had to come off in the first game of the World Cup because we thought there were other guys who were better. And there's a reason why I have him next to me now,\" said Scaloni.\n\nShould Scaloni start with Fern\u00e1ndez on the bench his midfield trio is likely to be made up of Rodrigo De Paul, Paredes and Alexis Mac Allister\n\nArgentina have started their CONMEBOL World Cup qualifying campaign positively with five wins out of six games but Scaloni said he was looking forward to match-ups with teams from outside of South America.\n\nThis edition of the Copa Am\u00e9rica features six teams from the CONCACAF region with Argentina facing Canada as well as Chile and Peru in Group A.\n\nWhile the USA and Mexico are traditionally the strongest teams from CONCACAF, Scaloni said he has been impressed by Canada's progress.\n\n\"They have a very good team, with important players and a new coach who has brought new ideas. In the last World Cup they played very well, but didn't get the luck they deserved,\" he said, before warning against complacency.\n\n\"They are a difficult opponent. Anyone who thinks it's all been said and done is wrong. They're the best in their country and it's extremely difficult, especially at the start of a tournament. {"uri": "8185652229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:32:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:32:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:30:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/soccer/arid-41419819.html", "title": "10 Premier League players who could catch the eye in the Copa America", "body": "Premier League fans will be familiar with a number of players taking part in the tournament, which ends with a Florida final on July 14.\n\nHere, we look at 10 men who could catch the eye in the United States.\n\nArgentinian midfielder Mac Allister had an impressive first season with Liverpool following his move from Brighton, with five goals and five assists in the Premier League. Strong performances at the 2022 World Cup add weight to the argument that the 25-year-old fully deserves to be a first-choice starter.\n\nDouglas Luiz, Brazil\n\nThe 26-year-old scored nine goals and claimed five assists to help Aston Villa secure Champions League football next season - and catch the eye of other clubs. However, before club football resumes the midfielder will be bidding to play an important role in Brazil's bid to regain their Copa America title.\n\nDarwin Nunez, Uruguay\n\nLiverpool's Nunez should go into the tournament full of confidence, following a hat-trick in the friendly win against Mexico. The 24-year-old forward is a handful and can help his country push for a 16th Copa America title - and first for 13 years.\n\nJulian Alvarez, Argentina\n\nLike Mac Allister, Alvarez will be keen to replicate his fine form at the 2022 World Cup. The 24-year-old Manchester City forward can be key in the world champions' quest for more silverware, having scored 11 goals and registered nine assists in the Premier League in 2023-24.\n\nMoises Caicedo, Ecuador\n\nThe 22-year-old can take control of the Ecuador midfield and be an important player for his country. Chelsea's big-money signing from Brighton prospered towards the end of the Premier League season and finished with a flourish, scoring from the halfway line in the final match against Bournemouth.\n\nLuis Diaz, Colombia\n\nDiaz, 27, proved he has the pedigree for this tournament in 2021, scoring four goals in five games. The winger's creativity for Liverpool brought eight goals and five assists last season and he can again be a strong influence for Colombia this summer.\n\nCristian Romero, Argentina\n\nRomero played a vital role in Argentina's World Cup win two years ago, starting six of their seven matches. Tottenham's 26-year-old centre-back, who also carries a threat in the opposition penalty area, will hope it is the same story in the Copa America.\n\nAntonee Robinson, United States\n\nMilton Keynes-born Robinson was one of the standout left-backs in the Premier League last season. If the 26-year-old can maintain his form - and his team-mates collectively excel - the United States could make the most of their host nation status and enjoy a fruitful tournament.\n\nEdson Alvarez, Mexico\n\nWith a solid first season in the top flight behind him following his move from Ajax, Alvarez should be full of confidence heading into the Copa America. Mexico have never won the tournament and will likely need the 26-year-old West Ham midfielder to be at his best if they are to break their duck.\n\nBruno Guimaraes, Brazil\n\nThe 26-year-old midfielder goes into the tournament on the back of two consistent seasons with Newcastle, helping him become a favourite with the fans. If he can help Dorival Junior's team land the Copa America for a 10th time, he could achieve similar cult status in his home nation.", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", Lionel Messi, in what could be his final international tournament.\n\nWhat is the mascot for Copa America 2024?\n\nThe official mascot of the Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 will be an eagle named Capitan.\n\nAs per the tournament organisers, the inspiration for the choice of an eagle as the mascot was born from the symbolism that this majestic animal has in various cultures of the Americas, illustrating strength, boldness, and excellence.\n\nCapitan also was explained to represent the unique fusion between the South American passion for football and the vibrant American To celebrate the start of the event, the developers at Electronic Arts have launched a new set of mystery Objectives in EA Sports FC 24. To complete these five Objectives, you'll need to use specific player cards to complete various in-game tasks. If you don't know which cards to use, you'll be left out to dry because EA Sports FC 24 has turned several of these Objectives into riddles players need to puzzle out. Below, you'll find a full list of answers for the Copa America Throwback Objective, giving you an easy way to learn all the answers and wrap up this Objective group quickly in EA Sports FC 24.\n\nAll Copa America Throwback Objectives in EA Sports FC 24\n\nAs mentioned, there are five Objectives to complete to finish the Copa America Throwback. Two of them require you to solve puzzles Electronic Arts has given. That makes this Objective group a bit easier than the EURO Throwback group EA dropped last week, but you still need to use specific players. It's worth noting that if you don't have those players, you can try to use them in a Draft mode. That worked with last week's Objective, so you'll probably be able to do the same. Here are all of the answers for the Copa America Throwback Objective:\n\nBuzzing in Bolivia - As the host nation in 1963, Bolivia had a lot to play for. They exceeded all expectations and emerged as the tournament champions. Score 4 goals in any game mode using Copa America players. Any players from Argentina, Canada, Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Jamaica, Mexico, Venezuela, Bolivia, Panama, USA, Uruguay, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, or Paraguay. Columbian Wall - Host nation Colombia claimed their first title in 2001! World-class defense matched with a powerful attack helped them conquer all opponents. Score 11 goals in any game mode using players from Colombia. Colombia. Back to Back - Chile was unstoppable during their 2015-16 run, battling hard and winning both years. Win two matches in any game mode while having at least two Copa America Path to Glory players in your starting 11. Boris Cespedes and Adalberto Carrasquillia are available on the Season Reward track and are the easiest players to get who fit this. Gifted Athlete - This player holds the Copa record for the most assists and also lifted the trophy in 2021. Assist 10 goals using players from this player's nation in any game mode. Argentina (Lionel Messi) Top 3 - Only three nations have won the title more than eight times. Win six matches in any game mode while having a full squad of players from any of those three nations. Argentina, Brazil, and Uruguay (Make sure your full bench also only includes players from these nations)\n\nOnce you complete all five Objectives, you'll earn 2,000 XP and an 87 x2 Rare Gold Players Pack. Copa America Throwback is available until July 11th, giving you plenty of time to complete it.\n\nEA Sports FC 24 is available now on PlayStation, Xbox, and PC platforms.", "source": {"uri": It happens to me with the games at Inter Miami.\"\n\n\"During the games I don't say anything to them. Afterwards, we talk, we comment. But it also depends on the moment and how you tell them. He's more susceptible, but he already realises when he does something wrong or right and looks for me to talk to. Not Mateo. Brazil, on the other hand, is full of stars but has struggled to gel on the field. The absences of Neymar, Ederson, and Casemiro are significant. {"uri": "8186783512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:07:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:07:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:06:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/football/news/pink-card-substitutes-rules-concussion-subs-copa-america-2024/f3f6e34c0fef3db198adb000", "title": "What is a pink card at Copa America 2024? Substitute rules for concussions and replacements for head injuries", "body": "The 2024 Copa America is underway. In total, 16 teams are ready to do battle as they aim to win one of the most prestigious tournaments in world football.\n\nTen CONMEBOL teams and six invited nations from CONCACAF will compete in the United States from June 20-July 14 for continental glory and bragging rights.\n\nFans will expect the usual high drama and entertainment that comes with the best national teams from the region gathering every four years, but this tournament will also be a little different. As well as being expanded to 16 teams, ahead of the 2024 kickoff the South American football governing body also announced a major change to the substitute rules for the tournament, most notably introducing the use of a pink card by referees as well as the traditional yellow and red.\n\nHere, The Sporting News explains what it is and how it will work at Copa America 2024, along with all the rules for substitution regulations at the tournament finals.\n\nMORE: Copa America bracket, full schedule of matches and latest results, updated LIVE\n\nThe pink card at Copa America 2024 will be used by the referee to signal for a substitution in the event of a suspected head trauma or concussion.\n\nEach team can make concussion substitutes independent of the five permitted regular substitutions they are allowed during matches at the tournament. The rule is designed to protect player welfare.\n\nOnce a concussion substitution has been taken, the opposing team will also have the opportunity to make a sixth substitution.\n\nThe competition's governing body, CONMEBOL, has also confirmed that players suspected of suffering a concussion will not be able to return to the field and that they will be assessed in the dressing room or taken to a hospital, if required.\n\nTeam doctors will then be required to submit a complete concussion assessment report within 24 hours of the end of the match in which the suspected head injury happened.\n\nCONMEBOL have also confirmed that for this year's tournament in USA, teams can make up to five 'regular' (non-concussion related) substitutions during 90 minutes.\n\nCoaches must utilize these in a maximum of three stoppages in play per team (which excludes half-time and other match delays).\n\nIt's worth noting that if subs are made during any drinks break for hot or humid weather, these will be counted as stoppages.\n\nIf a game goes into extra time, teams can make one extra substitution, with one extra stoppage of play per team allowed in that extra period. If a team has already used all their substitutions, and a player must come off the pitch due to injury (non-concussion related), the club will have to finish the match with 10 men.\n\nA player who has been subbed off the pitch is not allowed to later be brought back on.\n\nAny unused substitutes from regulation time (90 minutes) are carried over into extra time; for example, if a side only made four substitutions in 90 minutes, they will have the luxury to make a double change in extra time.\n\nThese changes align with the substitution regulations introduced in major domestic football leagues and recent international competitions. The aim is to reduce the increased risk of player injuries and burnout due to fixture congestion, which resulted from the postponement of previous tournaments because of COVID-19.\n\nMORE: FIFA Ranking for all Copa America sides\n\nTeams at this summer's men's Copa America tournament have been allowed to name rosters of up to 26 players, instead of the usual 23.\n\nThat decision was confirmed by CONMEBOL following a meeting held in Thailand on May 16.\n\nDespite the expanded overall squad, the maximum number of delegation members on the sidelines on match days (including players and coaching staff) will remain at 23. For example, if a side chooses to field 26 players, 11 on the field and 15 on the bench, the maximum number of staff on the bench should be eight.\n\nA similar decision for this summer's European Championship in Germany was announced in April, even though FIFA decided to stick with 23-player rosters during the most recent men's and women's World Cups.\n\nMORE: Copa America winners, who has won the trophy before?\n\nTeams had to provide CONMEBOL with a final list containing a maximum of 26 players by the squad deadline of June 12, 2024, a week prior to the start of the tournament.\n\nAfter the final lists are submitted, teams can only make late replacements and withdrawals for serious injuries, illnesses, or medical reasons up to 24 hours before their first match in the competition.\n\nBut once Copa America 2024 is up and running, teams must find alternative solutions from within their submitted 26-man squads.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": For the second time in history, the event dubbed \"The World's Oldest Continental Tournament\" will take place in the United States.\n\nOn Thursday (June 20), the 71,000-seat Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta will witness the inauguration of Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024, marking the start of an exciting month of soccer. The opening ceremony will begin one hour before the first match, scheduled for 8 p.m. ET, where the Argentina national team, champions of Copa Am\u00e9rica 2021, will face Canada.\n\nThe men's soccer tournament, hosted by the South American Football Confederation (Conmebol), will be played in 14 venues across the U.S., including cities such as Las Vegas, Kansas City and Los Angeles. The 32-game competition will culminate on July 14 at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida, where the top two teams will face off for the championship title in its 48th edition.\n\nThis year, the tournament adopted a new format with the participation of 16 teams, instead of the usual 12, which will compete for the title of champion of Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024. Among them, 10 teams represent the Conmebol and six represent the northern confederation, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (Concacaf).\n\nCopa Am\u00e9rica 2024 will be available in Spanish in the United States on Univision, TUDN and UniM\u00e1s. It will also be available on FuboTV and TUDN streaming services.\n\nIn Mexico, Televisa, Canal 5 and Azteca 7 television channels will broadcast the matches. They will also be available through TUDN on a paid basis and the streaming application VIX for free.\n\nIn Colombia, the matches will be broadcast free of charge on Caracol and RCN channels. They will also be available through DIRECTV's paid signal.\n\nIn Argentina, they will be available for free on TV P\u00fablica, Telefe, TyC Sports. In addition, DIRECTV will have the games for a monthly subscription.\n\nThe 3Cat platform will have all 32 matches free of charge. A full Brazil international at just 17, Endrick has already earned comparisons to Selecao strikers of the past and is a player bursting with potential.\n\nAfter becoming the youngest player to appear for Palmeiras, the teenager has since hit 21 goals in 82 appearances for the Brazilian side and does not turn 18 until next month. For Brazil, he's also made an instant impact.\n\nA debut goal arrived in a friendly win over England in March - becoming the youngest player to score an international goal at Wembley - and has been followed with further strikes against Spain and Mexico in preparation for this summer's tournament.\n\nIconic Performances: A teenage Pel\u00e9 conquers the world\n\nIf this is to be Lionel Messi's farewell for Argentina, it is perhaps a fitting stage. The United States - where Messi-mania has taken a grip after his move to MLS and Inter Miami - will host the Copa America as the La Albiceleste aim for back-to-back titles.\n\nGone are the ghosts of past disappointments in the blue and white of the national team, with successes at the 2021 Copa America, 2022 Finalissima and 2022 World Cup completing the set for Messi.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner has 14 goals in 15 games for Inter Miami in 2024 and plenty of the old magic remains.\n\nMessi, Qatar, and the fulfilment of a football fairytale\n\nKendry P\u00e1ez will be the youngest player in the tournament with the Ecuadorian having only turned 17 last month. Such is the standing in which the midfielder is held, he has already won eight caps for the senior national team and opened his account for Ecuador in a World Cup qualifier against Bolivia in October.\n\nEcuador have an exciting collection of young talent that includes Chelsea midfielder Moises Caicedo and Bundesliga defensive duo Piero Hincapi\u00e9 and Willian Pacho, each of whom have attracted Premier League interest. Paez is one player already set for English football, having agreed a deal to sign for Chelsea upon turning 18 next year.\n\nSantiago Gimenez will lead the line for a Mexico team that enter the tournament in mixed form, having lost three of their last four fixtures. However, El Tricolor possess a goalscorer coveted across Europe with Gimenez having been a prolific presence for Feyenoord across the last two seasons.\n\nThe 23-year-old endured a slow start in the Eredivisie after arriving from Cruz Azul, scoring just twice before the winter break in 2022-23. From there, however, his numbers have been phenomenal. Gimenez ended that debut campaign with 23 goals in all competitions and added another 26 for the Rotterdam outfit this season.\n\nHe turned down the opportunity to represent Argentina, the nation of his birth, in favour of adorning Mexico's colours and follows in the footsteps of his father who won five caps for the national team.\n\nA strong tournament will lengthen his list of suitors, while Gimenez will want to improve on a modest record of four goals from 27 caps to date.\n\nDarwin Nunez remains the enigma Liverpool are yet to solve with two seasons in a red shirt having seen the forward frustrate and delight in equal measure.\n\nThe 24-year-old appeared to make strides of progress in 2023-24 as he returned 18 goals and 13 assists in all competitions, though he lost his place in the team across the run-in and remains erratic around goal.\n\nNunez has the raw ingredients to be an elite number nine and has started to become the main man for Uruguay. He has scored eight goals in his last seven caps, is the leading scorer in South America's 2026 FIFA World Cup qualification phase, and netted a hat-trick in a warm-up win over Mexico this Conmebol orchestrates this continental showdown.\n\nArgentina, fresh off a 2021 victory in Brazil, snapped a 28-year title drought. In the finale, Angel Di Mar\u00eda delivered the lone, decisive strike against Brazil at Rio's Maracan\u00e3.\n\nThe win echoed the heroics of Claudio Caniggia and Gabriel Batistuta back in 1993.\n\nMeanwhile, Uruguay last savored triumph in 2011, under Argentine tactician Marcelo Bielsa. They dominated Paraguay 3-0 at Buenos Aires' Monumental Stadium.\n\nTrailing behind, Brazil boasts nine championships. Their latest conquest was in 2019, overcoming Peru 3-1 in a thrilling final, again at the Maracan\u00e3.\n\nOthers linger in the backdrop. Paraguay, Chile, and Peru have each nabbed the title twice. Colombia and Bolivia trail with a solitary victory each.\n\nThis year's tournament unfolds in the United States, featuring a compelling opener between Argentina, the 2022 World Cup champions, and Canada. They're pitted in Group A alongside Chile and Peru.\n\nPowerhouses Clash: Argentina and Uruguay Lead in Copa America Glory\n\nFurthermore, Group B features a mix of contenders: Mexico, Ecuador, Venezuela, and Jamaica. In Group C, the hosts, the United States, face Uruguay, Panama, and Bolivia.\n\nThe action culminates in Miami with Group D's Brazil, Colombia, Paraguay, and Costa Rica clashing for supremacy, setting the stage for the grand finale on July 14.\n\nThis clash of football elites not only celebrates sport but also stitches together a tapestry of national pride and regional rivalries.\n\nThe Copa {"uri": "8183994101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "16:56:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T16:56:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T16:54:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3372549116611481, "url": "https://www.bullfrag.com/copa-america-2024-will-use-artificial-intelligence-and-all-this-technology-to-improve-the-tournament/", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 will use Artificial Intelligence and all this technology to improve the tournament", "body": "The Copa America 2024 It promises to be an unprecedented sporting event, not only because of the level of football that will be seen in each match, but also because of the implementation of different cutting-edge technological innovations that will seek to improve the experience for everyone on and off the field of play. The interesting thing here is that even this tournament will join the current furor over the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and this will be a fundamental part of the applied technology, but not the only one.\n\nFrom in-depth game analysis to optimizing the fan experience, AI and video surveillance cameras will play a crucial role in this tournament. Today we will give a brief review of each of these new features that have already been officially announced.\n\nIt is a fact that this tournament, from the perspective of the technology it will implement, will be one of the most relevant in history.\n\nAccording to a detailed article by colleagues at Sports ShowcaseOn the playing field, VAR (video referee) technology will be reinforced with stereoscopic 3D vision systems, allowing referees to make more precise and fair decisions in controversial plays. This will minimize controversial errors and ensure a smoother flow of the match.\n\nAt the same time, the television broadcasts of the Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024 will offer images 4K high quality, giving fans a more immersive and exciting visual experience. Furthermore, the use of interfaces Augmented reality will integrate real-time statistics and interactive replays, further enriching the viewer experience.\n\n\"Video cameras, accompanied by artificial intelligence (AI), will play a crucial role in the Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024. On the field, these tools will allow exhaustive analysis of the game, with new video systems that allow stereoscopic 3D views of the action, facilitating the making of more precise referee decisions and avoiding controversial errors that could affect the development of the match. Meanwhile, off the field, video surveillance cameras will also play a fundamental role in ensuring safety and optimizing the fan experience,\" said Michael Luman (Product Manager) of Dahua Technology.\n\nIn fact, Artificial Intelligence will also be used off the field, to optimize the logistics and security of the event. Since crowd management systems with predictive analysis will be implemented to avoid crowds and guarantee the safety of attendees.\n\nFans will also be able to enjoy different mobile applications specially designed for the Copa Am\u00e9rica 2024, which will offer exclusive content, live surveys and interactive experiences, encouraging greater participation and inclusion in the tournament. But it should be noted that None of them are exactly official.\n\nSo the tournament will mark a milestone in the integration of cutting-edge technology in football, with tools that will not only benefit this competition, but will also lay the foundation for a more technologically advanced future in the world of sports in general.\n\nIn a way the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica will serve as a laboratory to test and evaluate these new technologies and in that aspect the tournament will also be very exciting.", "source": {"uri": "bullfrag.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bullfrag"}, \u2b06\ufe0f\n\nPlayed 29 minutes against Mexico and 25 minutes against the USA, coming off the bench in both games.\n\nDespite this, he scored the goal that saved the team against the Mexicans with a precise header in the 50th minute of the second half.\n\nDorival Jr. has been cautious with the 17-year-old, but Endrick shows he can be very useful in the Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nRodrygo \u2b06\ufe0f\n\nHe is the second most important player on the Brazilian National Team, only behind Vini Jr.\n\nWith his Real Madrid teammate being somewhat subdued (see below), it was up to Rodrygo to take on the responsibility up front.\n\nHe didn't play against Mexico but was the best player on the field against the USA, scoring Brazil's only goal.\n\nHowever, the Girona forward has given the coach something to think about, especially with his performance in the first game.\n\nEven if he starts the Copa Am\u00e9rica on the bench, he is an interesting option to add speed to the attack and Today, however, the scenario is different.\n\nEven with \u00c9derson injured, some fans are questioning Alisson and calling for Bento to be the starter.\n\nThe three goals conceded in the two friendlies -- especially the goal by the USA -- have increased the criticism.\n\nAfter the mistake on Wednesday (12th), he made good saves to prevent a loss. He lost the ball, leading to Mexico's first goal.\n\nHe couldn't replicate his previous intensity. With strong competition, Paquet\u00e1 starts the Copa Am\u00e9rica with his spot under threat.\n\nVini Jr \u2b07\ufe0f\n\nHe is the star of the Brazilian National Team, an undisputed starter, and a favorite for the 2024 Ballon d'Or.\n\nBecause of all this, fans expected more from him. He couldn't shine against the United States.\n\nTo make matters worse, he missed a clear chance that would have given Brazil the victory in the final moments.\n\nHe needs to regain his top-level form
